CC   -!- FUNCTION: Protein kinase that seems to play a role in the
CC       regulation of cell morphogenesis and proliferation.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + a protein = ADP + a phosphoprotein.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associates with PAG1/TAO3 and interacts with MOB2.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11854408, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12196508}.

CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein kinase superfamily. STE Ser/Thr
CC       protein kinase family. COT1 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Co-chaperone that binds to the molecular chaperone Hsp70
CC       (SSA1 and SSA2). Regulates Hsp70 ATPase activity (By similarity).
CC       Required for recovery from heat shock. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12482202}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with HSC82, HSP104, MDY2, SSA1 AND SSA2.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17441508}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12285:MDY2; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-31784, EBI-34904;
CC       P25491:YDJ1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-31784, EBI-10420;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 9424 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SGT family. {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "Structural basis of the radicicol resistance displayed by a fungal
RT   hsp90.";
RL   ACS Chem. Biol. 4:289-297(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Molecular chaperone that promotes the maturation,
CC       structural maintenance and proper regulation of specific target
CC       proteins involved in cell cycle control and signal transduction.
CC       Undergoes a functional cycle that is linked to its ATPase
CC       activity. The nucleotide-free form of the dimer is found in an
CC       open conformation in which the N-termini are not dimerized and the
CC       complex is ready for client protein binding. Binding of ATP
CC       induces large conformational changes, resulting in the formation
CC       of a ring-like closed structure in which the N-terminal domains
CC       associate intramolecularly with the middle domain and also
CC       dimerize with each other, stimulating their intrinsic ATPase
CC       activity and acting as a clamp on the substrate. Finally, ATP
CC       hydrolysis results in the release of the substrate. This cycle
CC       probably induces conformational changes in the client proteins,
CC       thereby causing their activation. Interacts dynamically with
CC       various co-chaperones that modulate its substrate recognition,
CC       ATPase cycle and chaperone function. Required for growth at high
CC       temperatures. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17114002}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by geldanamycin, macbecin I and
CC       radicicol, which bind to the ATP-binding pocket. Co-chaperones
CC       CDC37, SBA1 and STI1 reduce ATPase activity. Co-chaperones AHA1
CC       and HCH1 increase ATPase activity.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with the co-chaperones AHA1, CDC37,
CC       CNS1, CPR6, CPR7, HCH1, SBA1, SSE1 and STI1. CNS1, CPR6, CPR7 and
CC       STI1. Interacts directly with the substrates GCN2, HAP1 and STE11.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10480867, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10567567,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10664467, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12504007,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14718169, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14739935,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16625188, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17114002,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18357975, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19236053,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7929182, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8939862,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9230303, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9632755,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9632766, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9817749,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9819421, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9925731}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=10; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-8659;

CC       P53858:BNI4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-3704;
CC       P06101:CDC37; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-4266;
CC       P33313:CNS1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-4806;
CC       P53691:CPR6; NbExp=13; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-5429;

CC       P43581:HXT10; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-8750;
CC       P27705:MIG1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-10913;
CC       P35198:MTH1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-11561;

CC       P41808:SMK1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-17457;
CC       P10591:SSA1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-8591;
CC       P10592:SSA2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-8603;

CC       P15705:STI1; NbExp=18; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-18418;
CC       P25638:TAH1; NbExp=10; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-21956;
CC       P04637:TP53 (xeno); NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-366083;
CC       Q12407:YDL199C; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8659, EBI-33162;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expressed constitutively and induced by high
CC       temperatures dependent on transcription factor HSF1. According to
CC       PubMed:2674684, it is constitutively expressed at low levels,
CC       however, due to the specificity of the antibody, this result is
CC       unsure. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2674684, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9296388}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The TPR repeat-binding motif mediates interaction with TPR
CC       repeat-containing proteins like the co-chaperones AHA1, CDC37,
CC       CNS1, CPR6, CPR7, HCH1, SBA1, SSE1 and STI1. CNS1, CPR6, CPR7 and
CC       STI1.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 444943 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the heat shock protein 90 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Molecular chaperone that promotes the maturation,
CC       structural maintenance and proper regulation of specific target
CC       proteins involved in cell cycle control and signal transduction
CC       such as CNA2. Undergoes a functional cycle that is linked to its
CC       ATPase activity (By similarity). Interacts dynamically with
CC       various co-chaperones that modulate its substrate recognition,
CC       ATPase cycle and chaperone function. Required for growth at high
CC       temperatures. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11094077}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with the co-chaperone SGT1. Interacts directly
CC       with the substrate CNA2. Interacts with NAP1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11094077, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15340069,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18086883}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12449:AHA1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8666, EBI-37072;
CC       P08566:ARO1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8666, EBI-2883;
CC       P33313:CNS1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8666, EBI-4806;
CC       P47103:CPR7; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8666, EBI-5436;
CC       P53043:PPT1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8666, EBI-13796;
CC       P38164:SEA4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8666, EBI-21365;
CC       Q02821:SRP1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8666, EBI-1797;
CC       P10591:SSA1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8666, EBI-8591;
CC       P15705:STI1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8666, EBI-18418;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Mitochondrion.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expressed constitutively at a high level and is
CC       moderately induced by high temperatures dependent on transcription
CC       factor HSF1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2674684,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9296388}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The TPR repeat-binding motif mediates interaction with TPR
CC       repeat-containing proteins. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 132053 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the heat shock protein 90 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 153-405.
RX   PubMed=18268327; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0712032105;
RA   Wickner R.B., Dyda F., Tycko R.;
RT   "Amyloid of Rnq1p, the basis of the [PIN+] prion, has a parallel in-
RT   register beta-sheet structure.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 105:2403-2408(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Transferable epigenetic modifier which forms a prion
CC       responsible for the non-Mendelian trait [PIN+]. The native
CC       function of the soluble protein is unknown.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10678178, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11511345}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-21708, EBI-21708;
CC       P25294:SIS1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-21708, EBI-17244;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The prion domain (PrD) is a Gln/Asn (Q/N)-rich domain,
CC       which is unstructured in its native, soluble form, and which forms
CC       a parallel in-register beta-sheet in its amyloid form.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: [PIN+], also known as [RNQ+], is the prion form of
CC       RNQ1 (PubMed:10678178). [PIN+] is the result of a conformational
CC       change of the cellular RNQ1 protein that becomes self-propagating
CC       and infectious. This conformational change generates a form of
CC       RNQ1 that assembles into amyloid fibrils (PubMed:17097676). [PIN+]
CC       promotes de novo [PSI+] formation upon SUP35 overproduction
CC       (cross-seeding) (PubMed:11511345). [PIN+] can be cured by GdnHCl
CC       and by deletion of the molecular chaperone HSP104, which is
CC       required for [PIN+] propagation (PubMed:10678178).
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10678178, ECO:0000305|PubMed:11511345,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:17097676}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1140 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA34615.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=323; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Multiubiquitin binding protein.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The 26S proteasome is composed of a core protease, known
CC       as the 20S proteasome, capped at one or both ends by the 19S
CC       regulatory complex (RC). The RC is composed of at least 18
CC       different subunits in two subcomplexes, the base and the lid,
CC       which form the portions proximal and distal to the 20S proteolytic
CC       core, respectively (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P48510:DSK2; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-15949, EBI-6174;
CC       P38764:RPN1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-15949, EBI-15913;
CC       P33297:RPT5; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15949, EBI-13920;
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 17200 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the proteasome subunit S5A family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [13]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.95 ANGSTROMS) OF 2-239 IN COMPLEX WITH RPN8,
RP   AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=24463465; DOI=10.1038/nsmb.2771;
RA   Worden E.J., Padovani C., Martin A.;
RT   "Structure of the Rpn11-Rpn8 dimer reveals mechanisms of substrate
RT   deubiquitination during proteasomal degradation.";
RL   Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 21:220-227(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the lid subcomplex of the 26S proteasome, a
CC       multiprotein complex involved in the ATP-dependent degradation of
CC       ubiquitinated proteins. RPN11 is the only catalytically active
CC       member of the lid and serves as the essential deubiquitinase of
CC       the proteasome. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12183636,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21075847, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24463465}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Thiol-dependent hydrolysis of ester,
CC       thioester, amide, peptide and isopeptide bonds formed by the C-
CC       terminal Gly of ubiquitin (a 76-residue protein attached to
CC       proteins as an intracellular targeting signal).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the lid subcomplex of the 19S proteasome
CC       regulatory particle complex (also named PA700 complex). The 26S
CC       proteasome consists of a 20S proteasome core and two 19S
CC       regulatory subunits. Interacts directly with RPN8 and STS1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21075847, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23589842,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23911091, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24463465}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12250:RPN5; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-11219, EBI-15935;
CC       Q08723:RPN8; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-11219, EBI-36176;
CC       Q04062:RPN9; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-11219, EBI-15944;
CC       P33299:RPT1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11219, EBI-13910;
CC       P40327:RPT2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-11219, EBI-13901;
CC       P33298:RPT3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11219, EBI-13905;
CC       Q01939:RPT6; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-11219, EBI-13914;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The JAMM motif is required for the deubiquitination and
CC       degradation of ubiquitinated substrates.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12183636}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-acetylated by NAT3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12504901}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 16400 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase M67A family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: This essential protein binds to polyadenylated RNA and
CC       single-stranded DNA. It may be involved not only in RNA processing
CC       but also in transcription regulation. Believed to associate
CC       directly with nascent RNA polymerase II transcripts and remain
CC       associated during subsequent nuclear RNA processing reactions.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q04839:GFD1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-11770, EBI-27549;
CC       P38074:HMT1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-11770, EBI-8394;
CC       P38217:KAP104; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-11770, EBI-9152;
CC       Q02455:MLP1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-11770, EBI-11009;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 9670 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the NAB2 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Meisinger C., Pfannschmidt S., Rissler M., Milenkovic D., Becker T.,
RA   Stojanovski D., Youngman M.J., Jensen R.E., Chacinska A., Guiard B.,
RA   Pfanner N., Wiedemann N.;
RT   "The morphology proteins Mdm12/Mmm1 function in the major beta-barrel
RT   assembly pathway of mitochondria.";
RL   EMBO J. 26:2229-2239(2007).
RN   [18]
RP   FUNCTION, IDENTIFICATION IN ERMES/MDM COMPLEX, AND SUBCELLULAR
RP   LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=19556461; DOI=10.1126/science.1175088;
RA   Kornmann B., Currie E., Collins S.R., Schuldiner M., Nunnari J.,
RA   Weissman J.S., Walter P.;
RT   "An ER-mitochondria tethering complex revealed by a synthetic biology
RT   screen.";
RL   Science 325:477-481(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ERMES/MDM complex, which serves as a
CC       molecular tether to connect the endoplasmic reticulum and
CC       mitochondria. Components of this complex are involved in the
CC       control of mitochondrial shape and protein biogenesis and may
CC       function in phospholipid exchange. MDM10 is involved in the late
CC       assembly steps of the general translocase of the mitochondrial
CC       outer membrane (TOM complex). Functions in the TOM40-specific
CC       route of the assembly of outer membrane beta-barrel proteins,
CC       including the association of TOM40 with the receptor TOM22 and
CC       small TOM proteins. Can associate with the SAM(core) complex as
CC       well as the MDM12-MMM1 complex, both involved in late steps of the
CC       major beta-barrel assembly pathway, that is responsible for
CC       biogenesis of all outer membrane beta-barrel proteins. May act as
CC       a switch that shuttles between both complexes and channels
CC       precursor proteins into the TOM40-specific pathway. Plays a role
CC       in mitochondrial morphology and in the inheritance of
CC       mitochondria. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03102,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12454062, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15239954,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16760475, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17410204,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8089171,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9628893}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the ER-mitochondria encounter structure
CC       (ERMES) or MDM complex, composed of MMM1, MDM10, MDM12 and MDM34.
CC       Associates with the mitochondrial outer membrane sorting assembly
CC       machinery SAM(core) complex, which consists of SAM35, SAM37 and
CC       SAM50, to form a SAM(holo) complex. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03102, ECO:0000269|PubMed:13679517,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15239954, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17410204,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q92328:MDM12; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-10580, EBI-10584;
CC       P14693:SAM35; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-10580, EBI-24602;
CC       P53969:SAM50; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-10580, EBI-28646;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion outer membrane
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03102, ECO:0000269|PubMed:13679517,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407407,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8089171}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03102,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:13679517, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407407, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8089171}. Note=The ERMES/MDM complex localizes
CC       to a few discrete foci (around 10 per single cell), that represent
CC       mitochondria-endoplasmic reticulum junctions. These foci are often
CC       found next to mtDNA nucleoids.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Lacks alpha-helical transmembrane segments, suggesting
CC       that it resides in the membrane via beta-sheet conformations
CC       similar to those predicted for other outer membrane proteins and
CC       porin.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 768 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MDM10 family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03102}.

RN   [12]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.9 ANGSTROMS) OF 1-292.
RX   PubMed=10445030; DOI=10.1016/S1097-2765(00)80190-2;
RA   Rice L.M., Brunger A.T.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the vesicular transport protein Sec17:
RT   implications for SNAP function in SNARE complex disassembly.";
RL   Mol. Cell 4:85-95(1999).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: SNARE complex protein that binds to cis-SNARE complexes
CC       on membranes and is required for vesicular transport between the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum and the Golgi apparatus and for homotypic
CC       vacuole fusion. During the priming step of membrane fusion, is
CC       released from cis-SNARE complexes by SEC18 to establish a pool of
CC       unpaired SNAREs, which are required for interactions in trans
CC       during docking and fusion steps. Can displace HOPS from SNARE
CC       complexes, which may be a prerequisite for trans-SNARE complex
CC       disassembly and subsequent rounds of priming, docking and fusion.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15889152, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8620540,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670830, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9144293}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds to vacuolar cis-SNARE complexes composed of the v-
CC       SNAREs NYV1, VTI1 and YKT6, and the t-SNAREs VAM3 and VAM7.
CC       Interacts with SEC18. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15889152}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Peripheral membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SNAP family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.3 ANGSTROMS) OF 22-210.
RX   PubMed=10611286; DOI=10.1073/pnas.96.26.14759;
RA   Babor S.M., Fass D.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the Sec18p N-terminal domain.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 96:14759-14764(1999).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for vesicle-mediated transport. Catalyzes the
CC       fusion of transport vesicles within the Golgi cisternae. Is also
CC       required for transport from the endoplasmic reticulum to the Golgi
CC       stack. Seems to function as a fusion protein required for the
CC       delivery of cargo proteins to all compartments of the Golgi stack
CC       independent of vesicle origin.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homohexamer. Binds to SEC17.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 5920 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the AAA ATPase family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA35031.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for 5.8S rRNA and tRNA processing; associated
CC       with RNase MRP and RNase P. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9085845,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9620854}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of nuclear RNase P and RNase MRP complexes.
CC       RNase P consists of an RNA moiety and at least 9 protein subunits
CC       including POP1, POP3, POP4, POP5, POP6, POP7, POP8, RPP1 and RPR2.
CC       RNase MRP complex consists of an RNA moiety and at least 10
CC       protein subunits including POP1, POP3, POP4, POP5, POP6, POP7,
CC       POP8, RMP1, RPP1 and SNM1, many of which are shared with the RNase
CC       P complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15637077,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9085845, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9620854}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P41812:POP1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-13646, EBI-13621;
CC       P53218:POP6; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-13646, EBI-13662;
CC       P38291:POP7; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-13646, EBI-13670;
CC       P38786:RPP1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-13646, EBI-15968;
CC       P40993:SNM1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-13646, EBI-15622;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic/archaeal RNase P protein
CC       component 1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   SUBUNIT, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=14970230; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M314104200;
RA   Sambade M., Kane P.M.;
RT   "The yeast vacuolar proton-translocating ATPase contains a subunit
RT   homologous to the Manduca sexta and bovine e subunits that is
RT   essential for function.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 279:17361-17365(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Subunit of the integral membrane V0 complex of vacuolar
CC       ATPase. V-ATPase is responsible for acidifying a variety of
CC       intracellular compartments in eukaryotic cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14594803}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: V-ATPase is a heteromultimeric enzyme composed of a
CC       peripheral catalytic V1 complex (components A to H) attached to an
CC       integral membrane V0 proton pore complex (components: a, c, c',
CC       c'', d and e). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14970230}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14970230}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14970230}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the V-ATPase e1/e2 subunit family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Oxidizes long-chain alcohols and, in the presence of
CC       glutathione, is able to oxidize formaldehyde. Is responsible for
CC       yeast resistance to formaldehyde.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-(hydroxymethyl)glutathione + NAD(P)(+) = S-
CC       formylglutathione + NAD(P)H.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A primary alcohol + NAD(+) = an aldehyde +
CC       NADH.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A secondary alcohol + NAD(+) = a ketone +
CC       NADH.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Zn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29105; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 2 Zn(2+) ions per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By formaldehyde, ethanol and methyl methanesulphonate.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Requires GSH for oxidation of formaldehyde or of
CC       methylglyoxal, while oxidation of long-chain alcohols is
CC       independent of GSH and enzyme activity improves with chain length.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 8370 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the zinc-containing alcohol dehydrogenase
CC       family. Class-III subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=21719644; DOI=10.1126/science.1207125;
RA   Stefer S., Reitz S., Wang F., Wild K., Pang Y.Y., Schwarz D.,
RA   Bomke J., Hein C., Lohr F., Bernhard F., Denic V., Dotsch V.,

RN   [19]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.0 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=22684149; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2012.05.045;
RA   Kubota K., Yamagata A., Sato Y., Goto-Ito S., Fukai S.;
RT   "Get1 stabilizes an open dimer conformation of get3 ATPase by binding
RT   two distinct interfaces.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 422:366-375(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: ATPase required for the post-translational delivery of
CC       tail-anchored (TA) proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum.
CC       Recognizes and selectively binds the transmembrane domain of TA
CC       proteins in the cytosol. This complex then targets to the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum by membrane-bound receptors GET1 and GET2,
CC       where the tail-anchored protein is released for insertion. This
CC       process is regulated by ATP binding and hydrolysis. ATP binding
CC       drives the homodimer towards the closed dimer state, facilitating
CC       recognition of newly synthesized TA membrane proteins. ATP
CC       hydrolysis is required for insertion. Subsequently, the homodimer
CC       reverts towards the open dimer state, lowering its affinity for
CC       the GET1-GET2 receptor, and returning it to the cytosol to
CC       initiate a new round of targeting. Cooperates with the HDEL
CC       receptor ERD2 to mediate the ATP-dependent retrieval of resident
CC       ER proteins that contain a C-terminal H-D-E-L retention signal
CC       from the Golgi to the ER. Involved in low-level resistance to the
CC       oxyanions arsenite and arsenate, and in heat tolerance.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03112, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12680698,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18724936,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21866104}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Component of the Golgi to ER traffic (GET)
CC       complex, which is composed of GET1, GET2 and GET3. Interacts with
CC       the chloride channel protein GEF1. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03112, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11805837,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12680698, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16260785,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16816426,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19675567, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19706470,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20015340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21866104}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-2989;
CC       P37020:GEF1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-7552;
CC       P53192:GET1; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-23722;
CC       P40056:GET2; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-22604;
CC       Q12125:GET4; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-36940;
CC       Q12285:MDY2; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-34904;
CC       Q12255:NYV1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-35465;
CC       P32854:PEP12; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-13098;
CC       P22214:SEC22; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-16577;
CC       P60468:SEC61B (xeno); NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-2989, EBI-1788819;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Endoplasmic reticulum. Golgi
CC       apparatus. Note=GET1 and GET2 are required for targeting GET3 to
CC       the endoplasmic reticulum.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 17300 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the arsA ATPase family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03112}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The 26S proteasome is involved in the ATP-dependent
CC       degradation of ubiquitinated proteins. The regulatory (or ATPase)
CC       complex confers ATP dependency and substrate specificity to the
CC       26S complex (By similarity). Has ATPase activity. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38764:RPN1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-13901, EBI-15913;
CC       P43588:RPN11; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-13901, EBI-11219;
CC       P33299:RPT1; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-13901, EBI-13910;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000305}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the AAA ATPase family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=20375281; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1000063107;
RA   Lynch-Day M.A., Bhandari D., Menon S., Huang J., Cai H.,

RT   "Trs85 directs a Ypt1 GEF, TRAPPIII, to the phagophore to promote
RT   autophagy.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 107:7811-7816(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Specific subunit of the TRAPP III complex that acts as
CC       an autophagy-specific guanine nucleotide exchange factor (GEF) for
CC       YPT1. TRS85 directs the TRAPP III complex to the phagophore
CC       assembly site (PAS) that is involved in autophagosome formation.
CC       Required for membrane expansion during autophagy and the CVT
CC       pathway. Required for sporulation. Has a role late in meiosis
CC       following DNA replication. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10727015,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239471, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16079147,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16874038, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8619313}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Part of the multisubunit TRAPP (transport protein
CC       particle) III complex composed of BET3, BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31,
CC       TRS33 and TRS85. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239471,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9564032}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38334:TRS20; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-19492, EBI-19468;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Preautophagosomal structure
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239471, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 8760 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRS85 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=12654246; DOI=10.1016/S0092-8674(03)00161-2;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the SRP (signal recognition particle)
CC       receptor. Ensures, in conjunction with the signal recognition
CC       particle, the correct targeting of the nascent secretory proteins
CC       to the endoplasmic reticulum membrane system. GTP hydrolysis may
CC       enhance the fidelity of and provide unidirectionality to the
CC       targeting reaction. It is important but not essential for cell
CC       growth. May be directly involved in mitochondrial protein import.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1327299}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of an alpha and a beta chain.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12654246}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P36057:SRP102; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-18098, EBI-18091;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1327299}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1327299}; Cytoplasmic side
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1327299}. Note=Thought to be anchored in the
CC       membrane through an interaction with SR-beta, which contains a
CC       bona fide transmembrane domain.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The SRX domain is sufficient for interaction with GTP-
CC       bound SR-beta.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GTP-binding SRP family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates GPI anchoring in the endoplasmic reticulum, by
CC       replacing a protein's C-terminal GPI attachment signal peptide
CC       with a pre-assembled GPI. During this transamidation reaction, the
CC       GPI transamidase forms a carbonyl intermediate with the substrate
CC       protein.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycolipid biosynthesis; glycosylphosphatidylinositol-
CC       anchor biosynthesis.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a complex with CDC91, GPI16, GPI17 and GAA1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11598210}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P39012:GAA1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7822, EBI-7252;
CC       P38875:GPI16; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-7822, EBI-24869;
CC       Q04080:GPI17; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-7822, EBI-7777;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Single-pass
CC       type I membrane protein.
CC   -!- PTM: The disulfide bond between GPI8 and GPI16 is important for
CC       normal enzyme activity. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1560 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase C13 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       Required to maintain a functional Golgi apparatus.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The M-Pol II complex possesses alpha-1,6-
CC       mannosyltransferase activity and is probably involved in the
CC       elongation of the mannan backbone of N-linked glycans on cell wall
CC       and periplasmic proteins.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (4.6 ANGSTROMS) OF 2-35 IN COMPLEX WITH GET3,
RP   FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TOPOLOGY.
RX   PubMed=21719644; DOI=10.1126/science.1207125;
RA   Stefer S., Reitz S., Wang F., Wild K., Pang Y.Y., Schwarz D.,
RA   Bomke J., Hein C., Lohr F., Bernhard F., Denic V., Dotsch V.,
RA   Sinning I.;
RT   "Structural basis for tail-anchored membrane protein biogenesis by the
RT   Get3-receptor complex.";
RL   Science 333:758-762(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for the post-translational delivery of tail-
CC       anchored (TA) proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum. Together with
CC       GET1, acts as a membrane receptor for soluble GET3, which
CC       recognizes and selectively binds the transmembrane domain of TA
CC       proteins in the cytosol. The GET complex cooperates with the HDEL
CC       receptor ERD2 to mediate the ATP-dependent retrieval of resident
CC       ER proteins that contain a C-terminal H-D-E-L retention signal
CC       from the Golgi to the ER. Involved in DNA replication and DNA
CC       damage response and also in cell wall function.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03114, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10929718,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12586695, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12615994,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18724936,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21835666}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Golgi to ER traffic (GET) complex, which
CC       is composed of GET1, GET2 and GET3. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03114, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11805837,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21835666}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53192:GET1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-22604, EBI-23722;
CC       Q12154:GET3; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-22604, EBI-2989;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GET2 family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03114}.

CC       Sequence=AAB64638.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-647, AND IDENTIFICATION

RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the peripheral membrane COG complex
CC       that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking. COG is
CC       located at the cis- Golgi, and regulates tethering of retrograde
CC       intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other membrane
CC       trafficking events. COG3 is also involved in actin cytoskeleton
CC       organization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10562277,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10588657, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006647}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10562277,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006647}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53079:COG1; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-16605, EBI-4835;
CC       P53271:COG2; NbExp=16; IntAct=EBI-16605, EBI-16614;
CC       Q06096:COG4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-16605, EBI-4823;
CC       P53951:COG5; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-16605, EBI-4841;
CC       P53959:COG6; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-16605, EBI-4829;
CC       P53195:COG7; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-16605, EBI-4847;
CC       Q01590:SED5; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-16605, EBI-16930;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10562277, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10588657};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10562277,

RA   Taylor A.B., Smith B.S., Kitada S., Kojima K., Miyaura H.,
RA   Otwinowski Z., Ito A., Deisenhofer J.;
RT   "Crystal structures of mitochondrial processing peptidase reveal the
RT   mode for specific cleavage of import signal sequences.";
RL   Structure 9:615-625(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cytochrome c oxidase is the component of the respiratory
CC       chain that catalyzes the reduction of oxygen to water.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 4 ferrocytochrome c + O(2) + 4 H(+) = 4
CC       ferricytochrome c + 2 H(2)O.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Energy metabolism; oxidative phosphorylation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Cytochrome c oxidase is composed of 11 subunits: one copy
CC       each of COX1, COX2, COX3, COX4, COX5A or COX5B, COX6, COX7, COX9,
CC       COX12, COX13 and two copies of COX8.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11470436}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 9410 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cytochrome c oxidase subunit 5B family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.3 ANGSTROMS) OF 19-103 IN COMPLEX WITH GET2
RP   AND GET3, FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TOPOLOGY.
RX   PubMed=21719644; DOI=10.1126/science.1207125;
RA   Stefer S., Reitz S., Wang F., Wild K., Pang Y.Y., Schwarz D.,
RA   Bomke J., Hein C., Lohr F., Bernhard F., Denic V., Dotsch V.,
RA   Sinning I.;
RT   "Structural basis for tail-anchored membrane protein biogenesis by the
RT   Get3-receptor complex.";
RL   Science 333:758-762(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for the post-translational delivery of tail-
CC       anchored (TA) proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum. Together with
CC       GET2, acts as a membrane receptor for soluble GET3, which
CC       recognizes and selectively binds the transmembrane domain of TA
CC       proteins in the cytosol. The GET complex cooperates with the HDEL
CC       receptor ERD2 to mediate the ATP-dependent retrieval of resident
CC       ER proteins that contain a C-terminal H-D-E-L retention signal
CC       from the Golgi to the ER. Involved in mitochondrial distribution
CC       and morphology. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03113,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11907266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18724936, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21835666}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Golgi to ER traffic (GET) complex, which
CC       is composed of GET1, GET2 and GET3. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03113, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11805837,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21719644,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21835666}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P40056:GET2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-23722, EBI-22604;
CC       Q12154:GET3; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-23722, EBI-2989;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2250 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the WRB/GET1 family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03113}.

RP   COMPOSITION OF THE COG COMPLEX, AND INTERACTION WITH COG4.
RX   PubMed=15047703; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M400662200;
RA   Loh E., Hong W.;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the peripheral membrane COG complex
CC       that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking. COG is
CC       located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of retrograde
CC       intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other membrane
CC       trafficking events.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53271:COG2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4847, EBI-16614;

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.3 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=10873857; DOI=10.1016/S0969-2126(00)00152-0;

RN   [7]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.97 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=11880631; DOI=10.1073/pnas.052704699;
RA   Lange C., Hunte C.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the yeast cytochrome bc1 complex with its bound
RT   substrate cytochrome c.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 99:2800-2805(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ubiquinol-cytochrome c reductase
CC       complex (complex III or cytochrome b-c1 complex), which is part of
CC       the mitochondrial respiratory chain that generates an
CC       electrochemical potential coupled to ATP synthesis. The complex
CC       couples electron transfer from ubiquinol to cytochrome c. QCR9 is
CC       required for formation of a fully functional complex.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Fungal cytochrome b-c1 complex contains 10 subunits; 3
CC       respiratory subunits, 2 core proteins and 5 low-molecular weight
CC       proteins. Cytochrome b-c1 complex is a homodimer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 4550 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the UQCR10/QCR9 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;

RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This magnesium-dependent enzyme catalyzes the hydrolysis
CC       of ATP coupled with the transport of phospholipids (Potential).
CC       Leads to neomycin-resistance when overexpressed. Required for
CC       traffic between late Golgi and early endosomes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15314152, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + H(2)O + phospholipid(Side 1) = ADP +
CC       phosphate + phospholipid(Side 2).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with MON2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15314152}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q03921:DOP1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-3137, EBI-34442;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15314152}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15314152}. Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15314152}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15314152}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cation transport ATPase (P-type) (TC
CC       3.A.3) family. Type IV subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-67, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Negatively regulates sulfur amino acids biosynthesis
CC       genes expression. Controls cell cycle function (being required for
CC       the G1/S transition and M-phase but not the S-phase), sulfur
CC       metabolism, and methionine biosynthesis as part of the E3
CC       ubiquitin ligase complex SCF(Met30). Required for the efficient
CC       binding of CDC45 and MCM proteins to origins of replication.
CC       Involved in the S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet)-mediated inhibition
CC       of the transcription function of MET4. In the context of the E3
CC       ubiquitin ligase complex SCF(Met30), involved in the degradation
CC       of MET4 and the cellular response to cadmium. Required for
CC       efficient expression of G1 cyclins. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10637232,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14660673, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15689486,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15870262, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8524217}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homomultimer. Interacts with MET4. Interacts with CDC53
CC       and SKP1/CBF3D to form the E3 ubiquitin ligase complex SCF(Met30).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10637232, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14660673,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15883825, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8524217,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9499404}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-11507, EBI-11507;
CC       Q12018:CDC53; NbExp=10; IntAct=EBI-11507, EBI-4321;
CC       P32389:MET4; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-11507, EBI-10757;
CC       P52286:SKP1; NbExp=14; IntAct=EBI-11507, EBI-4090;
CC       Q12020:SRL2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11507, EBI-38714;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Nucleus.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Transcriptional activation requires MET4 as well as
CC       MET31 and MET32. Regulated by intracellular AdoMet levels. L-
CC       methionine regulates the abundance of MET30. The amount of MET30
CC       regulates the activity of the E3 ubiquitin ligase complex
CC       SCF(Met30). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10637232,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11027256}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 217 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the WD repeat MET30/SCONB/SCON-2 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.3 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=10873857; DOI=10.1016/S0969-2126(00)00152-0;

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.97 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=11880631; DOI=10.1073/pnas.052704699;
RA   Lange C., Hunte C.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the yeast cytochrome bc1 complex with its bound
RT   substrate cytochrome c.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 99:2800-2805(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ubiquinol-cytochrome c reductase
CC       complex (complex III or cytochrome b-c1 complex), which is part of
CC       the mitochondrial respiratory chain that generates an
CC       electrochemical potential coupled to ATP synthesis. The complex
CC       couples electron transfer from ubiquinol to cytochrome c. QCR8,
CC       together with cytochrome b, binds to ubiquinone.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Fungal cytochrome b-c1 complex contains 10 subunits; 3
CC       respiratory subunits, 2 core proteins and 5 low-molecular weight
CC       proteins. Cytochrome b-c1 complex is a homodimer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6140 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the UQCRQ/QCR8 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.30 ANGSTROMS) OF 27-172 OF LSM1-LSM7 COMPLEX,
RP   SUBUNIT, AND INTERACTION WITH PAT1.
RX   PubMed=24139796; DOI=10.1016/j.celrep.2013.10.004;

RN   [12]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.95 ANGSTROMS) OF LSM1-LSM7 COMPLEX, SUBUNIT,
RP   FUNCTION, RNA-BINDING, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ARG-105.
RX   PubMed=24513854; DOI=10.1038/cr.2014.18;
RA   Zhou L., Zhou Y., Hang J., Wan R., Lu G., Yan C., Shi Y.;
RT   "Crystal structure and biochemical analysis of the heptameric Lsm1-7
RT   complex.";
RL   Cell Res. 24:497-500(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the cytoplasmic LSM1-LSM7 complex which is
CC       involved in mRNA degradation by activating the decapping step. The
CC       LSM1-LSM7 complex binds RNA with a preference for poly-U ends.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10747033, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10761922,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10913177, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24513854}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the heptameric LSM1-LSM7 complex that forms
CC       a seven-membered ring structure with a donut shape. The LSm
CC       subunits are arranged in the order LSM1, LSM2, LSM3, LSM6, LSM5,
CC       LSM7 and LSM4. Except for LSM1, where a C-terminal helix crosses
CC       the ring structure to form additional interactions with LSM3 and
CC       LSM6, each subunit interacts only with its two neighboring
CC       subunits. The LSM1-LSM7 complex interacts with PAT1; within the
CC       complex PAT1 has direct interactions with LSM2 and LSM3.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10747033, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10761922,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10913177, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24139796,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24513854}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P39517:DHH1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-174, EBI-158;
CC       P38203:LSM2; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-174, EBI-180;
CC       P57743:LSM3; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-174, EBI-10227;
CC       P40070:LSM4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-174, EBI-188;
CC       P40089:LSM5; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-174, EBI-10236;
CC       Q06406:LSM6; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-174, EBI-196;
CC       P25644:PAT1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-174, EBI-204;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10761922}.
CC       Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10761922}. Cytoplasm, P-body
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10913177}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3490 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in retrograde transport from early and late
CC       endosomes to late Golgi. Links the Golgi-associated retrograde
CC       protein (GARP) complex to the t-SNARE TLG1, leading to the fusion
CC       between the endosomal vesicles with the late Golgi. May also be
CC       indirectly involved in apical bud growth.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11957109, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12134085,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12446664,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12686613}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Golgi-associated retrograde protein
CC       (GARP) complex, also called VPS fifty three (VFT) complex,
CC       composed of VPS51, VPS52, VPS53 and VPS54. Interacts with the t-
CC       SNARE TLG1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12446664,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12686613}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q03322:TLG1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-26352, EBI-38705;

CC       Q12071:VPS54; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-26352, EBI-36751;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus, trans-Golgi network
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769}; Peripheral membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769}. Endosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May play a role in the transport of polypeptides both
CC       across the mitochondrial membranes and into the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum. A functional difference between SSA1 and SSA2 proteins
CC       is expected. SSA2 can participate in the ATP-dependent disassembly
CC       of clathrin-coated vesicles. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761219}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds human HTN3/histatin-5, a peptide from saliva, and
CC       mediates its fungicidal activity. Interacts with NAP1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761219, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18086883}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53940:APJ1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8603, EBI-2612341;
CC       P18900:COQ1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8603, EBI-4912;
CC       P22696:ESS1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8603, EBI-6679;
CC       P02829:HSP82; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8603, EBI-8659;
CC       P17505:MDH1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8603, EBI-10594;
CC       P25294:SIS1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8603, EBI-17244;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Secreted, cell wall.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 364000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the heat shock protein 70 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Nonessential SNARE involved in targeting and fusion of
CC       ER-derived transport vesicles with the Golgi complex as well as
CC       Golgi-derived retrograde transport vesicles with the ER.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11001058, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12853481,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12893879, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1990290}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of two distinct SNARE complexes consisting of
CC       SED5, BOS1, BET1 and SEC22 or UFE1, USE1, SEC20 and SEC22. YKT6
CC       can probably replace SEC22 as subunit of either complex. Interacts
CC       with SEC24, YIF1 and YIP1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11001058,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12657649, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12853481,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12893879, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12941276}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12154:GET3; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-16577, EBI-2989;
CC       Q01590:SED5; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-16577, EBI-16930;
CC       P32867:SSO1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-16577, EBI-2206525;
CC       P01123:YPT1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-16577, EBI-29496;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type IV
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type IV membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type IV
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 396 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Deletion of SEC22 is viable. Overexpression of
CC       SEC22 suppresses deletion of YPT1.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the synaptobrevin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the peripheral membrane COG complex
CC       that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking. COG is
CC       located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of retrograde
CC       intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other membrane
CC       trafficking events. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53079:COG1; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-6035, EBI-4835;
CC       P53271:COG2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6035, EBI-16614;
CC       P53951:COG5; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-6035, EBI-4841;
CC       P53959:COG6; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-6035, EBI-4829;
CC       P53195:COG7; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6035, EBI-4847;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6440 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the COG8 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RL   J. Biol. Chem. 279:24640-24648(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the peripheral membrane COG complex
CC       that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking. COG is
CC       located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of retrograde
CC       intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other membrane
CC       trafficking events. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006647,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12011112}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006647, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12011112}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53079:COG1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-4829, EBI-4835;
CC       P53271:COG2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4829, EBI-16614;
CC       P40094:COG3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4829, EBI-16605;
CC       P53951:COG5; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4829, EBI-4841;
CC       P53195:COG7; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4829, EBI-4847;
CC       Q04632:COG8; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-4829, EBI-6035;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1720 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the COG6 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;

RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the anaphase promoting complex/cyclosome
CC       (APC/C), a cell cycle-regulated E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase
CC       complex that controls progression through mitosis and the G1 phase
CC       of the cell cycle. The APC/C is thought to confer substrate
CC       specificity and, in the presence of ubiquitin-conjugating E2
CC       enzymes, it catalyzes the formation of protein-ubiquitin
CC       conjugates that are subsequently degraded by the 26S proteasome.
CC       In early mitosis, the APC/C is activated by CDC20 and targets
CC       securin PDS1, the B-type cyclin CLB5, and other anaphase
CC       inhibitory proteins for proteolysis, thereby triggering the
CC       separation of sister chromatids at the metaphase-to-anaphase
CC       transition. In late mitosis and in G1, degradation of CLB5 allows
CC       activation of the APC/C by CDH1, which is needed to destroy CDC20
CC       and the B-type cyclin CLB2 to allow exit from mitosis and creating
CC       the low CDK state necessary for cytokinesis and for reforming
CC       prereplicative complexes in G1 prior to another round of
CC       replication.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The APC/C is composed of at least 13 subunits that stay
CC       tightly associated throughout the cell cycle: APC1, APC2, APC4,
CC       APC5, APC9, APC11, CDC16, CDC23, CDC26, CDC27, DOC1, MND2 and
CC       SWM1. APC5 directly interacts with MND2 and SWM1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12609981, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9469814}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q04601:APC4; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-35371, EBI-32842;
CC       P40577:MND2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-35371, EBI-25433;
CC       Q12379:SWM1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-35371, EBI-33330;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 259 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the APC5 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RA   Han G.-S., O'Hara L., Carman G.M., Siniossoglou S.;
RT   "An unconventional diacylglycerol kinase that regulates phospholipid
RT   synthesis and nuclear membrane growth.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 283:20433-20442(2008).
RN   [11]
RP   SYNTHESIS OF 133-145 AND 188-201, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, COFACTOR, ENZYME
RP   REGULATION, BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES, AND MUTAGENESIS OF
RP   1-MET--GLY-66; 1-MET--THR-70; 1-MET--LYS-77; ARG-76; LYS-77; ASP-177
RP   AND GLY-184.
RX   PubMed=18458076; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M802866200;
RA   Han G.-S., O'Hara L., Siniossoglou S., Carman G.M.;
RT   "Characterization of the yeast DGK1-encoded CTP-dependent
RT   diacylglycerol kinase.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 283:20443-20453(2008).
RN   [12]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-44; SER-45 AND SER-46,
RP   AND IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in pre-tRNA splicing (By similarity). CTP-
CC       dependent diacylglycerol kinase that catalyzes the phosphorylation
CC       of diacylglycerol (DAG) to phosphatidate (PA). Controls
CC       phosphatidate levels at the nuclear envelope. Counteracts the
CC       activity of PAH1/SMP2. Involved in the resistance to nickel
CC       chloride and nalidixic acid. May be involved in vesicle
CC       trafficking between the endoplasmic reticulum and the Golgi
CC       apparatus. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10407277,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11481671, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458075}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: CTP + 1,2-diacyl-sn-glycerol = CDP + 1,2-
CC       diacyl-sn-glycerol 3-phosphate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458075,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458076}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Ca(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29108;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458076};
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458076};
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by N-ethylmaleimide, dCTP, and
CC       sphingoid bases including sphinganine, sphingosine and
CC       phytosphingosine. DAG pyrophosphate, cardiolipin, CDP-DAG, and
CC       lyso-PA inhibited activity by 23-66%. Also inhibited by Ca(2+)
CC       concentrations of more than 1 mM, by addition of EDTA or EGTA at 5
CC       mM, and by 5 mM Mn(2+) and Zn(2+). Stimulated by major membrane
CC       phospholipids including phosphatidylcholine,
CC       phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylinositol,
CC       phosphatidylserine, phosphatidylglycerol, and phosphatidate. Also
CC       stimulated to a maximum by addition of TritonX-100 at a
CC       concentration of 1 mM, followed by an apparent inhibition of
CC       activity at concentrations above 1 mM.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458076}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=0.3 mM for CTP {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458076};
CC         KM=0.4 mM for dCTP {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458076};
CC         Vmax=0.018 nM/min/mg enzyme {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458076};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 7.0-7.5. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458076};
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Maximum activity at 30 degrees Celsius. Labile above 40 degrees
CC         Celsius. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18458076};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein. Nucleus membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 784 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Rescues the lethality of dephosphorylated
CC       PAH1/SMP2. Overexpression causes the appearance of phosphatidate-
CC       enriched membranes around the nucleus, leading to expansion of the
CC       nuclear membrane without proliferation of the cortical endoplasmic
CC       reticulum membrane. Deletion restores normal nuclear structure in
CC       PAH1/SMP2 deleted cells and returns the level of INO1 mRNA to
CC       normal. Deletion does not affect the abnormal levels of
CC       phosphatidylinositol and major neutral lipid triacylglycerol seen
CC       in the PAH1/SMP2 deletion mutant.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DGK1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.65 ANGSTROMS) OF 806-878 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   MLC1.
RX   PubMed=12351846; DOI=10.1107/S0907444902013951;
RA   Terrak M., Otterbein L.R., Wu G., Palecanda L.A., Lu R.C.,
RA   Dominguez R.;
RT   "Crystallization, X-ray characterization and selenomethionine phasing
RT   of Mlc1p bound to IQ motifs from myosin V.";
RL   Acta Crystallogr. D 58:1882-1885(2002).
RN   [33]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.65 ANGSTROMS) OF 806-830 AND 854-878 IN
RP   COMPLEX WITH MLC1.
RX   PubMed=12554638; DOI=10.1093/emboj/cdg058;
RA   Terrak M., Wu G., Stafford W.F., Lu R.C., Dominguez R.;
RT   "Two distinct myosin light chain structures are induced by specific
RT   variations within the bound IQ motifs-functional implications.";
RL   EMBO J. 22:362-371(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Myosin heavy chain that is required for the cell cycle-
CC       regulated transport of various organelles and proteins for their
CC       segregation. Functions by binding with its tail domain to receptor
CC       proteins on organelles and exerting force with its N-terminal
CC       motor domain against actin filaments, thereby transporting its
CC       cargo along polarized actin cables. Essential for the delivery of
CC       secretory vesicles to sites of active growth during bud emergence
CC       and cytokinesis. Required for segregation and inheritance of
CC       peroxisomes, late Golgi compartments, mitochondria and the vacuole
CC       to the daughter cell during cell division. Also required for
CC       correct alignment of the spindle during mitosis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10931864, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11285273,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11381095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11733545,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11781333, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12391144,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12743102, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21248204}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with calmodulin (CMD1) and the
CC       myosin light chain MLC1 through its IQ repeats. Binds to the
CC       membrane receptors SEC4 and VAC17 to transport secretory vesicles
CC       and the vacuole, respectively. Binds to KAR9, which transports
CC       BIM1-coated cytoplasmic microtubules that are attached to the
CC       spindle pole body into the emerging bud, thereby correctly
CC       orienting the mitotic spindle. Interacts with YPT11 and MMR1 to
CC       accelerate mitochondrial distribution to the bud. Interacts with
CC       SHE4 and localizes it to the bud tip. Interacts with RHO3 and
CC       SMY1, putative regulators of MYO2 function. Interacts with SRO7.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10207081, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10679024,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10984058, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12351846,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12391144, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12456647,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12554638, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12642614,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12725728, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15201867,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15964280, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21248204,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8294515, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9700160}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q03824:INP2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11659, EBI-27354;
CC       P32526:KAR9; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-11659, EBI-9516;
CC       P53141:MLC1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11659, EBI-10988;
CC       P51534:SHE4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-11659, EBI-17086;
CC       P25591:VAC17; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-11659, EBI-21800;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Bud neck {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8188749}. Bud
CC       tip {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8188749}. Note=Concentrates to sites of
CC       polarized growth, namely to the bud tip during S and G2 phases of
CC       the cell cycle and to the bud neck during cytokinesis.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The myosin motor domain binds to actin.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The IQ domains provide the interaction surface for the
CC       myosin light chain MLC1.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The coiled-coiled domain is necessary for dimerization.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The tail domain is a globular cargo-binding domain
CC       involved in vectorial vesicle transport.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 4339 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Moves with an average velocity of 3 um/s along
CC       actin cables.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class myosin-kinesin ATPase
CC       superfamily. Myosin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in sporulation. Essential for completion of the
CC       nuclear division. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11101837}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted, cell wall
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10383953}. Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Lipid-
CC       anchor, GPI-anchor {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in late pachytene.
CC   -!- PTM: The GPI-anchor is attached to the protein in the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum and serves to target the protein to the cell surface.
CC       There, the glucosamine-inositol phospholipid moiety is cleaved off
CC       and the GPI-modified mannoprotein is covalently attached via its
CC       lipidless GPI glycan remnant to the 1,6-beta-glucan of the outer
CC       cell wall layer (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.

RP   FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, AND INTERACTION WITH CLATHRIN.

RN   [4]
RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Adaptins are components of the adaptor complexes which
CC       link clathrin to receptors in coated vesicles. Clathrin-associated
CC       protein complexes are believed to interact with the cytoplasmic
CC       tails of membrane proteins, leading to their selection and
CC       concentration. The AP-1 complex interacts directly with clathrin.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10564262}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Adaptor protein complex 1 (AP-1) is a heterotetramer
CC       composed of two large adaptins (gamma-type subunit APL4 and beta-
CC       type subunit APL2), a medium adaptin (mu-type subunit APM1) and a
CC       small adaptin (sigma-type subunit APS1). AP-1 interacts with
CC       clathrin. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10564262}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P36000:APL2; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-33025, EBI-2206;
CC       P35181:APS1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-33025, EBI-2612;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Golgi apparatus
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250};
CC       Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, clathrin-
CC       coated vesicle membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Note=The coatomer
CC       is cytoplasmic or polymerized on the cytoplasmic side of the
CC       Golgi, as well as on the vesicles/buds originating from it.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 4850 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RN   [8]
RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH EPS1 AND PDI1.
RX   PubMed=16002399; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M503377200;
RA   Kimura T., Hosoda Y., Sato Y., Kitamura Y., Ikeda T., Horibe T.,
RA   Kikuchi M.;
RT   "Interactions among yeast protein-disulfide isomerase proteins and
RT   endoplasmic reticulum chaperone proteins influence their activities.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 280:31438-31441(2005).
RN   [9]
RP   INTERACTION WITH YOS9.
RX   PubMed=16873065; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2006.05.045;
RA   Denic V., Quan E.M., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "A luminal surveillance complex that selects misfolded glycoproteins
RT   for ER-associated degradation.";
RL   Cell 126:349-359(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probably plays a role in facilitating the assembly of
CC       multimeric protein complexes inside the ER. Is required for
CC       secretory polypeptide translocation. May physically associate with
CC       SEC63 protein in the endoplasmic reticulum and this interaction
CC       may be regulated by ATP hydrolysis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16002399}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: The chaperone activity is regulated by ATP-
CC       induced allosteric coupling of the nucleotide-binding (NBD) and
CC       substrate-binding (SBD) domains. In the ADP-bound and nucleotide-
CC       free (apo) states, the two domains have little interaction. In
CC       contrast, in the ATP-bound state the two domains are tightly
CC       coupled, which results in drastically accelerated kinetics in both
CC       binding and release of polypeptide substrates. J domain-containing
CC       co-chaperones stimulate the ATPase activity and are required for
CC       efficient substrate recognition by HSPA5/BiP.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11021}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with EPS1, PDI1 and YOS9.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16002399, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16873065}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P21954:IDP1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-7876, EBI-8898;
CC       Q99220:YOS9; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-7876, EBI-34938;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum lumen
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU10138,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2661018}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 337000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the heat shock protein 70 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the Ssh1 complex, which probably is the major
CC       component of a channel-forming translocon complex that may
CC       function exclusively in the cotranslational pathway of protein
CC       endoplasmic reticulum (ER) import. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11702951}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the heterotrimeric Ssh1 complex, which is
CC       composed of SSH1, SBH2 and SSS1.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53337:ERV29; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-18175, EBI-23662;
CC       P38264:PHO88; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-18175, EBI-13350;
CC       P35179:SSS1; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-18175, EBI-16406;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 704 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SecY/SEC61-alpha family. {ECO:0000305}.

RL   Proteomics 12:236-240(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: May play a role in the transport of polypeptides both
CC       across the mitochondrial membranes and into the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum. A functional difference between SSA1 and SSA2 proteins
CC       is expected. SSA1 can participate in the ATP-dependent disassembly
CC       of clathrin-coated vesicles. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761219}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds human HTN3/histatin-5, a peptide from saliva, and
CC       mediates its fungicidal activity. Interacts with polyadenylate-
CC       binding protein PAB1 and Hsp70 chaperone SSA1 on translating
CC       ribosomes. Interacts with NAP1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11279042,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12761219, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18086883}.

RN   [58]
RP   UBIQUITINATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-442, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22106047; DOI=10.1002/pmic.201100166;

RT   "Sites of ubiquitin attachment in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   Proteomics 12:236-240(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required, in concert with Hsp40 (YDJ1) and Hsp70 (SSA1)
CC       and small Hsps (HSP26), for the dissociation, resolubilization and
CC       refolding of aggregates of damaged proteins after heat or other
CC       environmental stresses. Extracts proteins from aggregates by
CC       unfolding and threading them in an ATP-dependent process through
CC       the axial channel of the protein hexamer, after which they can be
CC       refolded by components of the Hsp70/Hsp40 chaperone system.
CC       Substrate binding is ATP-dependent, and release of bound
CC       polypeptide is triggered by ATP hydrolysis. Also responsible for
CC       the maintenance of prions by dissociating prion fibrils into
CC       smaller oligomers, thereby producing transmissible seeds that can
CC       infect daughter cells during mitosis and meiosis. Loss of HSP104
CC       can cure yeast cells of the prions [PSI+], [URE3] and [PIN+].
CC       Excess HSP104 can also specifically cure cells of [PSI+].
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10678178, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11073991,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11375656, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11442834,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12101251, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14507919,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15128736, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15155912,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15843375, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15845535,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1600951, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16570324,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16885031, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17253904,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17259993, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17367387,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17543332, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18312264,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2188365, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7754373,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7984243, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8407824,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8643570, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9534180,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9674429}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by micromolar concentrations of
CC       guanidinium chloride. Inhibits the ATPase activity, but does not
CC       dissociate the hexameric protein. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14668331}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=170 uM for ATP (at NBD1) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11158570,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:11782421, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15128736,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:9534180, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9624144};
CC         KM=4.7 uM for ATP (at NBD2) {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11158570,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:11782421, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15128736,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:9534180, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9624144};
CC         Vmax=1.25 nmol/min/ug enzyme for ATP
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11158570, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11782421,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:15128736, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9534180,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:9624144};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homohexamer, forming a ring with a central pore. The
CC       hexamer is stabilized by high protein concentrations and by ADP or
CC       ATP. Oligomerization influences ATP hydrolysis activity at NBD2.
CC       Interacts with YDJ1. Interacts (via C-terminal DDLD tetrapeptide)
CC       with CNS1, CPR7 and STI1 (via TPR repeats); under respiratory
CC       growth conditions. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11158570,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11604493, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16135516,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18160044, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18197703,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8308017, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9534180,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9674429}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-8050, EBI-8050;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Nucleus. Note=Shuttles between
CC       the cytoplasm and the nucleus in an importin KAP95- and KAP121-
CC       dependent and an exportin XPO1-dependent manner. Accumulation in
CC       the nucleus is enhanced by severe heat shock. In the cytoplasm,
CC       concentrates on a perivacuolar compartment, the 'insoluble protein
CC       deposit' (IPOD), in which terminally aggregated proteins are
CC       sequestered. It is also found, to a lesser extent, at a
CC       'juxtanuclear quality control' (JUNQ) compartment, where soluble
CC       ubiquitinated misfolded proteins accumulate.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By heat stress dependent on the heat shock
CC       transcription factor HSF1 and the general stress transcription
CC       factors MSN2 and MSN4. Expressed at a higher level in respiring
CC       cells than in fermenting cells. Expressed in stationary phase
CC       cells and spores (at protein level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11967066,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15049822, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1600951,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8308017, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8643570}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Has 2 AAA ATPase type nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs)
CC       per monomer, a low-affinity, high-turnover site (NBD1) and a high-
CC       affinity site (NBD2) with a 300-fold slower rate of hydrolysis.
CC       There is allosteric regulation between the 2 sites. ATP binding to
CC       NBD1 triggers binding of polypeptides and stimulates ATP
CC       hydrolysis at NBD2. Nucleotide binding to NBD2 is crucial for
CC       oligomerization.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal extension is involved in oligomerization.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 32800 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ClpA/ClpB family. {ECO:0000305}.
