CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for nuclear migration during mitosis. It is
CC       required for the normal initiation of translation. Might mediate
CC       the dissociation of a specific protein complex of the translation
CC       machinery. Essential for viability.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with polyadenylate-binding protein PAB1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11279042}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P25367:RNQ1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-17244, EBI-21708;
CC       P10591:SSA1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-17244, EBI-8591;
CC       P10592:SSA2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-17244, EBI-8603;
CC       P32589:SSE1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-17244, EBI-8648;
CC       Q7LKB1:SUP35 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-17244, EBI-8411471;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}. Note=Localized throughout
CC       the cell but is more concentrated at the nucleus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 20300 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Has a role in mitochondrial fission. Has a role in outer
CC       membrane fission but not matrix separation. Required for targeting
CC       MDV1 to the mitochondria. Regulates the assembly of DNM1 into
CC       punctate structures, in the mitochondrial tubules, promoting
CC       mitochondrial membrane constriction and/or division.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11038182, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11038183,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12163467, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12679388,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23530241}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with DNM1 and MDV1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12163467, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14517324}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P36130:CAF4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-25059, EBI-26394;
CC       P47025:MDV1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-25059, EBI-26032;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion outer membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11038183, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12514182,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278}; Single-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11038183, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12514182,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminus is required for mitochondrial localization,
CC       while the N-terminus is necessary for mitochondrial fission.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2410 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the FIS1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Stabilizes the proteasome holoenzyme, probably by
CC       tethering the 20S proteolytic core particle and the 19S regulatory
CC       particle. The proteasome is a multicatalytic proteinase complex
CC       which is characterized by its ability to cleave peptides with Arg,
CC       Phe, Tyr, Leu, and Glu adjacent to the leaving group at neutral or
CC       slightly basic pH. The proteasome has an ATP-dependent proteolytic
CC       activity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12408819}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the proteasome. ECM29 binds to both
CC       proteasome 19S and 20S particles. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12408819}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2950 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ECM29 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic component of the inositol phosphorylceramide
CC       synthase which catalyzes the addition of a phosphorylinositol
CC       group onto ceramide to form inositol phosphorylceramide, an
CC       essential step in sphingolipid biosynthesis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19726565,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9092515}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by aureobasidin A (AbA), khafrefungin
CC       and rustmicin. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=555 uM for phosphatidylinositol
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657};
CC         KM=3.0 uM for C(6)-NBD-ceramide {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657};
CC         Vmax=824 pmol/min/mg enzyme for phosphatidylinositol
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19047657};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Essential for protein sorting in meiotic cell division
CC       of Saccharomyces cerevisiae; it binds microtubules. Could also be
CC       involved in microtubule-associated motility. Necessary for
CC       membrane protein retention in a late Golgi compartment. Interacts
CC       with the MVP1 protein. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8344247}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8344247}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 5960 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class dynamin-like GTPase
CC       superfamily. Dynamin/Fzo/YdjA family. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU01055}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND IDENTIFICATION IN MDM12/MMM1 AND MDM10/MDM12/MMM1
RP   COMPLEXES.
RX   PubMed=17410204; DOI=10.1038/sj.emboj.7601673;
RA   Meisinger C., Pfannschmidt S., Rissler M., Milenkovic D., Becker T.,
RA   Stojanovski D., Youngman M.J., Jensen R.E., Chacinska A., Guiard B.,

RN   [16]
RP   FUNCTION, IDENTIFICATION IN ERMES/MDM COMPLEX, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION,
RP   TOPOLOGY, AND GLYCOSYLATION.
RX   PubMed=19556461; DOI=10.1126/science.1175088;
RA   Kornmann B., Currie E., Collins S.R., Schuldiner M., Nunnari J.,
RA   Weissman J.S., Walter P.;
RT   "An ER-mitochondria tethering complex revealed by a synthetic biology
RT   screen.";
RL   Science 325:477-481(2009).
RN   [17]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=27469264; DOI=10.1038/srep30777;
RA   Kojima R., Endo T., Tamura Y.;
RT   "A phospholipid transfer function of ER-mitochondria encounter
RT   structure revealed in vitro.";
RL   Sci. Rep. 6:30777-30777(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ERMES/MDM complex, which serves as a
CC       molecular tether to connect the endoplasmic reticulum and
CC       mitochondria (PubMed:19556461). Components of this complex are
CC       involved in the control of mitochondrial shape and protein
CC       biogenesis, and function in nonvesicular lipid trafficking between
CC       the ER and mitochondria (PubMed:8089172, PubMed:9628893,
CC       PubMed:27469264). The MDM12-MMM1 subcomplex functions in the major
CC       beta-barrel assembly pathway that is responsible for biogenesis of
CC       all outer membrane beta-barrel proteins, and acts in a late step
CC       after the SAM complex. The MDM10-MDM12-MMM1 subcomplex further
CC       acts in the TOM40-specific pathway after the action of the MDM12-
CC       MMM1 complex (PubMed:17410204). Essential for establishing and
CC       maintaining the structure of mitochondria and maintenance of mtDNA
CC       nucleoids (PubMed:11266455, PubMed:12454062, PubMed:14981098).
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03103, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11266455,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12454062, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981098,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17410204, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27469264, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8089172,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9628893}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer (By similarity). Component of the ER-
CC       mitochondria encounter structure (ERMES) or MDM complex, composed
CC       of MMM1, MDM10, MDM12 and MDM34 (PubMed:13679517, PubMed:17410204,
CC       PubMed:19556461). A MMM1 homodimer associates with one molecule of
CC       MDM12 on each side in a pairwise head-to-tail manner, and the SMP-
CC       LTD domains of MMM1 and MDM12 generate a continuous hydrophobic
CC       tunnel for phospholipid trafficking (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:C5DRQ1, ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03103,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:13679517, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17410204,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q92328:MDM12; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-11029, EBI-10584;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03103, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11266455,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12972421, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981098,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407407, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8089172}; Single-pass type I membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03103, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11266455,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12972421, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981098,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407407, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8089172}. Note=The ERMES/MDM complex localizes
CC       to a few discrete foci (around 10 per single cell), that represent
CC       mitochondria-endoplasmic reticulum junctions. These foci are often
CC       found next to mtDNA nucleoids. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03103}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The SMP-LTD domain is a barrel-like domain that can bind
CC       various types of glycerophospholipids in its interior and mediate
CC       their transfer between two adjacent bilayers. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03103}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Normal levels of MMM1 require MDM34.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2490 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MMM1 family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03103}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Was originally (PubMed:12972421 and PubMed:8089172)
CC       proposed to be inserted into either the outer or inner
CC       mitochondrial membrane, yet more recent data indicates that it is
CC       instead inserted into the ER. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:19556461}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.40 ANGSTROMS) OF 1-170 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   PHOSPHATIDIC ACID AND MDM35, INTERACTION WITH MDM35, FUNCTION,
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF ARG-25; LYS-61 AND LYS-155, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=26235513; DOI=10.1038/ncomms8922;
RA   Watanabe Y., Tamura Y., Kawano S., Endo T.;
RT   "Structural and mechanistic insights into phospholipid transfer by
RT   Ups1-Mdm35 in mitochondria.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 6:7922-7922(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for maintenance of normal mitochondrial
CC       morphology (PubMed:16754953, PubMed:26071601). Required for PCP1-
CC       dependent processing of MGM1 (PubMed:16754953). The UPS1:MDM35
CC       complex mediates the transfer of phosphatidic acid (PA) between
CC       liposomes and probably functions as a PA transporter across the
CC       mitochondrion intermembrane space (PubMed:26071602,
CC       PubMed:26071601, PubMed:26235513). Phosphatidic acid release
CC       requires dissociation of the UPS1:MDM35 complex (PubMed:26235513).
CC       Phosphatidic acid import is required for cardiolipin (CL)
CC       synthesis in the mitochondrial inner membrane (PubMed:26071602).
CC       With UPS2, controls the level of cardiolipin in mitochondria
CC       (PubMed:19506038). Cardiolipin is a unique phospholipid with four
CC       fatty acid chains and is present mainly in the mitochondrial inner
CC       membrane where it stabilizes the electron transport chain
CC       supercomplex between complexes III and IV through direct
CC       interaction of their subunits. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16754953,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19221197, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19506038,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20622808, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26071602,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26235513}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with MDM35 (PubMed:20622808, PubMed:20657548,
CC       PubMed:26071602, PubMed:26071601, PubMed:26235513). Found
CC       associated with a 170 kDa complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16754953,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20622808, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20657548,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26071601, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26071602,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26235513}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       O60200:MDM35; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-30337, EBI-2080774;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26235513}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26235513}; Intermembrane side {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Mitochondrion intermembrane space {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26235513}.
CC       Note=Lacks the two major intermembrane space-targeting signals,
CC       bipartite presequences and cysteine motifs, and import is mediated
CC       by another IMS protein, MDM35. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Cells show slow growth, fragmented
CC       mitochondria and have a 50-fold reduced level of s-MGM1. These
CC       defects can be complemented by human PRELI or bypassed by growth
CC       on a nonfermentable carbon source. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16754953}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 704 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the slowmo family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   STRAIN=ATCC 76625 / YPH499;
RX   PubMed=14576278; DOI=10.1073/pnas.2135385100;
RA   Sickmann A., Reinders J., Wagner Y., Joppich C., Zahedi R.P.,
RA   Meyer H.E., Schoenfisch B., Perschil I., Chacinska A., Guiard B.,
RA   Rehling P., Pfanner N., Meisinger C.;
RT   "The proteome of Saccharomyces cerevisiae mitochondria.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 100:13207-13212(2003).
RN   [13]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND INTERACTION WITH COX1 AND COX14.
RX   PubMed=15306853; DOI=10.1038/sj.emboj.7600358;
RA   Barrientos A., Zambrano A., Tzagoloff A.;
RT   "Mss51p and Cox14p jointly regulate mitochondrial Cox1p expression in
RT   Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   EMBO J. 23:3472-3482(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Has a dual role in the assembly of cytochrome oxidase
CC       subunit 1 (COX1). It has a regulative function on COX1 synthesis,
CC       acting as a translational activator specific for the COX1 mRNA,
CC       and it also binds to newly synthesized COX1 protein. Together with
CC       COX14, may act as a chaperone that binds efficiently unassembled
CC       COX1 and prevents it from unproductive aggregation. When bound to
CC       COX1, MSS51 is unable to interact with the COX1 mRNA and
CC       translation is halted. This may be a feedback control that ensures
CC       that COX1 is only produced as long as potentially harmful assembly
CC       intermediates are not accumulating. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10803883,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14592991, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15306853,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:6320175}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with COX1 and COX14.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14592991, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15306853}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P40452:COA1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11318, EBI-25287;
CC       Q3E7B2:COA3; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-11318, EBI-3680840;
CC       P39103:COX14; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11318, EBI-5113;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10803883, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15306853};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10803883,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15306853}; Matrix side
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10803883, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15306853}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 4800 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MSS51 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Although no clear MSS51 ortholog is encoded in mammalian
CC       genomes, the mammalian MSS51/ZMYND17 protein of unknown function
CC       is significantly similar. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediator of sterol homeostasis involved in sterol
CC       uptake, trafficking and distribution into membranes. Regulates
CC       also the sphingolipid metabolism. Required for growth during
CC       anaerobiosis and sterol uptake. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11063737,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12145310}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12145310}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12145310}. Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12145310}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12145310}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Throughout most of the cell cycle it forms a double ring
CC       that coincides with the septins. After the onset of mitosis, forms
CC       a ring-like structure which colocalizes with the medial actin
CC       ring. Mediates cytoskeletal rearrangements required for
CC       cytokinesis. In conjunction with the medial actin ring exhibits
CC       contraction-like action. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18344988,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19528296}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with INN1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18344988,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19528296}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as a component of the m-AAA protease complex which
CC       is a ATP-dependent metalloprotease mediating degradation of non-
CC       assembled mitochondrial inner membrane proteins. The complex is
CC       necessary for the assembly of mitochondrial respiratory chain and
CC       ATPase complexes. Function both in post-translational assembly and
CC       in the turnover of mistranslated or misfolded polypeptides.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8681382, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9707443}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Zn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29105; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Note=Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit. {ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the 850 kDa m-AAA protease complex (YTA10-
CC       12) which consists of multiple copies of RCA1 AND AFG3.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8681382}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P39925:AFG3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-14858, EBI-2317;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8681382}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8681382}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 11500 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the AAA ATPase
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the C-terminal section; belongs to the peptidase
CC       M41 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Allows the formation of correctly charged Gln-tRNA(Gln)
CC       through the transamidation of misacylated Glu-tRNA(Gln) in the
CC       mitochondria. The reaction takes place in the presence of
CC       glutamine and ATP through an activated gamma-phospho-Glu-
CC       tRNA(Gln). Required for HMG2-induced ER-remodeling.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03150, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18667535,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19417106}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + L-glutamyl-tRNA(Gln) + L-glutamine = ADP
CC       + phosphate + L-glutaminyl-tRNA(Gln) + L-glutamate.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03150}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Subunit of the heterotrimeric GatFAB amidotransferase
CC       (AdT) complex, composed of A (HER2), B (PET112) and F (YGR102C)
CC       subunits.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03150, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11914276,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19417106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 486 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the amidase family. GatA subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03150}.

RX   PubMed=23124206; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M112.390997;
RA   Tamura Y., Onguka O., Itoh K., Endo T., Iijima M., Claypool S.M.,
RA   Sesaki H.;

RN   [18]
RP   FUNCTION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF LEU-461; SER-463 AND THR-464.
RX   PubMed=25829489; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M115.641118;
RA   Onguka O., Calzada E., Ogunbona O.B., Claypool S.M.;
RT   "Phosphatidylserine decarboxylase 1 autocatalysis and function does
RT   not require a mitochondrial-specific factor.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 290:12744-12752(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the formation of phosphatidylethanolamine
CC       (PtdEtn) from phosphatidylserine (PtdSer). Plays a central role in
CC       phospholipid metabolism and in the interorganelle trafficking of
CC       phosphatidylserine (PubMed:8227017, PubMed:8407984,
CC       PubMed:17976194, PubMed:23124206, PubMed:25829489).
CC       Phosphatidylethanolamine formed in the mitochondria is exported to
CC       other membranes to fullfill their requirements for PtdEtn
CC       (PubMed:8530379, PubMed:11294902). Required for normal
CC       mitochondrial morphology and proper mitochondrial fusion during
CC       yeast mating (PubMed:23045528). {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11294902, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17976194,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23045528, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25829489, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8227017,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8407984, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8530379}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Phosphatidyl-L-serine =
CC       phosphatidylethanolamine + CO(2). {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:6427211, ECO:0000305|PubMed:17976194}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=pyruvate; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:15361;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208};
CC       Note=Binds 1 pyruvoyl group covalently per subunit.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Phospholipid metabolism; phosphatidylethanolamine
CC       biosynthesis; phosphatidylethanolamine from CDP-diacylglycerol:
CC       step 2/2. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:8407984}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of a large membrane-associated beta subunit
CC       and a small pyruvoyl-containing alpha subunit. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Phosphatidylserine decarboxylase 1 beta
CC       chain: Mitochondrion inner membrane {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:3005242}; Single-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000305|PubMed:22984266};
CC       Intermembrane side {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Phosphatidylserine decarboxylase 1 alpha
CC       chain: Mitochondrion inner membrane {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:3005242}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266};
CC       Intermembrane side {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23124206}.
CC       Note=Anchored to the mitochondrial inner membrane through its
CC       interaction with the integral membrane beta chain.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266}.
CC   -!- PTM: The precursor is imported via the TOM complex into
CC       mitochondria, where the N-terminal presequence is cleaved by the
CC       matrix-located proteases MPP (MAS1-MAS2) and OCT1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22984266, ECO:0000305|PubMed:17976194}.
CC   -!- PTM: Is synthesized initially as an inactive proenzyme. Formation
CC       of the active enzyme involves a self-maturation process in which
CC       the active site pyruvoyl group is generated from an internal
CC       serine residue via an autocatalytic post-translational
CC       modification. Two non-identical subunits are generated from the
CC       proenzyme in this reaction, and the pyruvate is formed at the N-
CC       terminus of the alpha chain, which is derived from the carboxyl
CC       end of the proenzyme (PubMed:25829489). The autoendoproteolytic
CC       cleavage occurs by a canonical serine protease mechanism, in which
CC       the side chain hydroxyl group of the serine supplies its oxygen
CC       atom to form the C-terminus of the beta chain, while the remainder
CC       of the serine residue undergoes an oxidative deamination to
CC       produce ammonia and the pyruvoyl prosthetic group on the alpha
CC       chain. During this reaction, the Ser that is part of the protease
CC       active site of the proenzyme becomes the pyruvoyl prosthetic
CC       group, which constitutes an essential element of the active site
CC       of the mature decarboxylase (By similarity). {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03208, ECO:0000305|PubMed:18644857}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1080 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the phosphatidylserine decarboxylase
CC       family. PSD-B subfamily. Eukaryotic type I sub-subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03208}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for a novel path of interorganelle
CC       communication between mitochondria, peroxisomes and the nucleus,
CC       thereby maintaining a functional metabolic interaction between the
CC       tricarboxylic acid and glyoxylate cycles. Transcription factor
CC       that regulates CIT2 gene expression. Binds to two identical sites
CC       oriented as inverted repeats 28 bp apart in a regulatory upstream
CC       activation sequence element (UASR) in the CIT2 promoter. The core
CC       binding site is 5'-GGTCAC-3'.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds DNA as a heterodimer with RTG3.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38165:RTG3; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-16312, EBI-16328;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2190 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=18843051; DOI=10.1091/mbc.E08-01-0103;
RA   Dunn C.D., Tamura Y., Sesaki H., Jensen R.E.;
RT   "Mgr3p and Mgr1p are adaptors for the mitochondrial i-AAA protease
RT   complex.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 19:5387-5397(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic subunit of the mitochondrial inner membrane i-
CC       AAA protease supercomplex required for mitochondrial inner
CC       membrane protein turnover. The protease is probably ATP-dependent.
CC       Important to maintain the integrity of the mitochondrial
CC       compartment. Required both for the degradation of unassembled
CC       subunit 2 of cytochrome c oxidase (COX2) and for efficient
CC       assembly of mitochondrial respiratory chain. Binds unfolded
CC       substrates in an ATPase-independent manner; binding of folded
CC       COX2, a physiological substrate, requires an active ATPase but
CC       when COX2 is destabilized an active ATPase is no longer necessary.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16267274, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16527490}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Zn(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:29105; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the mitochondrial inner membrane i-AAA
CC       protease supercomplex composed of MGR1, MGR3 and YME1. Interacts
CC       directly with MGR1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16267274,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18843051}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P25573:MGR1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-27785, EBI-21740;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8355690,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8688560}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8355690,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8688560}; Matrix side
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8355690,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8688560}. Note=Although this protein does not
CC       have any predicted transmembrane helices it behaves like an
CC       integral membrane protein.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: An increased rate of escape of mtDNA to the
CC       nucleus, no growth on nonfermentable carbon sources at 37 degrees
CC       Celsius, a cold-sensitive defect in growth on fermentable carbon
CC       sources, lethality in rho- (cytoplasmic petite) cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8355690}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 20100 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the AAA ATPase
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the C-terminal section; belongs to the peptidase
CC       M41 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probably involved in mitochondrial protein import. Is
CC       also required for efficient translocation of pre-pro-alpha-factor.
CC       Involved in heme regulation of HAP1, as a component of the high-
CC       molecular-weight (HMC) complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689685}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Interacts with HAP1. Component of the HMC
CC       including HAP1, SRO9 and YDJ1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689685,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14656432}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12285:MDY2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-10420, EBI-34904;
CC       Q12118:SGT2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-10420, EBI-31784;
CC       Q7LKB1:SUP35 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-10420, EBI-8411471;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Cytoplasm, perinuclear region.
CC       Note=Concentrated in a perinuclear ring as well as in the
CC       cytoplasm.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: YDJ1 is a heat shock gene whose expression increases
CC       moderately at elevated temperatures.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 119000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RX   PubMed=15944695; DOI=10.1038/nature03680;
RA   Nelson R., Sawaya M.R., Balbirnie M., Madsen A.O., Riekel C.,
RA   Grothe R., Eisenberg D.;

RN   [25]
RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 1-253.
RX   PubMed=17170131; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0609638103;
RA   Shewmaker F., Wickner R.B., Tycko R.;
RT   "Amyloid of the prion domain of Sup35p has an in-register parallel
RT   beta-sheet structure.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 103:19754-19759(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in translation termination. Stimulates the
CC       activity of ERF1. Binds guanine nucleotides. Recruited by
CC       polyadenylate-binding protein PAB1 to poly(A)-tails of mRNAs.
CC       Interaction with PAB1 is also required for regulation of normal
CC       mRNA decay through translation termination-coupled poly(A)
CC       shortening. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12923185,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15337765, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7556078}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of two subunits, one of which binds GTP.
CC       Interacts with polyadenylate-binding protein PAB1, and TPA1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11971964, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12923185,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15337765, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15525991,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16809762}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=10; IntAct=EBI-6540, EBI-6540;
CC       P32644:ECM32; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-6540, EBI-22223;
CC       Q12315:GLE1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-6540, EBI-7635;
CC       Q04638:ITT1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-6540, EBI-27858;
CC       P12385:SUP45; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6540, EBI-6533;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The prion domain (PrD) is a Gln/Asn (Q/N)-rich domain,
CC       which is unstructured in its native, soluble form, and which forms
CC       a parallel in-register beta-sheet in its amyloid form.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: [PSI+] is the prion form of SUP35 (PubMed:8978027).
CC       [PSI+] is the result of a conformational change of the cellular
CC       SUP35 protein that becomes self-propagating and infectious. This
CC       conformational change generates a form of SUP35 that assembles
CC       into amyloid fibrils. [PSI+]-aggregates sequester soluble SUP35,
CC       resulting in defects in faithful translation termination by read-
CC       through of translation termination codons (PubMed:8670813). [PSI+]
CC       can be cured by GdnHCl and by deletion of the molecular chaperone
CC       HSP104, which is required for [PSI+] propagation (PubMed:9335589).
CC       It is speculated that the prion form would be at least mildly
CC       deleterious in most environments, but it might sometimes increases
CC       evolvability in certain harsh environments (PubMed:19917766).
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:19917766, ECO:0000305|PubMed:8670813,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:8978027, ECO:0000305|PubMed:9335589}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 78900 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class translation factor GTPase
CC       superfamily. Classic translation factor GTPase family. ERF3
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU01059}.

RA   Van Damme P., Lasa M., Polevoda B., Gazquez C., Elosegui-Artola A.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions in the transition of mRNAs from translation to
CC       an mRNP complex destined for decapping. High-copy-number
CC       suppressor of decapping defects. Overexpression suppresses
CC       decapping defects in both DCP1-2 and DCP2-7 mutations. Acts to
CC       promote translational repression of mRNA in conjunction with DHH1
CC       and subsequent mRNA localization to P bodies. Promotes
CC       translational repression of mRNA during glucose deprivation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16782896}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associated with snR10 and snR11 small nuclear RNAs.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16782896}.
CC       Nucleus, nucleolus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16782896,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2121740}. Note=Found in cytoplasmic P bodies.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16782896}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 12800 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RRM GAR family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:

RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: RNA-binding protein involved in post-transcriptional
CC       regulation. Negatively regulates expression of COX17 by binding to
CC       the 3'-UTR of COX17 mRNA. Promotes decay of COX17 mRNA by
CC       enhancing its rate of deadenylation and subsequent turnover.
CC       Predominantly binds to mRNAs encoding mitochondrial proteins and
CC       localizes them to the vicinity of mitochondria for translation.
CC       Regulates mitochondrial biogenesis, motility and morphology.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11101532, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15337848,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16244132, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16355254,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17210948, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18094119,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18523582}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion outer membrane; Peripheral
CC       membrane protein; Cytoplasmic side. Cytoplasm. Note=Localizes to
CC       multiple discrete foci in the cytoplasm.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 846 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PUF3 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the import of activated long-chain fatty
CC       acids from the cytosol to the peroxisomal matrix.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8670886}.

RX   PubMed=23332755; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2012.12.001;
RA   Willmund F., del Alamo M., Pechmann S., Chen T., Albanese V.,

RN   [21]
RP   SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=27917864; DOI=10.1038/ncomms13695;
RA   Hanebuth M.A., Kityk R., Fries S.J., Jain A., Kriel A., Albanese V.,
RA   Frickey T., Peter C., Mayer M.P., Frydman J., Deuerling E.;
RT   "Multivalent contacts of the Hsp70 Ssb contribute to its architecture
RT   on ribosomes and nascent chain interaction.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 7:13695-13695(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ribosome-bound, Hsp70-type chaperone that assists in the
CC       cotranslational folding of newly synthesized proteins in the
CC       cytosol. Stimulates folding by interacting with nascent chains,
CC       binding to short, largely hydrophobic sequences exposed by
CC       unfolded proteins, thereby stabilizing longer, more slowly
CC       translated, and aggregation-prone nascent polypeptides and domains
CC       that cannot fold stably until fully synthesized. The Hsp70-protein
CC       substrate interaction depends on ATP-binding and on allosteric
CC       regulation between the NBD and the SBD. The ATP-bound state is
CC       characterized by a fast exchange rate of substrate (low affinity
CC       state), while in the ADP-bound state exchange is much slower (high
CC       affinity state). During the Hsp70 cycle, the chaperone switches
CC       between the ATP-bound state (open conformation) and the ADP-bound
CC       state (closed conformation) by major conformational rearrangements
CC       involving mainly the lid domain. Ssb cooperates with a specific
CC       Hsp40/Hsp70 co-chaperone termed the ribosome-associated complex
CC       (RAC), which stimulates the ATPase activity of the ribosome-
CC       associated pool of Ssbs and switches it to the high affinity
CC       substrate binding state. Hsp110 chaperone SSE1 and FES1 act as
CC       nucleotide exchange factors that cause substrate release.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11739779, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11929994,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1394434, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16219770,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16221677, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332755,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9670014}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + H(2)O = ADP + phosphate.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11484}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds to ribosomes (PubMed:9670014, PubMed:1394434,
CC       PubMed:27917864). Binds close to the ribosomal tunnel exit via
CC       contacts with both ribosomal proteins RPL35, RPL39 and RPL19, and
CC       rRNA (By similarity). Directly interacts with nascent
CC       polypeptides. This interaction is dependent on the ribosome-
CC       associated complex (RAC) (PubMed:11929994, PubMed:23332755).
CC       Interacts with SSE1 (PubMed:23332755).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11484, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11929994,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1394434, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332755,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27917864, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9670014}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332755,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:1394434}. Note=About 50% of the protein is
CC       associated with translating ribosomes, but sufficient Ssb exists
CC       in the cell for each ribosome to be associated with at least one
CC       Ssb molecule. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1394434,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23332755, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9670014}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression decreases after heat shock or during growth
CC       to stationary phase (PubMed:6761581, PubMed:2651414). Up-regulated
CC       upon carbon upshift and down-regulated upon amino acid limitation
CC       in an HSF1-dependent manner (PubMed:10322015). Interacts with SSE1
CC       (PubMed:16219770, PubMed:16221677). Interacts with FES1 (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11484,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10322015, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16219770,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16221677, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2651414,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:6761581}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 104000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the heat shock protein 70 family. Ssb-type
CC       Hsp70 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.90 ANGSTROMS) OF 153-228 PHOSPHORYLATED AT

RX   PubMed=25527291; DOI=10.15252/embj.201489847;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ubiquitin: Exists either covalently attached to another
CC       protein, or free (unanchored). When covalently bound, it is
CC       conjugated to target proteins via an isopeptide bond either as a
CC       monomer (monoubiquitin), a polymer linked via different Lys
CC       residues of the ubiquitin (polyubiquitin chains) or a linear
CC       polymer linked via the initiator Met of the ubiquitin (linear
CC       polyubiquitin chains). Polyubiquitin chains, when attached to a
CC       target protein, have different functions depending on the Lys
CC       residue of the ubiquitin that is linked: Lys-6-linked may be
CC       involved in DNA repair; Lys-11-linked is involved in ERAD
CC       (endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation) and in cell-cycle
CC       regulation; Lys-29-linked is involved in lysosomal degradation;
CC       Lys-33-linked is involved in kinase modification; Lys-48-linked is
CC       involved in protein degradation via the proteasome; Lys-63-linked
CC       is involved in endocytosis, DNA-damage responses as well as in
CC       signaling processes leading to activation of the transcription
CC       factor NF-kappa-B. Linear polymer chains formed via attachment by
CC       the initiator Met lead to cell signaling. Ubiquitin is usually
CC       conjugated to Lys residues of target proteins, however, in rare
CC       cases, conjugation to Cys or Ser residues has been observed. When
CC       polyubiquitin is free (unanchored-polyubiquitin), it also has
CC       distinct roles, such as in activation of protein kinases, and in
CC       signaling. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16543144,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19754430}.

CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Ubiquitin: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitin: Phosphorylated at Ser-65 by PINK1 during
CC       mitophagy. Phosphorylated ubiquitin specifically binds and
CC       activates parkin (PRKN), triggering mitophagy (PubMed:24660806,
CC       PubMed:24751536, PubMed:24784582, PubMed:25527291).
CC       Phosphorylation does not affect E1-mediated E2 charging of
CC       ubiquitin but affects discharging of E2 enzymes to form
CC       polyubiquitin chains. It also affects deubiquitination by
CC       deubiquitinase enzymes such as USP30 (PubMed:25527291).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24660806, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24751536,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24784582, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25527291}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitin: Mono-ADP-riblosylated at the C-terminus by PARP9,
CC       a component of the PPAR9-DTX3L complex. ADP-ribosylation requires
CC       processing by E1 and E2 enzymes and prevents ubiquitin conjugation
CC       to substrates such as histones. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:28525742}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Ubiquitin is encoded by 4 different genes. UBA52
CC       and RPS27A genes code for a single copy of ubiquitin fused to the
CC       ribosomal proteins L40 and S27a, respectively. UBB and UBC genes
CC       code for a polyubiquitin precursor with exact head to tail
CC       repeats, the number of repeats differ between species and strains.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: For the sake of clarity sequence features are
CC       annotated only for the first chain, and are not repeated for each
CC       of the following chains.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ubiquitin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see https://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [13]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.05 ANGSTROMS) OF 1327-1769 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   ATP AND ACTIN.
RX   PubMed=15635372; DOI=10.1038/nature03251;
RA   Otomo T., Tomchick D.R., Otomo C., Panchal S.C., Machius M.,
RA   Rosen M.K.;
RT   "Structural basis of actin filament nucleation and processive capping
RT   by a formin homology 2 domain.";
RL   Nature 433:488-494(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for the assembly of F-actin structures, such as
CC       actin cables and stress fibers. Nucleates actin filaments. Binds
CC       to the barbed end of the actin filament and acts as leaky capper,
CC       slowing both polymerization and depolymerization. Protects the
CC       growing actin fiber from tight capping proteins and so increases
CC       the time of elongation and the total amount of F-actin. May
CC       organize microtubules by mediating spindle positioning and
CC       movement in the budding process. Potential target of the RHO
CC       family members. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10085293,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14561409}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer, and possibly also homotetramer. Interacts with
CC       PFY1 via the FH1 domain and with actin via the FH2 domain.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15635372}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-3692, EBI-3692;
CC       P68139:ACTA1 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-3692, EBI-3058728;
CC       P36006:MYO3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-3692, EBI-11670;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane. Cell projection, ruffle
CC       membrane. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The DAD domain regulates activation via by an
CC       autoinhibitory interaction with the GBD/FH3 domain. This
CC       autoinhibition is released upon competitive binding of an
CC       activated GTPase. The release of DAD allows the FH2 domain to then
CC       nucleate and elongate nonbranched actin filaments (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Each FH2 dimer contains binding sites for 4 actin
CC       molecules.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 166 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the formin homology family. BNI1 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=22814378; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1210303109;
RA   Van Damme P., Lasa M., Polevoda B., Gazquez C., Elosegui-Artola A.,
RA   Kim D.S., De Juan-Pardo E., Demeyer K., Hole K., Larrea E.,
RA   Timmerman E., Prieto J., Arnesen T., Sherman F., Gevaert K.,

RT   "N-terminal acetylome analyses and functional insights of the N-
RT   terminal acetyltransferase NatB.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:12449-12454(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in transport from the ER to the Golgi apparatus
CC       as well as in intra-Golgi transport. It belongs to a super-family
CC       of proteins called t-SNAREs or soluble NSF (N-ethylmaleimide-
CC       sensitive factor) attachment protein receptor. Rescues alpha-
CC       factor maturation defects. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160819,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11959998, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of several multiprotein Golgi SNARE complexes.
CC       Identified in a Golgi SNARE complex consisting of t-SNARES SED5,
CC       YKT6, and the v-SNARE SFT1. Interacts with BET1. Interacts with
CC       BOS1. Interacts with SEC22. Interacts with PEP12. Interacts with
CC       self. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10591633, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11959998,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9211930, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q01590:SED5; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-24365, EBI-16930;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107716, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16699523,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}; Single-pass type IV membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16107716, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16699523,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}. Note=Punctate localization pattern.
CC       Localization affected by loss of SVP26, a membrane protein, and is
CC       shifted to the ER.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Lack of late Golgi SNARE proteins, TLG1 and
CC       TLG2. Spores are temperature sensitive and fail to germinate at 37
CC       degrees Celsius. 10 to 20% of cells possess a variety of aberrant
CC       structures, including fragmentation of the vacuole, a common
CC       occurrence in secretory defects, and substantial accumulation of
CC       membranes in some cells. These structures are considered to be
CC       abnormal Golgi remnants. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER) retention
CC       defective, erd phenotype, which is characterized by hypersecretion
CC       of ER-resident proteins. This results from a defect in retrograde
CC       directed vesicles. Severely compromised viability when another
CC       Golgi protein, COY1P is overexpressed. Incomplete maturation of
CC       alpha-factor via defective localization of KEX2.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160819, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12429822, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9755865}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GOSR1 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Formerly referred to as a v-SNARE. {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "Purification of active HOPS complex reveals its affinities for
RT   phosphoinositides and the SNARE Vam7p.";
RL   EMBO J. 25:1579-1589(2006).
RN   [6]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for vacuolar assembly. Acts as component of the
CC       HOPS complex that acts during the docking stage of vacuole fusion.
CC       HOPS is an effector for the vacuolar Rab GTPase YPT7 and is
CC       required for vacuolar SNARE complex assembly. It remains bound to
CC       SNARE complexes after vacuole fusion.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16601699}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the HOPS complex which is composed of PEP5,
CC       VPS16, PEP3, VPS33, VPS39 and VPS41. HOPS associates with
CC       phosphoinositides and the PX domain of VAM7. Interacts with VPS41
CC       and VAM7. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16601699}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P20795:VPS33; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-20422, EBI-20395;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane {ECO:0000305}; Peripheral
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 319 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the VAM6/VPS39 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "Mms1 and Mms22 stabilize the replisome during replication stress.";

RN   [12]
RP   FUNCTION IN UBIQUITINATION OF H3.
RX   PubMed=24209620; DOI=10.1016/j.cell.2013.10.014;
RA   Han J., Zhang H., Zhang H., Wang Z., Zhou H., Zhang Z.;
RT   "A Cul4 E3 ubiquitin ligase regulates histone hand-off during
RT   nucleosome assembly.";
RL   Cell 155:817-829(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Substrate targeting component of a cullin-RING-based E3
CC       ubiquitin-protein ligase complex RTT101(MMS1-MMS22). RTT101(MMS1-
CC       MMS22) promotes fork progression through damaged DNA or natural
CC       pause sites by stabilizing replication proteins like the
CC       replication fork-pausing complex (FPC) and leading-strand
CC       polymerase at stalled replication forks. RTT101(MMS1-MMS22)
CC       ubiquitinates the acetylated histones H3K56ac-H4 at lysine
CC       residues H3K121, H3K122 and H3K125. Ubiquitination is required for
CC       efficient histone deposition during replication-coupled nucleosome
CC       assembly, probably by facilitating the transfer of H3-H4 from ASF1
CC       to other chaperones involved in histone deposition.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12482937, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12694535,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15718301, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16024805,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18321796, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18704118,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21593207, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24209620}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of a cullin-RING ligase (CRL) composed of 4
CC       subunits: the RING protein HRT1, the cullin RTT101, a linker
CC       protein MMS1, and the substrate receptor MMS22. This complex
CC       further interacts with RTT107 and CTF4 to form RTT101-MMS1-MMS22-
CC       RTT107 and RTT101-MMS1-MMS22-CTF4 complexes respectively.
CC       Interacts (via C-ter) with MMS1 (via N-ter). Interacts with
CC       RTT107. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16569515, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18704118,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20139071}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q01454:CTF4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-31156, EBI-5209;
CC       Q06211:MMS1; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-31156, EBI-38894;
CC       P47050:RTT101; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-31156, EBI-25861;
CC       P38850:RTT107; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-31156, EBI-24788;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15718301}.
CC       Note=Nuclear punctate foci structures.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MMS22 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=11864609; DOI=10.1016/S1097-2765(02)00446-X;

RN   [11]
RP   FUNCTION, AND IDENTIFICATION IN THE TIM22 COMPLEX WITH TIM10; TIM12;
RP   TIM18 AND TIM54.
RX   PubMed=12637749; DOI=10.1126/science.1080945;
RA   Rehling P., Model K., Brandner K., Kovermann P., Sickmann A.,
RA   Meyer H.E., Kuehlbrandt W., Wagner R., Truscott K.N., Pfanner N.;
RT   "Protein insertion into the mitochondrial inner membrane by a twin-
RT   pore translocase.";
RL   Science 299:1747-1751(2003).
RN   [12]
RP   ERRATUM.
RA   Rehling P., Model K., Brandner K., Kovermann P., Sickmann A.,
RA   Meyer H.E., Kuehlbrandt W., Wagner R., Truscott K.N., Pfanner N.;
RL   Science 300:251-251(2003).
RN   [13]
RP   DISULFIDE BOND, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TOPOLOGY.
RX   PubMed=27265872; DOI=10.1038/srep27484;
RA   Wrobel L., Sokol A.M., Chojnacka M., Chacinska A.;
RT   "The presence of disulfide bonds reveals an evolutionarily conserved
RT   mechanism involved in mitochondrial protein translocase assembly.";
RL   Sci. Rep. 6:27484-27484(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Essential core component of the TIM22 complex, a complex
CC       that mediates the import and insertion of multi-pass transmembrane
CC       proteins, such as mitochondrial carrier family members, into the
CC       mitochondrial inner membrane. In the TIM22 complex, it constitutes
CC       the voltage-activated and signal-gated channel. Forms a twin-pore
CC       translocase that uses the membrane potential as external driving
CC       force in 2 voltage-dependent steps. Mediates the insertion of
CC       precursor proteins in a 3 step process. After the precursor is
CC       tethered to the translocase without losing energy from the
CC       Delta(psi), 2 energy-requiring steps are needed. First, Delta(psi)
CC       acts on the precursor protein and promotes its docking in the
CC       translocase complex. Then, Delta(psi) and an internal signal
CC       peptide together induce rapid gating transitions in one pore and
CC       closing of the other pore and drive membrane insertion to
CC       completion. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11864609,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12637749, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8955274}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the TIM22 complex, whose core is composed of
CC       TIM18, TIM22 and TIM54, associated with the peripheral proteins
CC       MRS5/TIM12 and the 70 kDa heterohexamer composed of TIM9 and TIM10
CC       (or TIM8 and TIM13). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10648604,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12637749}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53220:TIM21; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9132, EBI-23128;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10397776, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8955274,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:27265872}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10397776, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8955274}.
CC       Note=Import into inner membrane protein requires TOM20 function.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the Tim17/Tim22/Tim23 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, AND INTERACTION WITH USA1.
RX   PubMed=20005842; DOI=10.1016/j.molcel.2009.10.015;
RA   Horn S.C., Hanna J., Hirsch C., Volkwein C., Schutz A., Heinemann U.,
RA   Sommer T., Jarosch E.;

RN   [11]
RP   FUNCTION, DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, ACETYLATION AT MET-1, AND MUTAGENESIS
RP   OF ASP-2.
RX   PubMed=23363603; DOI=10.1091/mbc.E12-11-0838;
RA   Zattas D., Adle D.J., Rubenstein E.M., Hochstrasser M.;
RT   "N-terminal acetylation of the yeast Derlin Der1 is essential for Hrd1
RT   ubiquitin-ligase activity toward luminal ER substrates.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 24:890-900(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the endoplasmic reticulum-associated
CC       degradation (ERAD) pathway. Specifically required for the ERAD-L
CC       pathway which mediates the degradation of proteins with misfolded
CC       lumenal domains within the endoplasmic reticulum.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16873066, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20005842,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23363603, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8631297}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the HRD1 complex which contains HRD1, HRD3,
CC       USA1, DER1, YOS9, CDC48, NPL4, UFD1 AND UBX2/SEL1. The complex is
CC       composed of the core membrane complex, consisting of the E3 ligase
CC       HRD1 and its cofactors HRD3, DER1 and USA1, the substrate
CC       recruiting factor YOS9, and the heterotrimeric UFD1-NPL4-CDC48/p97
CC       (UNC) ATPase complex recruited by UBX2/SEL1. Interacts with HRD1,
CC       HRD3, USA1, YOS9 and CDC48. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16873066,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20005842}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P25694:CDC48; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-5761, EBI-4308;
CC       Q08109:HRD1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-5761, EBI-37613;
CC       Q05787:HRD3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-5761, EBI-31647;
CC       P00729:PRC1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-5761, EBI-4153;
CC       P53044:UFD1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-5761, EBI-19997;
CC       Q03714:USA1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-5761, EBI-27760;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8631297}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8631297}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated by the unfolded protein response (UPR).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10847680}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-terminally acetylated by acetyltransferase NatB which
CC       enhances DER1 stability and is required for ERAD-L function.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23363603}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Impaired degradation of proteins with
CC       misfolded lumenal domains such as CPY*, a mutant, misfolded form
CC       of carboxypeptidase Y which is a known ERAD-L substrate.
CC       Degradation of proteins with misfolded intramembrane domains is
CC       not affected. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16873066,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20005842, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23363603}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 238 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the derlin family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA79688.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=40; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC       partially the defects due to BCY1 disruption. Is implicated in the
CC       control of the cell cycle G1 phase.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Major phosphatase responsible for tyrosine
CC       dephosphorylation of MAP kinases FUS3 and HOG1 to inactivate their
CC       activity; it also has important roles, along with MSG5, in the
CC       inactivation of FUS3 following pheromone stimulation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9032256, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9211927}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Protein tyrosine phosphate + H(2)O = protein
CC       tyrosine + phosphate. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU10044}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with HOG1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9211927}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 768 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the protein-tyrosine phosphatase family.
CC       Non-receptor class subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION AT SER-68; SER-70; SER-74; SER-77; SER-79; SER-81;
RP   SER-83; SER-84; THR-129; SER-130; THR-131; THR-144; SER-145; SER-147;

RX   PubMed=20702584; DOI=10.1091/mbc.E10-03-0182;
RA   Soulard A., Cremonesi A., Moes S., Schutz F., Jeno P., Hall M.N.;
RT   "The rapamycin-sensitive phosphoproteome reveals that TOR controls
RT   protein kinase A toward some but not all substrates.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 21:3475-3486(2010).
RN   [18]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.21 ANGSTROMS) OF 171-416 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   CAMP.
RX   PubMed=21070946; DOI=10.1016/j.str.2010.08.013;
RA   Rinaldi J., Wu J., Yang J., Ralston C.Y., Sankaran B., Moreno S.,
RA   Taylor S.S.;
RT   "Structure of yeast regulatory subunit: a glimpse into the evolution
RT   of PKA signaling.";
RL   Structure 18:1471-1482(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Regulatory subunit of the cyclic AMP-dependent protein
CC       kinase (PKA), an effector of the Ras/cAMP pathway. Inhibits PKA
CC       activity in the absence of cAMP. cAMP activates PKA and promotes
CC       growth and proliferation in response to good nutrient conditions.
CC       Together with ZDS1, provides a negative feedback control on the
CC       cell wall integrity-signaling pathway by acting as a negative
CC       regulator of MAP kinase SLT2/MPK1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12704202,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2823100, ECO:0000269|PubMed:3037314,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:6243658}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The inactive holoenzyme of cAMP-dependent protein kinase
CC       is a tetramer, composed of 2 regulatory subunits (R, encoded by
CC       BCY1) and two catalytic subunits (C, encoded by the 3 partially
CC       redundant TPK1, TPK2, and TPK3 genes). Activation by cAMP causes
CC       dissociation of the holoenzyme, producing 2 active catalytic
CC       monomers C and a regulatory dimer R(2).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21070946, ECO:0000269|PubMed:3037314}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-9475, EBI-9475;
CC       P22696:ESS1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9475, EBI-6679;
CC       P06244:TPK1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-9475, EBI-9458;
CC       P06245:TPK2; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-9475, EBI-9465;
CC       P05986:TPK3; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-9475, EBI-9470;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Nucleus. Note=Cytoplasmic when
CC       phosphorylated. Nuclear when not phosphorylated.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The inhibitor sequence (IS) is a substrate recognition
CC       motif that docks to the active site cleft of the catalytic subunit
CC       rendering the holoenzyme inactive.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Binding of cAMP to the 2 tandem cyclic-nucleotide binding
CC       domains (CNB-A and CNB-B) induces a conformational change in BCY1,
CC       causing the interaction surface with the catalytic subunit to be
CC       destroyed and eventually the dissociation of the R dimer from the
CC       C subunits.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated by YAK1 in response to glucose starvation.
CC       Phosphorylated by MCK1 at Thr-129 upon TOR complex 1 (TORC1)
CC       inhibition. Thr-129 phosphorylation activates BCY1 to inhibit PKA.
CC       TORC1 inhibits phosphorylation of RxxS/T sites but has no effect
CC       on Ser-145 phosphorylation. The phosphorylation sites can be
CC       clustered in several groups, all localized in the N-terminal part.
CC       The first cluster termed cluster I (CI) is located close to the N-
CC       terminus and includes Ser-3, Ser-4 and Ser-9 (PubMed:11134339,
CC       PubMed:12704202). The second includes Ser-68, Ser-70, Ser-74, Ser-
CC       77, Ser-79, Ser-81, Ser-83, and Ser-84. This cluster of
CC       phosphorylation sites, termed cluster II (CII), is important for
CC       BCY1 cytoplasmic localization and function (PubMed:11134339,
CC       PubMed:12704202, PubMed:20702584). The third cluster of
CC       phosphorylated residues consists of Thr-144, Ser-145, Ser-147,
CC       Thr-150, and Thr-160. This cluster falls within or near the so-
CC       called autoinhibitory domain where the catalytic subunit of PKA
CC       autophosphorylates the highly conserved Ser-145 to inhibit BCY1
CC       (PubMed:20702584). A last cluster of phosphorylated residues
CC       included Thr-129, Ser-130, and Thr-131 and is termed cluster III
CC       (CIII). Sites in CIII (and to a lesser extent in CII) are
CC       hyperphosphorylated in response to rapamycin (PubMed:20702584).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11134339, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12704202,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: A developmentally regulated protein important for
CC       microtubule functions. Targets KAR3 to the cytoplasmic
CC       microtubules during mating. Essential for KAR3 function during
CC       prophase of meiosis I. Required for interhomolog recombination,
CC       synapsis of homologous chromosomes and establishment of a meiosis
CC       I spindle. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10087265,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11729143}.

RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR, AND TRANSMEMBRANE DOMAIN.
RX   PubMed=15001703; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0400512101;
RA   Zubkov S., Lennarz W.J., Mohanty S.;
RT   "Structural basis for the function of a minimembrane protein subunit
RT   of yeast oligosaccharyltransferase.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 101:3821-3826(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Essential subunit of the N-oligosaccharyl transferase
CC       (OST) complex which catalyzes the transfer of a high mannose
CC       oligosaccharide from a lipid-linked oligosaccharide donor to an
CC       asparagine residue within an Asn-X-Ser/Thr consensus motif in
CC       nascent polypeptide chains. N-glycosylation occurs
CC       cotranslationally and the complex associates with the Sec61
CC       complex at the channel-forming translocon complex that mediates
CC       protein translocation across the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). All
CC       subunits are required for a maximal enzyme activity. OST4 is
CC       required for recruitment of OST3 or OST6 to the OST complex. It is
CC       essential for cell growth at 37 but not at 25 degrees Celsius.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Dolichyl diphosphooligosaccharide + [protein]-
CC       L-asparagine = dolichyl diphosphate + a glycoprotein with the
CC       oligosaccharide chain attached by N-beta-D-glycosyl linkage to a
CC       protein L-asparagine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein glycosylation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the oligosaccharyltransferase (OST) complex,
CC       which appears to exist in two assemblies comprising OST1, OST2,
CC       OST4, OST5, STT3, SWP1, WPB1, and either OST3 or OST6. OST3, OST4
CC       and STT3 probably form a subcomplex. May interact directly with
CC       OST2, OST3, OST5, OST6, STT3, WBP1 and SWP1. Interacts with SEC61,
CC       SBH1 and SSS1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10677492,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15831493, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15886282,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8175708, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9405463}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P48439:OST3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-12680;
CC       P52870:SBH1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-16410;
CC       P32915:SEC61; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-16400;
CC       P35179:SSS1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-16406;
CC       P39007:STT3; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-18447;
CC       Q02795:SWP1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-12666;
CC       P33767:WBP1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-12689, EBI-12658;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Single-pass
CC       type III membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2430 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the OST4 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Negatively regulates the high-osmolarity glycerol (HOG)
CC       pathway through its negative regulation of the HOG1 kinase
CC       activity. Mediates the binding between the PTC1 phosphatase and
CC       the PBS2 MAP/ERK kinase (MEK). With PTC1, regulates endoplasmic
CC       reticulum inheritance through the cell wall integrity (CWI) MAPK
CC       pathway by modulating the MAPK, SLT2.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14573466, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14685261,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16977319}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with PBS2 and PTC1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14685261}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P40563:AIM21; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-34713, EBI-25376;
CC       P48562:CLA4; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-34713, EBI-4750;
CC       P08018:PBS2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-34713, EBI-12972;
CC       P35182:PTC1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-34713, EBI-12784;
CC       Q03497:STE20; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-34713, EBI-18285;

CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC       the cell division cycle. Mediates a protein kinase cascade; it

RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=18407956; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M700468-MCP200;
RA   Albuquerque C.P., Smolka M.B., Payne S.H., Bafna V., Eng J., Zhou H.;

RN   [11]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: DNA-binding protein that recognizes sites within both
CC       the enhancer and the promoter of rRNA transcription, as well as
CC       upstream of many genes transcribed by RNA polymerase II. It is
CC       essential for cell growth. May stimulate or inhibit transcription.
CC       Specifically recognizes the sequence 5'-CCGGGTA-3' or 5'-CGGGTRR-
CC       3' (where R is any purine). A member of the general regulatory
CC       factors (GRFs) which act as genome partitioners. Acts as a
CC       chromatin insulator which are known as STARs (Subtelomeric anti-
CC       silencing region). STARs prevent negative or positive
CC       transcription influence by extending across chromotin to a
CC       promoter. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11258704,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12200417}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 7510 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE TRAPP III COMPLEX, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND

RX   PubMed=20375281; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1000063107;
RA   Lynch-Day M.A., Bhandari D., Menon S., Huang J., Cai H.,
RA   Bartholomew C.R., Brumell J.H., Ferro-Novick S., Klionsky D.J.;
RT   "Trs85 directs a Ypt1 GEF, TRAPPIII, to the phagophore to promote
RT   autophagy.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 107:7811-7816(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the TRAPP I, TRAPP II and TRAPP III
CC       complexes which act as guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEF)
CC       for YPT1. TRAPP I plays a key role in the late stages of
CC       endoplasmic reticulum to Golgi traffic. TRAPP II plays a role in
CC       intra-Golgi transport. TRAPP III plays a role in autophagosome
CC       formation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239471,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20972447,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9564032}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Part of the multisubunit TRAPP (transport protein
CC       particle) I complex composed of BET3, BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31
CC       and TRS33. Part of the multisubunit TRAPP (transport protein
CC       particle) II complex composed of BET3, BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31,
CC       TRS33, TRS65, TRS85, TRS120 and TRS130. Part of the multisubunit
CC       TRAPP (transport protein particle) III complex composed of BET3,
CC       BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31, TRS33 and TRS85.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239471, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20972447, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9564032}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P36149:BET3; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-19468, EBI-3567;
CC       Q03660:TRS130; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-19468, EBI-19461;
CC       Q03337:TRS31; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-19468, EBI-38770;
CC       P46944:TRS85; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-19468, EBI-19492;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus, cis-Golgi network.
CC       Endoplasmic reticulum. Preautophagosomal structure.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1200 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAPP small subunits family. Sedlin
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the dismutation of two molecules of 6,7-
CC       dimethyl-8-ribityllumazine, resulting in the formation of
CC       riboflavin and 5-amino-6-(D-ribitylamino)uracil.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7814407}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2 6,7-dimethyl-8-(1-D-ribityl)lumazine =
CC       riboflavin + 4-(1-D-ribitylamino)-5-amino-2,6-dihydroxypyrimidine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Cofactor biosynthesis; riboflavin biosynthesis;
CC       riboflavin from 2-hydroxy-3-oxobutyl phosphate and 5-amino-6-(D-
CC       ribitylamino)uracil: step 2/2.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotrimer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9Y7P0}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 7300 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE SPOTS COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=20182505; DOI=10.1038/nature08787;
RA   Breslow D.K., Collins S.R., Bodenmiller B., Aebersold R., Simons K.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic subunit of serine palmitoyltransferase (SPT),
CC       which catalyzes the committed step in the synthesis of
CC       sphingolipids, the condensation of serine with palmitoyl CoA to
CC       form the long chain base 3-ketosphinganine.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Palmitoyl-CoA + L-serine = CoA + 3-dehydro-D-
CC       sphinganine + CO(2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10713067,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11781309, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15485854,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8058731, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8063782}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=pyridoxal 5'-phosphate; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:597326;
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Lipid metabolism; sphingolipid metabolism.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: LCB1 and LCB2 encode essential subunits of the enzyme and
CC       form a heterodimer. Component of the SPOTS complex, at least
CC       composed of LCB1/2 (LCB1 and/or LCB2), ORM1/2 (ORM1 and/or ORM2),
CC       SAC1 and TSC3. Interacts with LCB1 and TSC3.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10713067, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11781309,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15485854, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20182505,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8058731}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P25045:LCB1; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-10067, EBI-10059;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Endoplasmic reticulum. Membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 54500 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   UBIQUITINATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-183, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22106047; DOI=10.1002/pmic.201100166;
RA   Starita L.M., Lo R.S., Eng J.K., von Haller P.D., Fields S.;
RT   "Sites of ubiquitin attachment in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   Proteomics 12:236-240(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: SNARE protein (of Qc type) involved in membrane fusion
CC       probably in retrograde traffic of cytosolic double-membrane
CC       vesicles derived from both, early and possibly late endosomes/PVC
CC       (prevacuolar compartment) back to the trans-Golgi network (TGN or
CC       late Golgi). It has been reported to function both as a (target
CC       membrane) t-SNARE and as a (vesicle) v-SNARE. Upon vesicle
CC       tethering to the target membrane, which requires additional
CC       proteins, a SNARE-pin is formed. This is a very stable 4 parallel
CC       alpha-helical coil bundle consisting of 4 SNARE domains (usually
CC       one of each type: Qa, Qb, Qc, and R), of which at least one is
CC       anchored in the opposite membrane. The formation of the SNARE-pin
CC       is believed to bring the two membranes in close proximity and to
CC       provide the energy to drive membrane fusion. Through its
CC       interaction with the VFT (or GARP) complex, it may also contribute
CC       to vesicle recognition specificity and tethering. Regulation of
CC       SNARE-pin formation also seems to depend on the phosphorylation
CC       state of the protein, phosphorylation by TPK1 causing inhibition
CC       and dephosphorylation by SIT4 activation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10397773, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11739407, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12686613, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9427746}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts in a SNARE-pin with the SNAREs TLG2 (Qa), VTI1
CC       (Qb), and SNC1 or SNC2 (R). Interacts with VPS51 of the VFT (or
CC       GARP) complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10397773,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11739407,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9427746}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P36116:VPS51; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-38705, EBI-26352;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus, trans-Golgi network
CC       membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type IV membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}. Early endosome membrane {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass
CC       type IV membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Late endosome membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Single-pass type IV membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Note=Probably shuttling between TGN and early/late endosome.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated at Thr-31 by TPK1 and dephosphorylated by
CC       SIT4. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006655}.
CC   -!- PTM: Palmitoylated by SWF1, which prevents its recognition and
CC       ubiquitination by TUL1 and its subsequent degradation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15973437}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the syntaxin family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       cytoplasmic domain. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12853481}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Actins are highly conserved proteins that are involved
CC       in various types of cell motility and are ubiquitously expressed
CC       in all eukaryotic cells.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Polymerization of globular actin (G-actin) leads to a
CC       structural filament (F-actin) in the form of a two-stranded helix
CC       (Probable). Treatments with Lantrunculin A, the microbial peptide
CC       Chondramide or the microbial metabolite Chivazole F inhibit actin
CC       polymerization (PubMed:28796488). Each actin can bind to 4 others.
CC       Interacts with YIH1 (via C-terminus); this interaction occurs in a
CC       GCN1-independent manner (PubMed:15126500, PubMed:21239490).
CC       Component of the INO80 complex. Component of the SWR1 complex.
CC       Component of the NuA4 complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15126500,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21239490, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28796488,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-2169;
CC       P46680:AIP1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-2406;
CC       Q03048:COF1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-4853;
CC       Q06440:CRN1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-4950;
CC       P0A6F5:groL (xeno); NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-543750;
CC       P02829:HSP82; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-8659;
CC       Q12446:LAS17; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-10022;
CC       P07274:PFY1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-13892;
CC       P39743:RVS167; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-14500;
CC       P32599:SAC6; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-6931;
CC       P17555:SRV2; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-4024;
CC       P12612:TCP1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-2169, EBI-19045;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the actin family. {ECO:0000305}.
