RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 465-718, AND TOPOLOGY.
RX   PubMed=22865878; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M112.342253;
RA   Huang C., Bhaskaran R., Mohanty S.;
RT   "Eukaryotic N-glycosylation occurs via the membrane-anchored C-
RT   terminal domain of the Stt3p subunit of oligosaccharyltransferase.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 287:32450-32458(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic subunit of the N-oligosaccharyl transferase
CC       (OST) complex which catalyzes the transfer of a high mannose
CC       oligosaccharide to an asparagine residue within an Asn-X-Ser/Thr
CC       consensus motif in nascent polypeptide chains. N-glycosylation
CC       occurs cotranslationally and the complex associates with the Sec61
CC       complex at the channel-forming translocon complex that mediates
CC       protein translocation across the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). All
CC       subunits are required for a maximal enzyme activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12359722}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Dolichyl diphosphooligosaccharide + [protein]-
CC       L-asparagine = dolichyl diphosphate + a glycoprotein with the
CC       oligosaccharide chain attached by N-beta-D-glycosyl linkage to a
CC       protein L-asparagine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein glycosylation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the oligosaccharyltransferase (OST) complex,
CC       which appears to exist in two assemblies comprising OST1, OST2,
CC       OST4, OST5, STT3, SWP1, WPB1, and either OST3 or OST6. OST3, OST4
CC       and STT3 probably form a subcomplex. May interact directly with
CC       OST3, OST4, OST6, WBP1 and SWP1. Interacts with SEC61.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10677492, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15831493,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15886282, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9405463,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9435788}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q99380:OST4; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-18447, EBI-12689;
CC       P32915:SEC61; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-18447, EBI-16400;
CC       P33767:WBP1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-18447, EBI-12658;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the STT3 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 61-262.
RX   PubMed=17565980; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M703716200;
RA   Cavanaugh L.F., Chen X., Richardson B.C., Ungar D., Pelczer I.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the peripheral membrane COG complex
CC       that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking. COG is
CC       located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of retrograde
CC       intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other membrane
CC       trafficking events. COG2 is required for ER to Golgi vesicle
CC       docking. Not essential for viability.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006647, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9606204}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. The COG complex interacts with the Rab GTPase YPT1, the
CC       Glogi SNAREs GOS1, SEC22, SED5, VTI1 and YKT6 and the COPI
CC       coatomer subunit gamma SEC21. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006647, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12011112,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15047703}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53079:COG1; NbExp=16; IntAct=EBI-16614, EBI-4835;
CC       P40094:COG3; NbExp=16; IntAct=EBI-16614, EBI-16605;
CC       Q06096:COG4; NbExp=15; IntAct=EBI-16614, EBI-4823;
CC       P53951:COG5; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-16614, EBI-4841;
CC       P53959:COG6; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-16614, EBI-4829;
CC       P53195:COG7; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-16614, EBI-4847;
CC       Q04632:COG8; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-16614, EBI-6035;
CC       Q01590:SED5; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-16614, EBI-16930;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9606204};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9606204}; Cytoplasmic side
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9606204}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3270 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the cyclization of (S)-2,3 oxidosqualene to
CC       lanosterol, a reaction that forms the sterol nucleus.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (3S)-2,3-epoxy-2,3-dihydrosqualene =
CC       lanosterol.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: ERG27 is required for activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12842197}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 7. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1731628};
CC       Temperature dependence:
CC         Optimum temperature is 35 degrees Celsius.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1731628};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Terpene metabolism; lanosterol biosynthesis; lanosterol
CC       from farnesyl diphosphate: step 3/3.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q12452:ERG27; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6572, EBI-38132;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Lipid droplet. Endoplasmic reticulum
CC       membrane; Peripheral membrane protein. Note=Predominantly in lipid
CC       particles.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2193 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the terpene cyclase/mutase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchor
CC       biosynthesis. Transfers ethanolamine phosphate to the GPI third
CC       mannose which links the GPI-anchor to the C-terminus of the
CC       proteins by an amide bond. Involved in cell wall biosynthesis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10487931, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10793139,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10823837, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12441642}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycolipid biosynthesis; glycosylphosphatidylinositol-
CC       anchor biosynthesis.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- PTM: Glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10823837}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 300 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the PIGG/PIGN/PIGO family. PIGO subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in pre-mRNA splicing.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Belongs to the CWC complex (or CEF1-associated complex),
CC       a spliceosome sub-complex reminiscent of a late-stage spliceosome
CC       composed of the U2, U5 and U6 snRNAs and at least BUD13, BUD31,
CC       BRR2, CDC40, CEF1, CLF1, CUS1, CWC2, CWC15, CWC21, CWC22, CWC23,
CC       CWC24, CWC25, CWC27, ECM2, HSH155, IST3, ISY1, LEA1, MSL1, NTC20,
CC       PRP8, PRP9, PRP11, PRP19, PRP21, PRP22, PRP45, PRP46, SLU7, SMB1,
CC       SMD1, SMD2, SMD3, SMX2, SMX3, SNT309, SNU114, SPP2, SYF1, SYF2,
CC       RSE1 and YJU2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11884590}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 996 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CWC24 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: ATP-dependent 5'->3' DNA/RNA helicase required for the
CC       expression and maturation of diverse classes of non-protein-coding
CC       RNAs like precursor tRNAs, rRNAs and small nuclear (snRNA) and
CC       nucleolar (snoRNA) RNAs. Directs RNA polymerase II transcription
CC       termination on snoRNAs as well as on several short protein-coding
CC       genes. May also play a role in transcription-coupled nucleotide
CC       excision repair. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11565036,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15121901, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17157256,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8943355, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9365256,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9819377}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RAD2, RNT1 and RPB1. Binds to multiple
CC       snoRNAs. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15121901}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P32598:GLC7; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-16945, EBI-13715;
CC       P38996:NAB3; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-16945, EBI-11776;
CC       P07276:RAD2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-16945, EBI-14757;
CC       Q02555:RNT1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-16945, EBI-15673;
CC       P04050:RPO21; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-16945, EBI-15760;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8544822}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 125 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DNA2/NAM7 helicase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAB63976.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=130; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RT   vesicle tethering.";

RN   [8]
RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE TRAPP III COMPLEX, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND
RP   FUNCTION OF THE TRAPP III COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=20375281; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1000063107;
RA   Lynch-Day M.A., Bhandari D., Menon S., Huang J., Cai H.,
RA   Bartholomew C.R., Brumell J.H., Ferro-Novick S., Klionsky D.J.;
RT   "Trs85 directs a Ypt1 GEF, TRAPPIII, to the phagophore to promote
RT   autophagy.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 107:7811-7816(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the TRAPP I, TRAPP II and TRAPP III
CC       complexes which act as guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEF)
CC       for YPT1. TRAPP I plays a key role in the late stages of
CC       endoplasmic reticulum to Golgi traffic. TRAPP II plays a role in
CC       intra-Golgi transport. TRAPP III plays a role in autophagosome
CC       formation. Required for sporulation. Has a role late in meiosis
CC       following DNA replication. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239471,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20972447,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9611195}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Part of the multisubunit TRAPP (transport protein
CC       particle) I complex composed of BET3, BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31
CC       and TRS33. Part of the multisubunit TRAPP (transport protein
CC       particle) II complex composed of BET3, BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31,
CC       TRS33, TRS65, TRS85, TRS120 and TRS130. Part of the multisubunit
CC       TRAPP (transport protein particle) III complex composed of BET3,
CC       BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31, TRS33 and TRS85.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239471, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20972447, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9564032}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P36149:BET3; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-3580, EBI-3567;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus, cis-Golgi network.
CC       Endoplasmic reticulum. Preautophagosomal structure.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAPP small subunits family. BET5
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   CHARACTERIZATION.
RX   PubMed=1313947; DOI=10.1038/356532a0;

RN   [6]
RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE SRP COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=7925282;
RA   Brown J.D., Hann B.C., Medzihradszky K.F., Niwa M., Burlingame A.L.,
RA   Walter P.;
RT   "Subunits of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae signal recognition particle
RT   required for its functional expression.";
RL   EMBO J. 13:4390-4400(1994).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Signal-recognition-particle (SRP) assembly has a crucial
CC       role in targeting secretory proteins to the rough endoplasmic
CC       reticulum (ER) membrane. SRP is required for the cotranslational
CC       protein translocation for ER import and preferentially recognizes
CC       strongly hydrophobic signal sequences. It is involved in targeting
CC       the nascent chain-ribosome (RNC) complex to the ER and is proposed
CC       to participate in the arrest of nascent chain elongation during
CC       membrane targeting. SEC65 is required for SRP integrity.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Fungal signal recognition particle (SRP) complex consists
CC       of a 7S RNA molecule (scR1) and at least six protein subunits:
CC       SRP72, SRP68, SRP54, SEC65, SRP21 and SRP14.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7925282}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38985:SRP14; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-16641, EBI-17977;
CC       P32342:SRP21; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-16641, EBI-17984;
CC       P38688:SRP72; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-16641, EBI-18011;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}.

RT   "The Saccharomyces cerevisiae v-SNARE Vti1p is required for multiple
RT   membrane transport pathways to the vacuole.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Cell 10:1719-1732(1999).
RN   [10]
RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH SNC2; TLG1 AND TLG2.
RX   PubMed=11739407; DOI=10.1083/jcb.200104092;

RA   Rothman J.E.;
RT   "A t-SNARE of the endocytic pathway must be activated for fusion.";
RL   J. Cell Biol. 155:961-968(2001).

RX   PubMed=12453154; DOI=10.1034/j.1600-0854.2002.31207.x;

RL   Traffic 3:922-929(2002).
RN   [12]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=14981247; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0400271101;
RA   Paumet F., Rahimian V., Rothman J.E.;
RT   "The specificity of SNARE-dependent fusion is encoded in the SNARE
RT   motif.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 101:3376-3380(2004).
RN   [13]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-110 AND SER-149, AND
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=18407956; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M700468-MCP200;
RA   Albuquerque C.P., Smolka M.B., Payne S.H., Bafna V., Eng J., Zhou H.;
RT   "A multidimensional chromatography technology for in-depth
RT   phosphoproteome analysis.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 7:1389-1396(2008).
RN   [14]
RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-110, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: t-SNARE found in various SNARE complexes involved in
CC       multiple transport pathways. The composition of the t-SNARE
CC       complexes is specific for a limited number of v-SNAREs and
CC       therefore allows only the vesicles carrying the matching v-SNARE
CC       to fuse. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10385523,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11739407, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981247}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms SNARE complexes with the t-SNAREs VAM3 and VAM7,
CC       and the v-SNAREs NYV1 and YKT6 on vacuolar membranes, which are
CC       involved in biosynthetic transport pathways to the vacuole and in
CC       homotypic vacuole fusion. Forms SNARE complexes with the cis-Golgi
CC       t-SNARE SED5 and the v-SNAREs SFT1 and YTK6, which are involved in
CC       retrograde traffic to the cis-Golgi compartment. Forms SNARE
CC       complexes with the t-SNAREs TLG1 and TLG2, and either the v-SNARE
CC       SNC1 or SNC2, which are involved in traffic from early endosomes
CC       to the trans-Golgi network (TGN). Forms SNARE complexes with the
CC       t-SNAREs PEP12 and either SYN8 or TLG1, and the v-SNARE SNC1,
CC       which are involved in traffic from the TGN to the prevacuolar
CC       compartment (PVC). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10385523}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P47160:ENT3; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-20519, EBI-25662;
CC       Q12255:NYV1; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-20519, EBI-35465;
CC       Q12241:VAM3; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-20519, EBI-20227;
CC       P36015:YKT6; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-20519, EBI-26982;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Prevacuolar compartment membrane; Single-
CC       pass type IV membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Single-
CC       pass type IV membrane protein. Note=A small portion is localized
CC       in the Golgi apparatus, the majority is localized in the PVC.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the VTI1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Binds preferentially to the U4/U6 hybrid snRNAs. Can
CC       stimulate the annealing of U4 and U6. Could participate in both
CC       the formation and disassembly of the U4/U6 hybrid during splicing.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P47093:LSM8; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-212, EBI-313;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 672 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic component of DNA polymerase alpha, which in
CC       complex with DNA primase (DNA polymerase alpha:primase)
CC       constitutes a replicative polymerase. POL1 has a role in promoting
CC       telomere replication during interaction with CDC13.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10898792}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Deoxynucleoside triphosphate + DNA(n) =
CC       diphosphate + DNA(n+1).
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=[4Fe-4S] cluster; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:49883;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:22119860};
CC       Note=Binds 1 [4Fe-4S] cluster. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22119860};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: DNA polymerase alpha:primase is a four subunit enzyme
CC       complex, which is assembled throughout the cell cycle, and
CC       consists of the two DNA polymerase subunits A and B, and the DNA
CC       primase large and small subunits. Subunit B binds to subunit A (By
CC       similarity). POL1 interacts with CDC13, POB3, SPT16 and MCM10.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10898792,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16675460, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8621497,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9199353}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P32797:CDC13; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6128, EBI-4187;
CC       Q01454:CTF4; NbExp=14; IntAct=EBI-6128, EBI-5209;
CC       P38121:POL12; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-6128, EBI-6111;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The CysB motif binds 1 4Fe-4S cluster and is required for
CC       the formation of polymerase complexes. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In eukaryotes there are five DNA polymerases:
CC       alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and epsilon which are responsible for
CC       different reactions of DNA synthesis.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1050 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the DNA polymerase type-B family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the anaphase promoting complex/cyclosome
CC       (APC/C), a cell cycle-regulated E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase
CC       complex that controls progression through mitosis and the G1 phase
CC       of the cell cycle. The APC/C is thought to confer substrate
CC       specificity and, in the presence of ubiquitin-conjugating E2
CC       enzymes, it catalyzes the formation of protein-ubiquitin
CC       conjugates that are subsequently degraded by the 26S proteasome.
CC       In early mitosis, the APC/C is activated by CDC20 and targets
CC       securin PDS1, the B-type cyclin CLB5, and other anaphase
CC       inhibitory proteins for proteolysis, thereby triggering the
CC       separation of sister chromatids at the metaphase-to-anaphase
CC       transition. In late mitosis and in G1, degradation of CLB5 allows
CC       activation of the APC/C by CDH1, which is needed to destroy CDC20
CC       and the B-type cyclin CLB2 to allow exit from mitosis and creating
CC       the low CDK state necessary for cytokinesis and for reforming
CC       prereplicative complexes in G1 prior to another round of
CC       replication. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12609981,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8895471}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The APC/C is composed of at least 13 subunits that stay
CC       tightly associated throughout the cell cycle: APC1, APC2, APC4,
CC       APC5, APC9, APC11, CDC16, CDC23, CDC26, CDC27, DOC1, MND2 and
CC       SWM1. APC1 interacts directly with MND2.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12609981, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8895471}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-29017, EBI-29017;
CC       P53068:DOC1; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-29017, EBI-2603;
CC       P40577:MND2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-29017, EBI-25433;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton,
CC       spindle pole {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 178 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the APC1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Guanine nucleotide-exchange factor (GEF) required for
CC       the formation or budding of transport vesicles from the ER. This
CC       function involves the cytoplasmic domain of the protein, which is
CC       thought to interact with the small GTP-binding protein SAR1.
CC       Required for autophagy. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11694599,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12655150, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1327759,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16413259, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1649197,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1907973, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1907974,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1922074, ECO:0000269|PubMed:2512296,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:3047151, ECO:0000269|PubMed:6996832,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7865879, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8106544,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8377826, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8583945,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9023343}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Single-pass
CC       type II membrane protein. Golgi apparatus, cis-Golgi network
CC       membrane; Single-pass type II membrane protein. Note=Cycling
CC       between endoplasmic reticulum and the early Golgi.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In the process of transport, SEC12 itself may
CC       migrate to the Golgi apparatus and function in subsequent
CC       transport events.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6160 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the WD repeat SEC12 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Van Damme P., Lasa M., Polevoda B., Gazquez C., Elosegui-Artola A.,
RA   Kim D.S., De Juan-Pardo E., Demeyer K., Hole K., Larrea E.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the Sec62/63 complex which is
CC       involved in SRP-independent post-translational translocation
CC       across the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and functions together with
CC       the Sec61 complex and KAR2 in a channel-forming translocon
CC       complex. In an initial step, the signal sequence seems to bind
CC       simultaneously to SEC61 and SEC62. SEC62 and SEC63 are required
CC       for interactions between SEC61 and translocating polypeptides.
CC       SEC62 may affect SEC1-polypeptide interactions by increasing the
CC       affinity of targeting pathways for SEC61 and/or by modifying SEC61
CC       to allow more efficient polypeptide interaction. A cycle of
CC       assembly and disassembly of Sec62/63 complex from SEC61 may govern
CC       the activity of the translocon. SEC62 is essential for cell
CC       growth.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the heterotetrameric Sec62/63complex
CC       composed of SEC62, SEC63, SEC71 and SEC72. The Sec62/63 complex
CC       associates with the Sec61 complex to form the Sec complex.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2000150}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P32915:SEC61; NbExp=10; IntAct=EBI-16632, EBI-16400;
CC       P14906:SEC63; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-16632, EBI-16636;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 16500 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SEC62 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAB68205.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAB56541.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May act as a molecular switch during maturation of the
CC       40S ribosomal subunit in the nucleolus. The depletion of BMS1
CC       interferes with processing of the 35S pre-rRNA at sites A0, A1,
CC       and A2, and the formation of 40S subunits.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11565748, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11565749}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associates with RCL1.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q08096:RCL1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-3683, EBI-14892;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11565749}.
CC       Nucleus, nucleolus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11565749}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAFAC class translation factor GTPase
CC       superfamily. Bms1-like GTPase family. BMS1 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   COMPOSITION OF THE COG COMPLEX, AND INTERACTION WITH COG1; COG2; COG5
RP   AND COG7.
RX   PubMed=15047703; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M400662200;
RA   Loh E., Hong W.;
RT   "The binary interacting network of the conserved oligomeric Golgi
RT   tethering complex.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 279:24640-24648(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as essential component of the peripheral membrane
CC       COG complex that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking.
CC       COG is located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of
CC       retrograde intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other
CC       membrane trafficking events. COG4 is required for normal
CC       endoplasmic reticulum function and is also involved in calcium
CC       regulation. Possesses ATPase activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006647, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12011112,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12058017}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11733049, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12006647,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12011112}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53079:COG1; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-4823, EBI-4835;
CC       P53271:COG2; NbExp=15; IntAct=EBI-4823, EBI-16614;
CC       P40094:COG3; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-4823, EBI-16605;
CC       P53951:COG5; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-4823, EBI-4841;
CC       P53195:COG7; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4823, EBI-4847;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12058017}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12058017}. Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12058017}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12058017}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1620 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the COG4 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in pre-rRNA processing. Required for
CC       maintaining steady-state levels of 40S ribosomal subunit. Required
CC       for the initial processing of pre-rRNA at the A0 to A2 sites,
CC       leading to the processing of the 23S pre-rRNA intermediate to the
CC       18S rRNA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11884397}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with NOP1. Binds to the 35S pre-rRNA and the U3
CC       snoRNA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11884397}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53254:UTP22; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-34383, EBI-1878;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11884397}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2220 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RRM MRD1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=20375281; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1000063107;
RA   Lynch-Day M.A., Bhandari D., Menon S., Huang J., Cai H.,
RA   Bartholomew C.R., Brumell J.H., Ferro-Novick S., Klionsky D.J.;
RT   "Trs85 directs a Ypt1 GEF, TRAPPIII, to the phagophore to promote
RT   autophagy.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 107:7811-7816(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the TRAPP I, TRAPP II and TRAPP III
CC       complexes which act as guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEF)
CC       for YPT1. TRAPP I plays a key role in the late stages of
CC       endoplasmic reticulum to Golgi traffic. TRAPP II plays a role in
CC       intra-Golgi transport. TRAPP III plays a role in autophagosome
CC       formation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239471,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20972447}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Part of the multisubunit TRAPP (transport protein
CC       particle) I complex composed of BET3, BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31
CC       and TRS33. Part of the multisubunit TRAPP (transport protein
CC       particle) II complex composed of BET3, BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31,
CC       TRS33, TRS65, TRS85, TRS120 and TRS130. Part of the multisubunit
CC       TRAPP (transport protein particle) III complex composed of BET3,
CC       BET5, TRS20, TRS23, TRS31, TRS33 and TRS85.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11239471, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11805826,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20972447,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9564032}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P36149:BET3; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-19474, EBI-3567;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus, cis-Golgi network.
CC       Endoplasmic reticulum. Preautophagosomal structure.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3130 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TRAPP small subunits family. TRAPPC4
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [25]
RP   FUNCTION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=20375281; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1000063107;
RA   Lynch-Day M.A., Bhandari D., Menon S., Huang J., Cai H.,
RA   Bartholomew C.R., Brumell J.H., Ferro-Novick S., Klionsky D.J.;
RT   "Trs85 directs a Ypt1 GEF, TRAPPIII, to the phagophore to promote
RT   autophagy.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 107:7811-7816(2010).
RN   [26]
RP   UBIQUITINATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT LYS-144, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22106047; DOI=10.1002/pmic.201100166;
RA   Starita L.M., Lo R.S., Eng J.K., von Haller P.D., Fields S.;
RT   "Sites of ubiquitin attachment in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   Proteomics 12:236-240(2012).
RN   [27]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.5 ANGSTROMS) IN COMPLEX WITH GDI1.
RX   PubMed=14576435; DOI=10.1126/science.1087761;
RA   Rak A., Pylypenko O., Durek T., Watzke A., Kushnir S., Brunsveld L.,
RA   Waldmann H., Goody R.S., Alexandrov K.;
RT   "Structure of Rab GDP-dissociation inhibitor in complex with
RT   prenylated YPT1 GTPase.";
RL   Science 302:646-650(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The small GTPases Rab are key regulators of
CC       intracellular membrane trafficking, from the formation of
CC       transport vesicles to their fusion with membranes. Rabs cycle
CC       between an inactive GDP-bound form and an active GTP-bound form
CC       that is able to recruit to membranes different set of downstream
CC       effectors directly responsible for vesicle formation, movement,
CC       tethering and fusion. YPT1 regulates the trafficking of secretory
CC       vesicles from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to the Golgi.
CC       Vesicular transport depends on shuttling of YPT1 between membrane
CC       and cytosol by GDI1, probably by recycling it to its membrane of
CC       origin after a vesicle fusion event. Plays a role in the initial
CC       events of the autophagic vacuole development which take place at
CC       specialized regions of the endoplasmic reticulum. Also involved in
CC       the recycling of membrane proteins. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10071213,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11879636, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12189143,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12802060, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15082776,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Rab activation is generally mediated by a
CC       guanine exchange factor (GEF), while inactivation through
CC       hydrolysis of bound GTP is catalyzed by a GTPase activating
CC       protein (GAP). YPT1 is activated by the GEFs DSS4 and TRAPP
CC       complex, and inactivated by GAPs GYP1, GYP5 and GYP8.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11102533, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11359917,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12189143, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9819430}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a complex with the Rab escort protein (REP) MRS6,
CC       which is recognized by Rab geranylgeranyltransferase BET2-BET4.
CC       Interacts with the Rab GDP dissociation inhibitor GDI1, which can
CC       retrieve from and deliver to membranes the GDP-bound and
CC       prenylated form of YPT1. Interacts with YIP1, which is required
CC       for proper membrane targeting of prenylated YPT1. Interacts with
CC       YIF1, YIP3, YIP4 and YIP5. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11785952,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11943201, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12802060,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576435, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8898359}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P39958:GDI1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-29496, EBI-7517;
CC       P22214:SEC22; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-29496, EBI-16577;
CC       Q01590:SED5; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-29496, EBI-16930;
CC       P53845:YIF1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-29496, EBI-28230;
CC       P53633:YIP3; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-29496, EBI-25301;
CC       P53093:YIP4; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-29496, EBI-24124;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12802060}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12802060}. Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12802060}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12802060}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12802060}. Preautophagosomal structure
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20375281}; Lipid-anchor
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000305}. Note=ER and Golgi
CC       when GTP-bound. Cytoplasmic when bound to GDI1.
CC   -!- PTM: Prenylation is required for interaction with GDI1 and YIP1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10071213}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the small GTPase superfamily. Rab family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: In PubMed:3042385 the location of any palmitoylation was
CC       not determined. Mutagenesis of either Cys-205 or Cys-206 would
CC       disrupt normal geranylgeranylation, and there would be no primary
CC       membrane association for secondary S-palmitoylation to occur at
CC       some other position, for example Cys-23. Mutagenesis of both Cys-
CC       205 and Cys-206 is lethal, so protein production could not have
CC       been observed. {ECO:0000305}.

RT   "N-terminal acetylome analyses and functional insights of the N-
RT   terminal acetyltransferase NatB.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:12449-12454(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The coatomer is a cytosolic protein complex that binds
CC       to dilysine motifs and reversibly associates with Golgi non-
CC       clathrin-coated vesicles, which further mediate biosynthetic
CC       protein transport from the ER, via the Golgi up to the trans Golgi
CC       network. Coatomer complex is required for budding from Golgi
CC       membranes, and is essential for the retrograde Golgi-to-ER
CC       transport of dilysine-tagged proteins.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Oligomeric complex that consists of at least the alpha,
CC       beta, beta', gamma, delta, epsilon and zeta subunits. Interacts
CC       with the ESCRT-0 subunit VPS27. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53622:COP1; NbExp=18; IntAct=EBI-4898, EBI-4860;
CC       P02829:HSP82; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4898, EBI-8659;
CC       P40509:SEC28; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-4898, EBI-4884;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Golgi apparatus
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250};
CC       Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, COPI-coated
CC       vesicle membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Note=The coatomer
CC       is cytoplasmic or polymerized on the cytoplasmic side of the
CC       Golgi, as well as on the vesicles/buds originating from it.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 129000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the WD repeat COPB2 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes C14-demethylation of lanosterol which is
CC       critical for ergosterol biosynthesis. It transforms lanosterol
CC       into 4,4'-dimethyl cholesta-8,14,24-triene-3-beta-ol.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: A 14-alpha-methylsteroid + 3 O(2) + 3 NADPH =
CC       a Delta(14)-steroid + formate + 3 NADP(+) + 4 H(2)O.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=heme; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:30413; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Steroid biosynthesis; zymosterol biosynthesis; zymosterol
CC       from lanosterol: step 1/6.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with ERG28. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15995173}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53045:ERG25; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-5127, EBI-6506;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Single-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: It is the main target for antifungal compounds of
CC       the triazole family like ketoconazole which inhibits by
CC       coordinating the iron atom at the sixth ligand position.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 73200 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cytochrome P450 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE SPOTS COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=20182505; DOI=10.1038/nature08787;
RA   Breslow D.K., Collins S.R., Bodenmiller B., Aebersold R., Simons K.,
RA   Shevchenko A., Ejsing C.S., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Orm family proteins mediate sphingolipid homeostasis.";
RL   Nature 463:1048-1053(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of serine palmitoyltransferase (SPT), which
CC       catalyzes the committed step in the synthesis of sphingolipids,
CC       the condensation of serine with palmitoyl CoA to form the long
CC       chain base 3-ketosphinganine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11781309,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8058731}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Palmitoyl-CoA + L-serine = CoA + 3-dehydro-D-
CC       sphinganine + CO(2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10713067,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11781309, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15485854,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8058731}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=pyridoxal 5'-phosphate; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:597326;
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Lipid metabolism; sphingolipid metabolism.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: LCB1 and LCB2 encode essential subunits of the enzyme and
CC       form a heterodimer. Component of the SPOTS complex, at least
CC       composed of LCB1/2 (LCB1 and/or LCB2), ORM1/2 (ORM1 and/or ORM2),
CC       SAC1 and TSC3. Interacts with LCB2 and TSC3.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10713067, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11781309,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15485854, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20182505,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8058731}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P40970:LCB2; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-10059, EBI-10067;
CC       P53224:ORM1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-10059, EBI-12592;
CC       Q06144:ORM2; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-10059, EBI-34916;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane;
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The first transmembrane domain is not required for
CC       stability, membrane association, interaction with LCB2, or
CC       enzymatic activity. The second and third transmembrane domains are
CC       required for stability and interaction with LCB2.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 22400 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the class-II pyridoxal-phosphate-dependent
CC       aminotransferase family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [9]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22814378; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1210303109;
RA   Van Damme P., Lasa M., Polevoda B., Gazquez C., Elosegui-Artola A.,
RA   Kim D.S., De Juan-Pardo E., Demeyer K., Hole K., Larrea E.,
RA   Timmerman E., Prieto J., Arnesen T., Sherman F., Gevaert K.,
RA   Aldabe R.;
RT   "N-terminal acetylome analyses and functional insights of the N-
RT   terminal acetyltransferase NatB.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 109:12449-12454(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Signal-recognition-particle (SRP) assembly has a crucial
CC       role in targeting secretory proteins to the rough endoplasmic
CC       reticulum (ER) membrane. SRP is required for the cotranslational
CC       protein translocation for ER import and preferentially recognizes
CC       strongly hydrophobic signal sequences. It is involved in targeting
CC       the nascent chain-ribosome (RNC) complex to the ER and is proposed
CC       to participate in the arrest of nascent chain elongation during
CC       membrane targeting. SRP54 binds to the signal sequence of
CC       presecretory protein when they emerge from the ribosomes. SRP54
CC       interacts with the scR1 RNA and mediates the association of the
CC       resulting SRP-RNC complex with the signal recognition particle
CC       receptor (SR) via its alpha subunit SRP101. Both, SRP54 and
CC       SRP101, are locked in their GTP bound forms in the SRP-RNC-SR
CC       complex, which dissociates upon transferring the signal sequence
CC       to the protein-conducting channel (translocon). After signal
CC       sequence transfer, SRP54 and SRP101 act as reciprocal GTPAse-
CC       activating proteins (GAPs), thereby resolving their association.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10676815, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8805251}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Fungal signal recognition particle (SRP) complex consists
CC       of a 7S RNA molecule (scR1) and at least six protein subunits:
CC       SRP72, SRP68, SRP54, SEC65, SRP21 and SRP14. SRP54 interacts with
CC       SRP101. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7925282}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Has a two domain structure: the G-domain binds GTP; the M-
CC       domain binds the 7S RNA and also binds the signal sequence.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GTP-binding SRP family. SRP54
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: May be responsible for the transport of FAD into the
CC       endoplasmic reticulum lumen, where it is required for oxidative
CC       protein folding. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16717099}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16717099}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16717099}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 414 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor potential (TRP) ion
CC       channel family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Transcription factor that controls part of the HOG1-
CC       mediated osmostress responses. Binds to the DNA sequence 5'-
CC       ACTACTA[TA](4)TAG-3'. Does not appear to function in the MPK1
CC       pathway. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12482976}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Can heterodimerize with RLM1. Interacts with HOG1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12482976}.

CC       ProRule:PRU00251}.

RX   PubMed=25609543; DOI=10.1038/ncomms7019;
RA   Pfeffer S., Woellhaf M.W., Herrmann J.M., Forster F.;

RN   [11]
RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (3.20 ANGSTROMS), AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=24675956; DOI=10.1126/science.1249410;
RA   Amunts A., Brown A., Bai X.C., Llacer J.L., Hussain T., Emsley P.,
RA   Long F., Murshudov G., Scheres S.H., Ramakrishnan V.;
RT   "Structure of the yeast mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit.";
RL   Science 343:1485-1489(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the mitochondrial ribosome (mitoribosome),
CC       a dedicated translation machinery responsible for the synthesis of
CC       mitochondrial genome-encoded proteins, including at least some of
CC       the essential transmembrane subunits of the mitochondrial
CC       respiratory chain. The mitoribosomes are attached to the
CC       mitochondrial inner membrane and translation products are
CC       cotranslationally integrated into the membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:24675956, ECO:0000305|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit
CC       (mt-LSU). Mature yeast 74S mitochondrial ribosomes consist of a
CC       small (37S) and a large (54S) subunit. The 37S small subunit
CC       contains a 15S ribosomal RNA (15S mt-rRNA) and 34 different
CC       proteins. The 54S large subunit contains a 21S rRNA (21S mt-rRNA)
CC       and 46 different proteins. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12392552,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2060626, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24675956}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278}. Note=Mitoribosomes are tethered to
CC       the mitochondrial inner membrane and spatially aligned with the
CC       membrane insertion machinery through two distinct membrane contact
CC       sites, formed by the 21S rRNA expansion segment 96-ES1 and the
CC       inner membrane protein MBA1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2250 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the mitochondrion-specific ribosomal
CC       protein mL41 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: This small integral protein plays a role in holoenzyme
CC       assembly or stability.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 4 ferrocytochrome c + O(2) + 4 H(+) = 4
CC       ferricytochrome c + 2 H(2)O.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Cytochrome c oxidase is composed of 11 subunits: one copy
CC       each of COX1, COX2, COX3, COX4, COX5A or COX5B, COX6, COX7, COX9,
CC       COX12, COX13 and two copies of COX8.

RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   STRAIN=ATCC 76625 / YPH499;
RX   PubMed=14576278; DOI=10.1073/pnas.2135385100;
RA   Sickmann A., Reinders J., Wagner Y., Joppich C., Zahedi R.P.,

RT   "The proteome of Saccharomyces cerevisiae mitochondria.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 100:13207-13212(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: mRNA-specific translational activator of cytochrome b.
CC       The cytochrome b (COB) leader RNA may represent the target
CC       sequence for CBS1 and CBS2, tethering the COB mRNA to the inner
CC       mitochondrial membrane, where cotranslational insertion of
CC       cytochrome b into the membrane can occur.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1745228};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1745228}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 556 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: CBS1 protein devoid of mitochondrial targeting
CC       sequences can enter mitochondria in vivo, possibly due to a bypass
CC       of the mitochondrial import system.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The in vitro imported CBS1 protein is functional
CC       and soluble indicating that the N-terminal part of CBS1 confers
CC       some binding to mitochondrial membranes.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:

RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (3.20 ANGSTROMS), AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=24675956; DOI=10.1126/science.1249410;
RA   Amunts A., Brown A., Bai X.C., Llacer J.L., Hussain T., Emsley P.,
RA   Long F., Murshudov G., Scheres S.H., Ramakrishnan V.;
RT   "Structure of the yeast mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit.";
RL   Science 343:1485-1489(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the mitochondrial ribosome (mitoribosome),
CC       a dedicated translation machinery responsible for the synthesis of
CC       mitochondrial genome-encoded proteins, including at least some of
CC       the essential transmembrane subunits of the mitochondrial
CC       respiratory chain. The mitoribosomes are attached to the
CC       mitochondrial inner membrane and translation products are
CC       cotranslationally integrated into the membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:24675956, ECO:0000305|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit
CC       (mt-LSU). Mature yeast 74S mitochondrial ribosomes consist of a
CC       small (37S) and a large (54S) subunit. The 37S small subunit
CC       contains a 15S ribosomal RNA (15S mt-rRNA) and 34 different
CC       proteins. The 54S large subunit contains a 21S rRNA (21S mt-rRNA)
CC       and 46 different proteins. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24675956}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Note=Mitoribosomes are tethered to the mitochondrial inner
CC       membrane and spatially aligned with the membrane insertion
CC       machinery through two distinct membrane contact sites, formed by
CC       the 21S rRNA expansion segment 96-ES1 and the inner membrane
CC       protein MBA1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 200 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the bacterial ribosomal protein bL34
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in retrograde transport from early and late
CC       endosomes to late Golgi by linking the vesicle through the t-SNARE
CC       TGL1 to the Golgi, leading to the membrane fusion between late
CC       Golgi and endosomal vesicles. May also be involved in the actin
CC       cytoskeleton organization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10637310,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12446664, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12686613,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:2656401}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Golgi-associated retrograde protein
CC       (GARP) complex, also called VFT (VPS fifty-three) complex,
CC       composed of VPS51, VPS52, VPS53 and VPS54. Interacts also with
CC       TLG1 and YPT6. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10637310,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12446664, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12686613}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P36116:VPS51; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-16418, EBI-26352;
CC       P47061:VPS53; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-16418, EBI-25828;
CC       Q12071:VPS54; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-16418, EBI-36751;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus, trans-Golgi network
CC       membrane; Peripheral membrane protein. Endosome membrane;
CC       Peripheral membrane protein. Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 3130 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the VPS52 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Pfeffer S., Woellhaf M.W., Herrmann J.M., Forster F.;

RT   situ by cryoelectron tomography.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 6:6019-6019(2015).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mitochondrial inner membrane insertase that mediates the
CC       insertion of both mitochondrion-encoded precursors and nuclear-
CC       encoded proteins from the matrix into the inner membrane. Links
CC       mitoribosomes with the inner membrane (PubMed:22904327). Forms
CC       pores capable of accommodating translocating protein segments
CC       (PubMed:22829595). Essential for the activity and assembly of
CC       cytochrome c oxidase (PubMed:22904327). Plays a central role in
CC       the translocation and export of the N-terminal part of the COX2
CC       protein into the mitochondrial intermembrane space.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20025673, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22829595,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22846909, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904327,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9482871}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with the large ribosome subunit of
CC       mitochondrial ribosome (PubMed:14657017, PubMed:22904327).
CC       Interacts directly with MRP20 (PubMed:14657017). Interacts with
CC       OXA1 (PubMed:25609543). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14657017,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904327, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion inner membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22513091, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9171337}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9171337}. Note=The
CC       availability of nuclear- and mitochondrial-encoded substrates
CC       influences the inner- membrane distribution.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22513091}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Leads to reduced steady-state levels and
CC       activities of the mitochondrial ATP/ADP carrier protein AAC2.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22846909}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6550 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the OXA1/ALB3/YidC family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, AND BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=22904058; DOI=10.1128/AEM.01675-12;
RA   Romagnoli G., Luttik M.A., Koetter P., Pronk J.T., Daran J.M.;

RN   [18]
RP   FUNCTION IN BUTANOL PRODUCTION.
RX   PubMed=23642236; DOI=10.1186/1754-6834-6-68;
RA   Branduardi P., Longo V., Berterame N.M., Rossi G., Porro D.;
RT   "A novel pathway to produce butanol and isobutanol in Saccharomyces
RT   cerevisiae.";
RL   Biotechnol. Biofuels 6:68-68(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Minor of three pyruvate decarboxylases (PDC1, PDC5,
CC       PDC6) implicated in the nonoxidative conversion of pyruvate to
CC       acetaldehyde and carbon dioxide during alcoholic fermentation.
CC       Most of the produced acetaldehyde is subsequently reduced to
CC       ethanol, but some is required for cytosolic acetyl-CoA production
CC       for biosynthetic pathways. The enzyme is also one of five 2-oxo
CC       acid decarboxylases (PDC1, PDC5, PDC6, ARO10, and THI3) able to
CC       decarboxylate more complex 2-oxo acids (alpha-keto-acids) than
CC       pyruvate, which seem mainly involved in amino acid catabolism.
CC       Here the enzyme catalyzes the decarboxylation of amino acids,
CC       which, in a first step, have been transaminated to the
CC       corresponding 2-oxo acids. In a third step, the resulting
CC       aldehydes are reduced to alcohols, collectively referred to as
CC       fusel oils or alcohols. Its preferred substrates are the
CC       transaminated amino acids derived from threonine (2-oxobutanoate),
CC       norvaline (2-oxopentanoate), valine (3-methyl-2-oxobutanoate, also
CC       alpha-keto-isovalerate), isoleucine ((3S)-3-methyl-2-
CC       oxopentanoate, also alpha-keto-beta-methylvalerate), phenylalanine
CC       (phenylpyruvate), and tryptophan (3-(indol-3-yl)pyruvate), whereas
CC       transaminated leucine is no substrate. In a side-reaction the
CC       carbanionic intermediate (or active aldehyde) generated by
CC       decarboxylation or by activation of an aldehyde can react with an
CC       aldehyde via condensation (or carboligation) yielding a 2-hydroxy
CC       ketone, collectively called acyloins. The expression level of this
CC       protein in the presence of fermentable carbon sources is so low
CC       that it cannot compensate for the other two pyruvate
CC       decarboxylases to sustain fermentation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10234824, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10753893,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11141278, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12499363,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12902239, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9341119, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9748245}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Pyruvate = acetaldehyde + CO(2).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1744053}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 3-methyl-2-oxobutanoate = 2-methylpropanal +
CC       CO(2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9748245}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (3S)-3-methyl-2-oxopentanoate = 2-
CC       methylbutanal + CO(2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10753893}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 3-(indol-3-yl)pyruvate = 2-(indol-3-
CC       yl)acetaldehyde + CO(2). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12499363}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Phenylpyruvate = phenylacetaldehyde + CO(2).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12499363}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2-oxobutanoate = 1-propanal + CO(2).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2-oxopentanoate = butanal + CO(2).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23642236}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2 acetaldehyde = acetoin.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11141278, ECO:0000305|PubMed:6383467}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Acetaldehyde + pyruvate = acetoin + CO(2).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11141278, ECO:0000305|PubMed:6383467}.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420; Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 Mg(2+) per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=thiamine diphosphate; Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:58937;
CC         Evidence={ECO:0000250};
CC       Note=Binds 1 thiamine pyrophosphate per subunit. {ECO:0000250};
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=2.9 mM for pyruvate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC         KM=1.0 mM for 2-oxobutanoate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC         KM=1.6 mM for 2-oxopentanoate {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC         Vmax=1.5 umol/min/mg enzyme for pyruvate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC         Vmax=0.5 umol/min/mg enzyme for 2-oxobutanoate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC         Vmax=0.4 umol/min/mg enzyme for 2-oxopentanoate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC         Vmax=31 umol/min/mg enzyme for 3-methyl-2-oxobutanoate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC         Vmax=19 umol/min/mg enzyme for 4-methyl-2-oxopentanoate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC         Vmax=10 umol/min/mg enzyme for 3-methyl-2-oxopentanoate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC         Vmax=51 umol/min/mg enzyme for 4-methylthio-2-oxobutanoate
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22904058};
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Fermentation; ethanol fermentation.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Amino-acid degradation; Ehrlich pathway.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression is very low in the presence of fermentable
CC       carbon sources, but is induced, in contrast to PDC5, by ethanol.
CC   -!- BIOTECHNOLOGY: Fusel oils and acyloins are important flavor and
CC       aroma compounds in yeast-fermented products contributing to the
CC       quality of beverages and food, e.g. fusel oils in whiskey,
CC       contrary to common believe, seem to alleviate hangover. In general
CC       they are desirable at low concentrations, whereas high
CC       concentrations may spoil the product. By adjusting growth
CC       conditions and substrate their production is sought to be
CC       influenced. Due to their broad substrate tolerance pyruvate
CC       decarboxylases are important biocatalysts for chemoenzymatic
CC       syntheses, both by fermentation and in vitro, e.g. in the
CC       production of ephedrine, vitamin E, or phenylethanol (rose
CC       flavor). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9655924}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1525 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TPP enzyme family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=25609543; DOI=10.1038/ncomms7019;
RA   Pfeffer S., Woellhaf M.W., Herrmann J.M., Forster F.;

RN   [11]
RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (3.30 ANGSTROMS), AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=28154081; DOI=10.1126/science.aal2415;
RA   Desai N., Brown A., Amunts A., Ramakrishnan V.;
RT   "The structure of the yeast mitochondrial ribosome.";
RL   Science 355:528-531(2017).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the mitochondrial ribosome (mitoribosome),
CC       a dedicated translation machinery responsible for the synthesis of
CC       mitochondrial genome-encoded proteins, including at least some of
CC       the essential transmembrane subunits of the mitochondrial
CC       respiratory chain. The mitoribosomes are attached to the
CC       mitochondrial inner membrane and translation products are
CC       cotranslationally integrated into the membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:25609543, ECO:0000305|PubMed:28154081}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the mitochondrial small ribosomal subunit
CC       (mt-SSU). Mature yeast 74S mitochondrial ribosomes consist of a
CC       small (37S) and a large (54S) subunit. The 37S small subunit
CC       contains a 15S ribosomal RNA (15S mt-rRNA) and 34 different
CC       proteins. The 54S large subunit contains a 21S rRNA (21S mt-rRNA)
CC       and 46 different proteins. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11278769,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12392552, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28154081}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11278769,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278}.
CC       Note=Mitoribosomes are tethered to the mitochondrial inner
CC       membrane and spatially aligned with the membrane insertion
CC       machinery through two distinct membrane contact sites, formed by
CC       the 21S rRNA expansion segment 96-ES1 and the inner membrane
CC       protein MBA1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the mitochondrion-specific ribosomal
CC       protein mS33 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the COPII coat, that covers ER-derived
CC       vesicles involved in transport from the endoplasmic reticulum to
CC       the Golgi apparatus. COPII acts in the cytoplasm to promote the
CC       transport of secretory, plasma membrane, and vacuolar proteins
CC       from the endoplasmic reticulum to the Golgi complex.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: COPII is composed of at least five proteins: the SEC23/24
CC       complex, the SEC13/31 complex and SAR1. Binds to SED5. Interacts
CC       with GHR1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17261844}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Golgi apparatus
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}. Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 12200 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SEC23/SEC24 family. SEC24 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=25609543; DOI=10.1038/ncomms7019;
RA   Pfeffer S., Woellhaf M.W., Herrmann J.M., Forster F.;
RT   "Organization of the mitochondrial translation machinery studied in
RT   situ by cryoelectron tomography.";
RL   Nat. Commun. 6:6019-6019(2015).
RN   [9]
RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (3.20 ANGSTROMS), AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=24675956; DOI=10.1126/science.1249410;
RA   Amunts A., Brown A., Bai X.C., Llacer J.L., Hussain T., Emsley P.,
RA   Long F., Murshudov G., Scheres S.H., Ramakrishnan V.;
RT   "Structure of the yeast mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit.";
RL   Science 343:1485-1489(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the mitochondrial ribosome (mitoribosome),
CC       a dedicated translation machinery responsible for the synthesis of
CC       mitochondrial genome-encoded proteins, including at least some of
CC       the essential transmembrane subunits of the mitochondrial
CC       respiratory chain. The mitoribosomes are attached to the
CC       mitochondrial inner membrane and translation products are
CC       cotranslationally integrated into the membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:24675956, ECO:0000305|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the mitochondrial large ribosomal subunit
CC       (mt-LSU). Mature yeast 74S mitochondrial ribosomes consist of a
CC       small (37S) and a large (54S) subunit. The 37S small subunit
CC       contains a 15S ribosomal RNA (15S mt-rRNA) and 34 different
CC       proteins. The 54S large subunit contains a 21S rRNA (21S mt-rRNA)
CC       and 46 different proteins. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12392552,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24675956, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9151978}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278}.
CC       Note=Mitoribosomes are tethered to the mitochondrial inner
CC       membrane and spatially aligned with the membrane insertion
CC       machinery through two distinct membrane contact sites, formed by
CC       the 21S rRNA expansion segment 96-ES1 and the inner membrane
CC       protein MBA1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25609543}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 5700 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the universal ribosomal protein uL6 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION OF PROBABLE INITIATION SITE.

RN   [7]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND INTERACTION WITH VPS27.
RX   PubMed=17101773; DOI=10.1128/MCB.00577-06;
RA   Gabriely G., Kama R., Gerst J.E.;
RT   "Involvement of specific COPI subunits in protein sorting from the
RT   late endosome to the vacuole in yeast.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Biol. 27:526-540(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The coatomer is a cytosolic protein complex that binds
CC       to dilysine motifs and reversibly associates with Golgi non-
CC       clathrin-coated vesicles, which further mediate biosynthetic
CC       protein transport from the ER, via the Golgi up to the trans Golgi
CC       network. The coatomer complex is required for budding from Golgi
CC       membranes, and is essential for the retrograde Golgi-to-ER
CC       transport of dilysine-tagged proteins.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9463377}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Oligomeric complex that consists of at least the alpha,
CC       beta, beta', gamma, delta, epsilon and zeta subunits. Interacts
CC       with the ESCRT-0 subunit VPS27. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53622:COP1; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-4884, EBI-4860;

RX   PubMed=21912603; DOI=10.1371/journal.pone.0023696;
RA   Ricarte F., Menjivar R., Chhun S., Soreta T., Oliveira L., Hsueh T.,
RA   Serranilla M., Gharakhanian E.;
RT   "A genome-wide immunodetection screen in S. cerevisiae uncovers novel
RT   genes involved in lysosomal vacuole function and morphology.";
RL   PLoS ONE 6:E23696-E23696(2011).
RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND INTERACTION WITH SND1; PHO88 AND
RP   SEC61.
RX   PubMed=27905431; DOI=10.1038/nature20169;
RA   Aviram N., Ast T., Costa E.A., Arakel E.C., Chuartzman S.G., Jan C.H.,
RA   Hassdenteufel S., Dudek J., Jung M., Schorr S., Zimmermann R.,
RA   Schwappach B., Weissman J.S., Schuldiner M.;
RT   "The SND proteins constitute an alternative targeting route to the
RT   endoplasmic reticulum.";
RL   Nature 540:134-138(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions in the SND pathway, a SRP (signal recognition
CC       particle) and GET (guided entry of tail-anchored proteins)
CC       independent pathway for targeting a broad range of substrate
CC       proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum. SND functions in parallel
CC       to GET in targeting proteins with downstream hydrophobic motifs
CC       (PubMed:27905431). Involved in vacuolar processing and morphology
CC       (PubMed:21912603). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21912603,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27905431}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with SND1, PHO88/SND3 and the translocon
CC       complex subunit SEC61. ENV10/SND2 and PHO88/SND3 form a complex
CC       with the translocon in the endoplasmic reticulum membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27905431}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27905431}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Exhibits cold sensitivity and leads to
CC       internal accumulation of precursor CPY.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21912603}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TMEM208 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       Rule:MF_03191, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9083048}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + 2-methoxy-6-all-
CC       trans-polyprenyl-1,4-benzoquinol = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + 6-
CC       methoxy-3-methyl-2-all-trans-polyprenyl-1,4-benzoquinol.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03191, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14701817,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9083049}.

CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03191, ECO:0000305|PubMed:9083048,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9083049}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Nonessential protein required for the fusion of ER-
CC       derived transport vesicles with the Golgi complex. Can be replaced
CC       by SFT2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10406798}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10406798}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10406798}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Lack of GOT1 is lethal in a strain lacking
CC       SFT2. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10406798}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GOT1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   COMPOSITION OF THE COG COMPLEX, AND INTERACTION WITH COG4.
RX   PubMed=15047703; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M400662200;
RA   Loh E., Hong W.;
RT   "The binary interacting network of the conserved oligomeric Golgi
RT   tethering complex.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 279:24640-24648(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the peripheral membrane COG complex
CC       that is involved in intra-Golgi protein trafficking. COG is
CC       located at the cis-Golgi, and regulates tethering of retrograde
CC       intra-Golgi vesicles and possibly a number of other membrane
CC       trafficking events.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the conserved oligomeric Golgi (COG or
CC       Sec34/Sec35) complex which consists of eight different proteins
CC       COG1-COG8. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11703943}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4841, EBI-4841;
CC       P53079:COG1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-4841, EBI-4835;
CC       P53271:COG2; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4841, EBI-16614;
CC       P40094:COG3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4841, EBI-16605;
CC       Q06096:COG4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-4841, EBI-4823;
CC       P53959:COG6; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-4841, EBI-4829;

CC       Q04632:COG8; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4841, EBI-6035;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 468 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the COG5 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (4.0 ANGSTROMS) OF 80S RIBOSOME.
RX   PubMed=21109664; DOI=10.1126/science.1194294;
RA   Ben-Shem A., Jenner L., Yusupova G., Yusupov M.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the eukaryotic ribosome.";

RN   [21]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.0 ANGSTROMS) OF 80S RIBOSOME, SUBUNIT, AND
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=22096102; DOI=10.1126/science.1212642;
RA   Ben-Shem A., Garreau de Loubresse N., Melnikov S., Jenner L.,
RA   Yusupova G., Yusupov M.;
RT   "The structure of the eukaryotic ribosome at 3.0 A resolution.";
RL   Science 334:1524-1529(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       eL19 may play a role in the last stages of translation initiation,
CC       in particular sububit joining and shedding/releasing factors.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). eL19 lies
CC       in close proximity to the binding site for eukaryotic initiation
CC       factor eIF4G (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102, ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=21573.159; Method=Electrospray; Range=2-
CC       189; Note=Average mass.; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:11983894};
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 97700 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for eL19 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic ribosomal protein eL19
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [18]
RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=24524803; DOI=10.1016/j.sbi.2014.01.002;
RA   Ban N., Beckmann R., Cate J.H.D., Dinman J.D., Dragon F., Ellis S.R.,
RA   Lafontaine D.L.J., Lindahl L., Liljas A., Lipton J.M., McAlear M.A.,
RA   Moore P.B., Noller H.F., Ortega J., Panse V.G., Ramakrishnan V.,
RA   Spahn C.M.T., Steitz T.A., Tchorzewski M., Tollervey D., Warren A.J.,
RA   Williamson J.R., Wilson D., Yonath A., Yusupov M.;
RT   "A new system for naming ribosomal proteins.";
RL   Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 24:165-169(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       eL19 may play a role in the last stages of translation initiation,
CC       in particular sububit joining and shedding/releasing factors.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). eL19 lies
CC       in close proximity to the binding site for eukaryotic initiation
CC       factor eIF4G (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102, ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=21573.159; Method=Electrospray; Range=2-
CC       189; Note=Average mass.; Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:11983894};
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 225000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for eL19 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic ribosomal protein eL19
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA54504.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,

RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in nuclear mRNA splicing. The principal role of
CC       the U1A is to help fold or maintain U1 RNA in an active
CC       configuration. It is the first snRNP to interact with pre-mRNA.
CC       This interaction is required for the subsequent binding of U2
CC       snRNP and the U4/U6/U5 tri-snRNP. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8449403,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8849781}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the spliceosome where it is associated with
CC       snRNP U1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11804584,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9012791}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2950 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RRM U1 A/B'' family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [6]
RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, MUTAGENESIS OF
RP   GLY-180, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=23558746; DOI=10.1093/nar/gkt195;
RA   Sharma S., Watzinger P., Kotter P., Entian K.D.;
RT   "Identification of a novel methyltransferase, Bmt2, responsible for
RT   the N-1-methyl-adenosine base modification of 25S rRNA in
RT   Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   Nucleic Acids Res. 41:5428-5443(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: S-adenosyl-L-methionine-dependent methyltransferase that
CC       specifically methylates the N(1) position of adenine 2142 in 25S
CC       rRNA. N(1)-methyladenine(2142) in 25S rRNA is present in helix 65,
CC       a region that accounts for most of the intersubunit surface of the
CC       large subunit. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03044,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23558746}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + adenine(2142) in 25S
CC       rRNA = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + N(1)-methyladenine(2142) in 25S
CC       rRNA. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03044,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23558746}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03044, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23558746}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Loss of N(1)-methyladenine(2142) in 25S
CC       rRNA. Confers anisomycin and peroxide sensitivity to the cells as
CC       well as slight defects in ribosome subunit joining.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23558746}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 623 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the BMT2 family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03044}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION IN THE SEC62/63 COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=2000150; DOI=10.1038/349806a0;
RA   Deshaies R.J., Sanders S.L., Feldheim D.A., Schekman R.;
RT   "Assembly of yeast Sec proteins involved in translocation into the
