RN   [8]
RP   IDENTIFICATION IN A COMPLEX WITH KAR2; SEC63 AND SEC72.
RX   PubMed=8253836; DOI=10.1083/jcb.123.6.1355;
RA   Brodsky J.L., Schekman R.;
RT   "A Sec63p-BiP complex from yeast is required for protein translocation
RT   in a reconstituted proteoliposome.";
RL   J. Cell Biol. 123:1355-1363(1993).
RN   [9]
RP   ASSOCIATION OF THE SEC62/63 COMPLEX WITH THE SEC61 COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=7758110; DOI=10.1016/0092-8674(95)90077-2;
RA   Panzner S., Dreier L., Hartmann E., Kostka S., Rapoport T.A.;
RT   "Posttranslational protein transport in yeast reconstituted with a
RT   purified complex of Sec proteins and Kar2p.";
RL   Cell 81:561-570(1995).
RN   [10]
RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as component of the Sec62/63 complex which is
CC       involved in SRP-independent post-translational translocation
CC       across the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and functions together with
CC       the Sec61 complex and KAR2 in a channel-forming translocon
CC       complex. A cycle of assembly and disassembly of Sec62/63 complex
CC       from SEC61 may govern the activity of the translocon. SEC66 is
CC       required to attach or retain SEC72 in the SEC63 complex. It is
CC       essential for growth at elevated temperatures.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the heterotetrameric Sec62/63complex
CC       composed of SEC62, SEC63, SEC66 and SEC72. The Sec62/63 complex
CC       associates with the Sec61 complex to form the Sec complex. Part of
CC       a complex consisting of KAR2, SEC63, SEC66 and SEC72.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2000150, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8253836,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8257795}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:

RX   PubMed=19779198; DOI=10.1126/science.1172867;
RA   Holt L.J., Tuch B.B., Villen J., Johnson A.D., Gygi S.P., Morgan D.O.;
RT   "Global analysis of Cdk1 substrate phosphorylation sites provides
RT   insights into evolution.";
RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the HIR complex, which functions as a
CC       histone chaperone that cooperates with ASF1 to promote
CC       replication-independent chromatin assembly. The HIR complex is
CC       also required for the periodic repression of three of the four
CC       histone gene loci during cell cycle as well as for autogenous
CC       regulation of the HTA1-HTB1 locus by H2A and H2B. DNA-binding by
CC       the HIR complex may repress transcription by inhibiting nucleosome
CC       remodeling by the SWI/SNF complex. The HIR complex may also be
CC       required for transcriptional silencing of centromeric, telomeric
CC       and mating-type loci in the absence of CAF-1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12524332, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16264190,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16303565}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the HIR complex, composed of HIR1, HIR2,
CC       HIR3 and HPC2. This complex may consist of one copy of HIR1 and
CC       HIR3 and two copies of HIR2 and HPC2. The HIR complex interacts
CC       with ASF1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16264190,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16303565}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P32479:HIR1; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-8520, EBI-8316;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 238 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the HPC2 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAA34684.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAA85179.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   NOMENCLATURE.
RX   PubMed=24524803; DOI=10.1016/j.sbi.2014.01.002;
RA   Ban N., Beckmann R., Cate J.H.D., Dinman J.D., Dragon F., Ellis S.R.,
RA   Lafontaine D.L.J., Lindahl L., Liljas A., Lipton J.M., McAlear M.A.,
RA   Moore P.B., Noller H.F., Ortega J., Panse V.G., Ramakrishnan V.,
RA   Spahn C.M.T., Steitz T.A., Tchorzewski M., Tollervey D., Warren A.J.,
RA   Williamson J.R., Wilson D., Yonath A., Yusupov M.;
RT   "A new system for naming ribosomal proteins.";
RL   Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 24:165-169(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes)
CC       (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102). The 5 acidic ribosomal P-
CC       proteins form the stalk structure of the 60S subunit. They are
CC       organized as a pentameric complex in which uL10/P0 interacts with
CC       2 heterodimers, P1A-P2B and P1B-P2A (PubMed:16573688,
CC       PubMed:11431471). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11431471,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16573688, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P05317:RPP0; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-15452, EBI-15447;
CC       P02400:RPP2B; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-15452, EBI-15464;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-terminally acetylated by acetyltransferase NatA.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10601260, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8476850}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The 4 small acidic ribosomal P-proteins from yeast
CC       can be classified into two couples of similar but not identical
CC       sequences. Each couple (P1A/P1B and P2A/P2B) is distinctly related
CC       to one of the two acidic ribosomal P-proteins P1/P2 present in
CC       multicellular organisms. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:2404943}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the eukaryotic ribosomal protein P1/P2
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for cytoplasm to vacuole transport (Cvt),
CC       pexophagy and mitophagy. Also involved in endoplasmic reticulum-
CC       specific autophagic process and is essential for the survival of
CC       cells subjected to severe ER stress. Functions in protein
CC       retrieval from the endocytic pathway. Required for proper sorting
CC       of the v-SNARE protein SNC1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12048214,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12554655, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15901835,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16138904, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17132049,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19793921, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20861302}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a complex with SNX4 and ATG17.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P47057:SNX4; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-36894, EBI-17610;
CC       P53039:YIP1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-36894, EBI-25295;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endosome membrane; Peripheral membrane
CC       protein. Preautophagosomal structure membrane; Peripheral membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The PX domain binds phosphatidylinositol 3-phosphate which
CC       is necessary for peripheral membrane localization of ATG20 to the
CC       perivacuolar punctate structures.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 358 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the sorting nexin family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [17]
RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (8.10 ANGSTROMS).
RX   PubMed=23142985; DOI=10.1038/nsmb.2425;
RA   Greber B.J., Boehringer D., Montellese C., Ban N.;
RT   "Cryo-EM structures of Arx1 and maturation factors Rei1 and Jjj1 bound
RT   to the 60S ribosomal subunit.";
RL   Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 19:1228-1233(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). uL29 is
CC       associated with the polypeptide exit tunnel (PubMed:9559554,
CC       PubMed:22096102). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=13769.991; Method=Electrospray; Range=2-
CC       120; Note=Monoisotopic mass.;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:11983894};
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for uL29 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the universal ribosomal protein uL29
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [14]
RP   3D-STRUCTURE MODELING, AND ELECTRON MICROSCOPY.
RX   PubMed=14976550; DOI=10.1038/sj.emboj.7600102;
RA   Spahn C.M.T., Gomez-Lorenzo M.G., Grassucci R.A., Joergensen R.,
RA   Andersen G.R., Beckmann R., Penczek P.A., Ballesta J.P.G., Frank J.;
RT   "Domain movements of elongation factor eEF2 and the eukaryotic 80S
RT   ribosome facilitate tRNA translocation.";
RL   EMBO J. 23:1008-1019(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ribosome, a large ribonucleoprotein
CC       complex responsible for the synthesis of proteins in the cell. The
CC       small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and
CC       translates the encoded message by selecting cognate aminoacyl-
CC       transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The large subunit (LSU) contains
CC       the ribosomal catalytic site termed the peptidyl transferase
CC       center (PTC), which catalyzes the formation of peptide bonds,
CC       thereby polymerizing the amino acids delivered by tRNAs into a
CC       polypeptide chain. The nascent polypeptides leave the ribosome
CC       through a tunnel in the LSU and interact with protein factors that
CC       function in enzymatic processing, targeting, and the membrane
CC       insertion of nascent chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes). uL29 is
CC       associated with the polypeptide exit tunnel (PubMed:9559554,
CC       PubMed:22096102). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MASS SPECTROMETRY: Mass=13769.991; Method=Electrospray; Range=2-
CC       120; Note=Monoisotopic mass.;
CC       Evidence={ECO:0000269|PubMed:11983894};
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 19100 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: There are 2 genes for uL29 in yeast. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the universal ribosomal protein uL29
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Phosphatase catalytic subunit of the trehalose synthase
CC       complex that catalyzes the production of trehalose from glucose-6-
CC       phosphate and UDP-alpha-D-glucose in a two step process.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9194697}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Trehalose 6-phosphate + H(2)O = trehalose +
CC       phosphate.
CC   -!- COFACTOR:
CC       Name=Mg(2+); Xref=ChEBI:CHEBI:18420;
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by EDTA.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=0.2 mM for trehalose 6-phosphate (at pH 6.0)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2546763};
CC         KM=0.5 mM for trehalose 6-phosphate (at pH 7.5)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2546763};
CC         Vmax=20 nmol/min/mg enzyme (at pH 6.0)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2546763};
CC         Vmax=10 nmol/min/mg enzyme (at pH 7.5)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2546763};
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Optimum pH is 6.0. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2546763};
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The trehalose synthase complex is composed of the two
CC       catalytic subunits TPS1 and TPS2, and at least one of the two
CC       regulatory subunits TPS3 or TSL1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9837904}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q00764:TPS1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-19440, EBI-19430;
CC       P38426:TPS3; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-19440, EBI-19448;
CC       P38427:TSL1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-19440, EBI-19638;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By heat shock. Repressed by glucose.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 22700 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the
CC       glycosyltransferase 20 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF
RP   GLY-209.
RX   PubMed=23180764; DOI=10.1093/nar/gks1102;
RA   Peifer C., Sharma S., Watzinger P., Lamberth S., Kotter P.,
RA   Entian K.D.;
RT   "Yeast Rrp8p, a novel methyltransferase responsible for m1A 645 base
RT   modification of 25S rRNA.";
RL   Nucleic Acids Res. 41:1151-1163(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: S-adenosyl-L-methionine-dependent methyltransferase that
CC       specifically methylates the N(1) position of adenine 645 in 25S
CC       rRNA. Required both for ribosomal 40S and 60S subunits biogenesis.
CC       Required for efficient pre-rRNA cleavage at site A2. Also involved
CC       in telomere length regulation and maintenance.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10864042, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15161972,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16552446, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23180764}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + adenine(645) in 25S
CC       rRNA = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + N(1)-methyladenine(645) in 25S
CC       rRNA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23180764}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10864042, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23180764}. Chromosome, telomere {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2780 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the methyltransferase superfamily. RRP8
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The COMPASS (Set1C) complex specifically mono-, di- and
CC       trimethylates histone H3 to form H3K4me1/2/3, which subsequently
CC       activates gene expression by regulating transcription elongation
CC       and plays a role in telomere length maintenance.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11742990, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11805083}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the COMPASS (Set1C) complex which consists
CC       of SET1(2), BRE2(2), SPP1(2), SDC1(1), SHG1(1), SWD1(1), SWD2(1),
CC       and SWD3(1). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11687631,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11742990}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P43132:BRE2; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-38307, EBI-27115;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 937 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the dpy-30 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: RNA polymerase II subunit B1 C-terminal domain (CTD)
CC       phosphatase that dephosphorylates 'Ser-5' of the CTD and regulates
CC       RNA polymerase II during the transition from 'Ser-5' to 'Ser-2'
CC       phosphorylation. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18408053,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19394294}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: [a protein]-serine/threonine phosphate + H(2)O
CC       = [a protein]-serine/threonine + phosphate.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RPO21. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18408053}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Nucleus. Note=Shuttles
CC       constitutively between the cytoplasm and the nucleus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 5480 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RPAP2 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.69 ANGSTROMS) OF 190-233 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   BRE5, FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=17632125; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2007.06.052;
RA   Li K., Ossareh-Nazari B., Liu X., Dargemont C., Marmorstein R.;
RT   "Molecular basis for bre5 cofactor recognition by the ubp3
RT   deubiquitylating enzyme.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 372:194-204(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Has an ATP-independent isopeptidase activity, cleaving
CC       at the C-terminus of the ubiquitin moiety in natural or engineered
CC       linear fusion proteins, irrespective of their size or the presence
CC       of an N-terminal extension to ubiquitin. Plays a role in
CC       regulation of silencing by interacting with SIR4. Also, in
CC       conjunction with BRE5, cleaves ubiquitin, leading to the
CC       subsequent mono-ubiquitination of SEC23.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12778054, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17632125}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Thiol-dependent hydrolysis of ester,
CC       thioester, amide, peptide and isopeptide bonds formed by the C-
CC       terminal Gly of ubiquitin (a 76-residue protein attached to
CC       proteins as an intracellular targeting signal).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17632125}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer with BRE5; contains two molecules of BRE5
CC       and two molecules of UBP3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12778054,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17632125}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53741:BRE5; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-19834, EBI-28528;
CC       P25694:CDC48; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-19834, EBI-4308;
CC       P36037:DOA1; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-19834, EBI-6017;
CC       P32485:HOG1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-19834, EBI-8437;
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2210 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase C19 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Could regulate export of the bud site and axial growth
CC       sites selection protein AXL2 and possibly other secretory proteins
CC       from the endoplasmic reticulum in COPII-coated vesicles. Seems to
CC       be required for axial budding pattern in haploid cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9732282}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein. Note=Resides in the endoplasmic and Golgi compartments,
CC       and then packaged into endoplasmic reticulum derived vesicles.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Defects in cell polarity. Strains homozygous
CC       for ERV14 deletion do not sporulate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9732282}.

RP   FUNCTION, CATALYTIC ACTIVITY, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND DISRUPTION
RP   PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=11867542; DOI=10.1093/emboj/21.5.1139;
RA   Pintard L., Bujnicki J.M., Lapeyre B., Bonnerot C.;
RT   "MRM2 encodes a novel yeast mitochondrial 21S rRNA
RT   methyltransferase.";
RL   EMBO J. 21:1139-1147(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: S-adenosyl-L-methionine-dependent 2'-O-ribose
CC       methyltransferase that catalyzes the formation of 2'-O-
CC       methyluridine at position 2791 (Um2791) in the 21S mitochondrial
CC       large subunit ribosomal RNA (mtLSU rRNA), a universally conserved
CC       modification in the peptidyl transferase domain of the mtLSU rRNA.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11867542}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + uridine(2791) in 21S
CC       rRNA = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + 2'-O-methyluridine(2791) in 21S
CC       rRNA. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11867542}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11867542}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Loses mitochondrial DNA with high frequency.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11867542}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the class I-like SAM-binding
CC       methyltransferase superfamily. RNA methyltransferase RlmE family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [11]
RP   FUNCTION, IDENTIFICATION IN ERMES/MDM COMPLEX, AND SUBCELLULAR
RP   LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=19556461; DOI=10.1126/science.1175088;
RA   Kornmann B., Currie E., Collins S.R., Schuldiner M., Nunnari J.,
RA   Weissman J.S., Walter P.;
RT   "An ER-mitochondria tethering complex revealed by a synthetic biology
RT   screen.";
RL   Science 325:477-481(2009).
RN   [12]
RP   IDENTIFICATION BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=22106047; DOI=10.1002/pmic.201100166;
RA   Starita L.M., Lo R.S., Eng J.K., von Haller P.D., Fields S.;
RT   "Sites of ubiquitin attachment in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   Proteomics 12:236-240(2012).
RN   [13]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=27469264; DOI=10.1038/srep30777;
RA   Kojima R., Endo T., Tamura Y.;
RT   "A phospholipid transfer function of ER-mitochondria encounter
RT   structure revealed in vitro.";
RL   Sci. Rep. 6:30777-30777(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ERMES/MDM complex, which serves as a
CC       molecular tether to connect the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and
CC       mitochondria (PubMed:11907266, PubMed:14981098). Components of
CC       this complex are involved in the control of mitochondrial shape
CC       and protein biogenesis, and function in nonvesicular lipid
CC       trafficking between the ER and mitochondria (PubMed:27469264).
CC       MDM34 is required for the interaction of the ER-resident membrane
CC       protein MMM1 and the outer mitochondrial membrane-resident beta-
CC       barrel protein MDM10 (By similarity) (PubMed:19556461).
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03105, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11907266,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981098, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27469264}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the ER-mitochondria encounter structure
CC       (ERMES) or MDM complex, composed of MMM1, MDM10, MDM12 and MDM34.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03105, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion outer membrane
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03105, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981098, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407407,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16823961, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03105,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14981098,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407407, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16823961,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19556461}. Note=The ERMES/MDM complex localizes
CC       to a few discrete foci (around 10 per single cell), that represent
CC       mitochondria-endoplasmic reticulum junctions. These foci are often
CC       found next to mtDNA nucleoids. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03105}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Lacks alpha-helical transmembrane segments, suggesting
CC       that it resides in the membrane via beta-sheet conformations
CC       similar to those predicted for other outer membrane proteins and
CC       porin. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03105}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The SMP-LTD domain is a barrel-like domain that can bind
CC       various types of glycerophospholipids in its interior and mediate
CC       their transfer between two adjacent bilayers. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03105}.
CC   -!- PTM: Ubiquitinated by a SCF (SKP1-CUL1-F-box protein) E3
CC       ubiquitin-protein ligase complex containing the F-box protein
CC       MDM30. Ubiquitination is important for mitochondrial integrity.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03105, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18775025}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 377 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the MDM34 family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03105}.

RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION, ENZYME ACTIVITY, AND BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES.
RX   PubMed=16709151; DOI=10.1042/BJ20060034;
RA   Garcera A., Barreto L., Piedrafita L., Tamarit J., Herrero E.;
RT   "Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells have three Omega class glutathione S-
RT   transferases acting as 1-Cys thiol transferases.";
RL   Biochem. J. 398:187-196(2006).
RN   [5]
RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND INDUCTION.
RX   PubMed=16936141; DOI=10.1128/EC.00216-06;
RA   Barreto L., Garcera A., Jansson K., Sunnerhagen P., Herrero E.;
RT   "A peroxisomal glutathione transferase of Saccharomyces cerevisiae is
RT   functionally related to sulfur amino acid metabolism.";
RL   Eukaryot. Cell 5:1748-1759(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Active as '1-Cys' thiol transferase against beta-
CC       hydroxyethyl disulfide (HED), as dehydroascorbate reductase and as
CC       dimethylarsinic acid reductase, while not active against the
CC       standard GST substrate 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene (CDNB).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16709151}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: RX + glutathione = HX + R-S-glutathione.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16709151}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: 2 glutathione + dehydroascorbate = glutathione
CC       disulfide + ascorbate. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16709151}.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       Kinetic parameters:
CC         KM=1.13 mM for reduced glutathione (GSH)
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16709151};
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Peroxisome {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16936141}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By diamide and 1-chloro-2,4-dinitrobenzene (CDNB) in a
CC       transcriptional factors YAP1 and/or MSN2/4-dependent manner.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16936141}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Null mutants display increased sensitivity
CC       to cadmium in the absence of GTT1 and GTT2. Null mutants also show
CC       growth defects on oleic acid-based medium, indicative of abnormal
CC       peroxisomal functions and altered expression of genes related to
CC       sulfur amino acid metabolism, and have low levels of reduced
CC       glutathione. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16936141}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GST superfamily. Omega family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as a sulfur carrier required for 2-thiolation of
CC       mcm(5)S(2)U at tRNA wobble positions of cytosolic tRNA(Lys),
CC       tRNA(Glu) and tRNA(Gln). Serves as sulfur donor in tRNA 2-
CC       thiolation reaction by being thiocarboxylated (-COSH) at its C-
CC       terminus by UBA4. The sulfur is then transferred to tRNA to form
CC       2-thiolation of mcm(5)S(2)U. Prior mcm(5) tRNA modification by the
CC       elongator complex is required for 2-thiolation. Also acts as a
CC       ubiquitin-like protein (UBL) that is covalently conjugated via an
CC       isopeptide bond to lysine residues of target proteins such as
CC       AHP1. The thiocarboxylated form serves as substrate for
CC       conjugation and oxidative stress specifically induces the
CC       formation of UBL-protein conjugates. Indirectly involved in
CC       regulation of budding and haploid invasive growth.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10713047, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14551258,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14555475, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18664566,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18755837, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19017811,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19145231, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19151091,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21209336}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: tRNA modification; 5-methoxycarbonylmethyl-2-thiouridine-
CC       tRNA biosynthesis. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03048}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer; homodimerization may provide an autoprotection
CC       to the highly active C-terminal residue before attacking its
CC       substrates. Interacts with NCS2 and NCS6. Forms a conjugate with
CC       the target protein AHP1. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03048,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10713047, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14555475,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19145231, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19151091}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53088:NCS6; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-24940, EBI-24137;
CC       P38820:UBA4; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-24940, EBI-24676;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Nucleus.
CC   -!- PTM: C-terminal thiocarboxylation occurs in 2 steps, it is first
CC       acyl-adenylated (-COAMP) via the hesA/moeB/thiF part of UBA4, then
CC       thiocarboxylated (-COSH) via the rhodanese domain of UBA4.
CC       {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-Rule:MF_03048, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18491921,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19145231, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19151091}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1240 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the URM1 family. {ECO:0000255|HAMAP-
CC       Rule:MF_03048}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in retrograde transport from early and late
CC       endosomes to late Golgi by linking the vesicle through the t-SNARE
CC       TGL1 to the Golgi, leading to the membrane fusion between late
CC       Golgi and endosomal vesicles. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10637310,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12377769,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12446664, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12686613}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the Golgi-associated retrograde protein
CC       (GARP) complex, also called VFT (VPS fifty-three) complex,
CC       composed of VPS51, VPS52, VPS53 and VPS54. Interacts also with
CC       TLG1, YPT6 and ARL1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10637310,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11689439, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12446664,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12620189, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12686613}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38116:ARL1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-25828, EBI-2869;
CC       P39904:VPS52; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-25828, EBI-16418;
CC       Q12071:VPS54; NbExp=9; IntAct=EBI-25828, EBI-36751;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Golgi apparatus, trans-Golgi network
CC       membrane; Peripheral membrane protein. Endosome membrane;
CC       Peripheral membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the VPS53 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for chromosome stability and methionine
CC       prototrophy. It is involved in chromosomal segregation. Binds to a
CC       highly conserved DNA sequence (5'-RTCACRTG-3'), called CDEI, found
CC       in centromeres and in several promoters. DNA-binding activity is
CC       enhanced by MET28. Required as an auxiliary factor for
CC       transcriptional activation of sulfur metabolism together with MET4
CC       and MET28. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1549123,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8665859}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds DNA as a dimer. Associates with MET4 to form a
CC       heteromeric complex which also includes MET28.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9171357}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Mitochondrion {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14576278}. Chromosome,
CC       centromere {ECO:0000269|PubMed:2185892}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6890 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the GSE complex, a GTPase complex required
CC       for intracellular sorting of GAP1 out of the endosome. Component
CC       of the EGO complex, a complex involved in the regulation of
CC       microautophagy. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15989961,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16732272}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the GSE complex composed of GTR1, GTR2,
CC       SLM4, MEH1 and LTV1. Component of the EGO complex, at least
CC       composed of GTR2, SLM4 and MEH1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15989961,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16732272}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q00582:GTR1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-27062, EBI-7954;
CC       P38247:SLM4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-27062, EBI-21507;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15989961}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 2740 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   STRUCTURE BY ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (8.1 ANGSTROMS) OF 77-128 WITHIN THE
RP   60S RIBOSOMAL SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=23142985; DOI=10.1038/nsmb.2425;
RA   Greber B.J., Boehringer D., Montellese C., Ban N.;
RT   "Cryo-EM structures of Arx1 and maturation factors Rei1 and Jjj1 bound
RT   to the 60S ribosomal subunit.";
RL   Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 19:1228-1233(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ubiquitin: Exists either covalently attached to another
CC       protein, or free (unanchored). When covalently bound, it is
CC       conjugated to target proteins via an isopeptide bond either as a
CC       monomer (monoubiquitin), a polymer linked via different Lys
CC       residues of the ubiquitin (polyubiquitin chains) or a linear
CC       polymer linked via the initiator Met of the ubiquitin (linear
CC       polyubiquitin chains). Polyubiquitin chains, when attached to a
CC       target protein, have different functions depending on the Lys
CC       residue of the ubiquitin that is linked: Lys-6-linked may be
CC       involved in DNA repair; Lys-11-linked is involved in ERAD
CC       (endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation) and in cell-cycle
CC       regulation; Lys-29-linked is involved in lysosomal degradation;
CC       Lys-33-linked is involved in kinase modification; Lys-48-linked is
CC       involved in protein degradation via the proteasome; Lys-63-linked
CC       is involved in endocytosis, and DNA-damage responses. Linear
CC       polymer chains formed via attachment by the initiator Met lead to
CC       cell signaling. Ubiquitin is usually conjugated to Lys residues of
CC       target proteins, however, in rare cases, conjugation to Cys or Ser
CC       residues has been observed. When polyubiquitin is free
CC       (unanchored-polyubiquitin), it also has distinct roles, such as in
CC       activation of protein kinases, and in signaling (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: 60S ribosomal protein L40-A: Component of the ribosome,
CC       a large ribonucleoprotein complex responsible for the synthesis of
CC       proteins in the cell. The small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds
CC       messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and translates the encoded message by
CC       selecting cognate aminoacyl-transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The
CC       large subunit (LSU) contains the ribosomal catalytic site termed
CC       the peptidyl transferase center (PTC), which catalyzes the
CC       formation of peptide bonds, thereby polymerizing the amino acids
CC       delivered by tRNAs into a polypeptide chain. The nascent
CC       polypeptides leave the ribosome through a tunnel in the LSU and
CC       interact with protein factors that function in enzymatic
CC       processing, targeting, and the membrane insertion of nascent
CC       chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel (PubMed:22096102). eL40
CC       is essential for translation of a subset of cellular transcripts,
CC       including stress response transcripts, such as DDR2
CC       (PubMed:23169626). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169626,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes)
CC       (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Ubiquitin: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: 60S ribosomal protein L40-A: Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Ubiquitin is encoded by several different genes.
CC       UBI1 and UBI2 genes code for a single copy of ubiquitin fused to
CC       the ribosomal proteins eL40. UBI3 is a polyprotein with one copy
CC       of ubiquitin fused to ribosomal protein eS31. UBI4 is a
CC       polyprotein containing 5 exact head to tail repeats of ubiquitin.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:3038523}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The 60S ribosomal protein L40 is present with 40000
CC       molecules/cell in log phase SD medium.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the ubiquitin
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the C-terminal section; belongs to the eukaryotic
CC       ribosomal protein eL40 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Moore P.B., Noller H.F., Ortega J., Panse V.G., Ramakrishnan V.,
RA   Spahn C.M.T., Steitz T.A., Tchorzewski M., Tollervey D., Warren A.J.,
RA   Williamson J.R., Wilson D., Yonath A., Yusupov M.;
RT   "A new system for naming ribosomal proteins.";
RL   Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 24:165-169(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ubiquitin: Exists either covalently attached to another
CC       protein, or free (unanchored). When covalently bound, it is
CC       conjugated to target proteins via an isopeptide bond either as a
CC       monomer (monoubiquitin), a polymer linked via different Lys
CC       residues of the ubiquitin (polyubiquitin chains) or a linear
CC       polymer linked via the initiator Met of the ubiquitin (linear
CC       polyubiquitin chains). Polyubiquitin chains, when attached to a
CC       target protein, have different functions depending on the Lys
CC       residue of the ubiquitin that is linked: Lys-6-linked may be
CC       involved in DNA repair; Lys-11-linked is involved in ERAD
CC       (endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation) and in cell-cycle
CC       regulation; Lys-29-linked is involved in lysosomal degradation;
CC       Lys-33-linked is involved in kinase modification; Lys-48-linked is
CC       involved in protein degradation via the proteasome; Lys-63-linked
CC       is involved in endocytosis, and DNA-damage responses. Linear
CC       polymer chains formed via attachment by the initiator Met lead to
CC       cell signaling. Ubiquitin is usually conjugated to Lys residues of
CC       target proteins, however, in rare cases, conjugation to Cys or Ser
CC       residues has been observed. When polyubiquitin is free
CC       (unanchored-polyubiquitin), it also has distinct roles, such as in
CC       activation of protein kinases, and in signaling (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: 60S ribosomal protein L40-B: Component of the ribosome,
CC       a large ribonucleoprotein complex responsible for the synthesis of
CC       proteins in the cell. The small ribosomal subunit (SSU) binds
CC       messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and translates the encoded message by
CC       selecting cognate aminoacyl-transfer RNA (tRNA) molecules. The
CC       large subunit (LSU) contains the ribosomal catalytic site termed
CC       the peptidyl transferase center (PTC), which catalyzes the
CC       formation of peptide bonds, thereby polymerizing the amino acids
CC       delivered by tRNAs into a polypeptide chain. The nascent
CC       polypeptides leave the ribosome through a tunnel in the LSU and
CC       interact with protein factors that function in enzymatic
CC       processing, targeting, and the membrane insertion of nascent
CC       chains at the exit of the ribosomal tunnel (PubMed:22096102). eL40
CC       is essential for translation of a subset of cellular transcripts,
CC       including stress response transcripts, such as DDR2
CC       (PubMed:23169626). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:23169626,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the large ribosomal subunit (LSU). Mature
CC       yeast ribosomes consist of a small (40S) and a large (60S)
CC       subunit. The 40S small subunit contains 1 molecule of ribosomal
CC       RNA (18S rRNA) and 33 different proteins (encoded by 57 genes).
CC       The large 60S subunit contains 3 rRNA molecules (25S, 5.8S and 5S
CC       rRNA) and 46 different proteins (encoded by 81 genes)
CC       (PubMed:9559554, PubMed:22096102). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102,
CC       ECO:0000305|PubMed:9559554}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Ubiquitin: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Nucleus
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: 60S ribosomal protein L40-B: Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22096102}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Ubiquitin is encoded by several different genes.
CC       UBI1 and UBI2 genes code for a single copy of ubiquitin fused to
CC       the ribosomal proteins eL40. UBI3 is a polyprotein with one copy
CC       of ubiquitin fused to ribosomal protein eS31. UBI4 is a
CC       polyprotein containing 5 exact head to tail repeats of ubiquitin.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:3038523}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The 60S ribosomal protein L40 is present with 40000
CC       molecules/cell in log phase SD medium.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the ubiquitin
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the C-terminal section; belongs to the eukaryotic
CC       ribosomal protein eL40 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for acetylation of 'Lys-56' of histone H3
CC       (H3K56ac) which occurs in S phase and disappears during G(2)/M
CC       phase of the cell cycle and is involved in transcription DNA
CC       repair process. H3K56 acetylation weakens of the interaction
CC       between the histone core and the surrounding DNA in the
CC       nucleosomal particle and drives chromatin disassembly. Involved in
CC       regulation of Ty1 transposition. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11779788,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17046836, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17272722,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17272723, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17320445,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17369253, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17690098,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18577595, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18723682}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Acetyl-CoA + [protein]-L-lysine = CoA +
CC       [protein]-N(6)-acetyl-L-lysine.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with ASF1 and VPS75.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17272723, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17320445,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17369253, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17690098,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18723682}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P25293:NAP1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-2887026, EBI-11850;
CC       P53853:VPS75; NbExp=20; IntAct=EBI-2887026, EBI-29225;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15282802}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Expression peaks in cell cycle G1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15282802}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1140 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the RTT109 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable sterol 3-beta-glucosyltransferase that is not
CC       involved in cytoplasm to vacuole transport (Cvt), pexophagy or
CC       nonselective autophagy (PubMed:17012830).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17012830}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: UDP-glucose + a sterol = UDP + a sterol 3-
CC       beta-D-glucoside. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC       Membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}; Peripheral membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 396 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glycosyltransferase 28 family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the pathway that organizes the shaping and
CC       sizing of the prospore membrane (PSM) during sporulation. May be
CC       required to stabilize the outer plaque of the spindle pole body
CC       (SPB). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12796288}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with CNM67, SPO21/MPC70 and NUD1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12796288}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton, microtubule
CC       organizing center, spindle pole body
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12796288}. Note=Localizes to the meiotic outer
CC       plaque of the SPB, at the end of the meiotic spindles.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Meiosis-specific.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12796288}.

RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,

RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the transfer of endogenously produced octanoic
CC       acid from octanoyl-acyl-carrier-protein onto the lipoyl domains of
CC       lipoate-dependent enzymes. Lipoyl-ACP can also act as a substrate
CC       although octanoyl-ACP is likely to be the physiological substrate
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Octanoyl-[acyl-carrier-protein] + protein =
CC       protein N(6)-(octanoyl)lysine + [acyl-carrier-protein].
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein lipoylation via endogenous
CC       pathway; protein N(6)-(lipoyl)lysine from octanoyl-[acyl-carrier-
CC       protein]: step 1/2.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1200 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In the reaction, the free carboxyl group of
CC       octanoic acid is attached via an amide linkage to the epsilon-
CC       amino group of a specific lysine residue of lipoyl domains of
CC       lipoate-dependent enzymes. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the LipB family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION OF THE FPC COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=16219777; DOI=10.1534/genetics.105.046128;
RA   Redon C., Pilch D.R., Bonner W.M.;
RT   "Genetic analysis of Saccharomyces cerevisiae H2A serine 129 mutant

RL   Genetics 172:67-76(2006).
RN   [12]
RP   FUNCTION OF THE FPC COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=16418273; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0506540103;
RA   Mohanty B.K., Bairwa N.K., Bastia D.;
RT   "The Tof1p-Csm3p protein complex counteracts the Rrm3p helicase to
RT   control replication termination of Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 103:897-902(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Forms a fork protection complex (FPC) with TOF1 which is
CC       required for chromosome segregation during meiosis and DNA damage
CC       repair. FPC coordinates leading and lagging strand synthesis and
CC       moves with the replication fork. FPC stabilizes replication forks
CC       in a configuration that is recognized by replication checkpoint
CC       sensors and protects stalled replication forks against the fork-
CC       releasing activity of RRM3 helicase. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11470404,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14742714, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15282308,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15755447, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16024805,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16219777, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16418273}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the fork protection complex (FPC) consisting
CC       of TOF1 and CSM3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15755447}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53840:TOF1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-28093, EBI-28257;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 358 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CSM3 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalytic component of the ISW2 complex, which acts in
CC       remodeling the chromatin by catalyzing an ATP-dependent alteration
CC       in the structure of nucleosomal DNA. The ISW2 complex is involved
CC       in coordinating transcriptional repression and in inheritance of
CC       telomeric silencing. It is involved in repression of MAT a-
CC       specific genes, INO1, and early meiotic genes during mitotic
CC       growth dependent upon transcription factor UME6 and in a parallel
CC       pathway to the RPD3-SIN3 histone deacetylase complex.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10090725, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11081629,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11238381, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11238944,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11489850, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11533234,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14673157}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the ISW2 complex, which at least consists of
CC       ISW2, ITC1, DLS1 and DPB4. May form a stable subcomplex with ITC1.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10090725, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14673157,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15024052}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P53125:ITC1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-31118, EBI-23967;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00624, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 1520 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SNF2/RAD54 helicase family. ISWI
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Accepts electrons from ETF and reduces ubiquinone.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions in nuclear protein import as nuclear transport
CC       receptor. Serves as receptor for nuclear localization signals
CC       (NLS) in cargo substrates. Thought to mediate docking of the
CC       importin/substrate complex to the nuclear pore complex (NPC)
CC       through binding to nucleoporin and the complex is subsequently
CC       translocated through the pore by an energy requiring, RAN-
CC       dependent mechanism. Required for nuclear import of Ho
CC       endonuclease and RFP1, and involved in rRNA-processing and
CC       assembly or export of 60S ribosomal subunits.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11071906, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12829295,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16507575, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16581791}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with GTP-bound GSP1 and RFP1. Associates with
CC       the nuclear pore complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16581791}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Nucleus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 6300 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the importin beta family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   GENE NAME.
RX   PubMed=14745011; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0308089100;
RA   Wilson M.A., St Amour C.V., Collins J.L., Ringe D., Petsko G.A.;
RT   "The 1.8-A resolution crystal structure of YDR533Cp from Saccharomyces
RT   cerevisiae: a member of the DJ-1/ThiJ/PfpI superfamily.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 101:1531-1536(2004).
RN   [4]
RP   INDUCTION, DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=24706893; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1319221111;
RA   Miller-Fleming L., Antas P., Pais T.F., Smalley J.L., Giorgini F.,
RA   Outeiro T.F.;
RT   "Yeast DJ-1 superfamily members are required for diauxic-shift
RT   reprogramming and cell survival in stationary phase.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 111:7012-7017(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Catalyzes the conversion of methylglyoxal (MG) to D-
CC       lactate in a single glutathione (GSH)-independent step. May play a
CC       role in detoxifying endogenously produced glyoxals. Involved in
CC       protection against reactive oxygen species (ROS) (By similarity).
CC       Important for viability in stationary phase. May negatively
CC       regulate TORC1 in response to nutrient limitation
CC       (PubMed:24706893). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q04432,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24706893}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (R)-lactate = methylglyoxal + H(2)O.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q04432}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q04432}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, P-body
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24706893}. Note=Present in processing bodies
CC       (P-bodies) and stress granule (SG) foci upon glucose starvation
CC       and heat shock. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24706893}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Induced during entry into stationary phase.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24706893}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Results in higher sensitivity to oxidative
CC       stress, reduced thermotolerance, accumulation of higher levels of
CC       reactive oxygen species, and reduced chronological life span.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24706893}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase C56 family. HSP31-like
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION IN CCAN, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=22561346; DOI=10.1038/ncb2493;
RA   Schleiffer A., Maier M., Litos G., Lampert F., Hornung P.,
RA   Mechtler K., Westermann S.;
RT   "CENP-T proteins are conserved centromere receptors of the Ndc80
RT   complex.";
RL   Nat. Cell Biol. 14:604-613(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the kinetochore, a multiprotein complex
CC       that assembles on centromeric DNA and attaches chromosomes to
CC       spindle microtubules, mediating chromosome segregation and sister
CC       chromatid segregation during meiosis and mitosis. Component of the
CC       inner kinetochore constitutive centromere-associated network
CC       (CCAN), which serves as a structural platform for outer
CC       kinetochore assembly. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9862478}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the heterotrimeric kinetochore subcomplex
CC       CTF3, which consists of CTF3, MCM16 and MCM22 (PubMed:11782448).
CC       The CTF3 subcomplex is part of a larger constitutive centromere-
CC       associated network (CCAN) (also known as central kinetochore CTF19
CC       complex in yeast), which is composed of at least AME1, CHL4, CNN1,
CC       CTF3, CTF19, IML3, MCM16, MCM21, MCM22, MHF1, MHF2, MIF2, NKP1,
CC       NKP2, OKP1 and WIP1 (PubMed:12408861, PubMed:22561346). Interacts
CC       with CTF19 (PubMed:11782448). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11782448,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12408861, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22561346}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q02732:CTF19; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-31487, EBI-5199;
CC       Q12748:CTF3; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-31487, EBI-30457;
CC       P47167:MCM22; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-31487, EBI-25691;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus. Chromosome, centromere,
CC       kinetochore. Note=Associated with kinetochores.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 279 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the CENP-H/MCM16 family. {ECO:0000255}.

RL   Science 325:1682-1686(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable ubiquitin ligase protein involved in many
CC       cellular processes, such as transcription regulation, maintenance
CC       of nuclear structure, cell cycle, mRNA export and rRNA maturation.
CC       E3 ubiquitin ligase proteins mediate ubiquitination and subsequent
CC       proteasomal degradation of target proteins. Involved in
CC       transcription regulation by interacting, and probably mediating,
CC       ubiquitination of some subunit of the SAGA complex. Required for
CC       SPT7 ubiquitination. Participates in mRNA export from the nucleus
CC       by regulating the transport of hnRNP proteins. Required for the
CC       shuttling of hnRNP protein NAB2, probably by mediating
CC       ubiquitination of a protein associated with NAB2. Also required
CC       for full induction of the general stress and heat-shock responses.
CC       Involved in 18S rRNA maturation by affecting several early steps
CC       in the rRNA processing pathway. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10395901,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10660055, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10873801,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11238398, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9753545}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: S-ubiquitinyl-[E2 ubiquitin-conjugating
CC       enzyme]-L-cysteine + [acceptor protein]-L-lysine = [E2 ubiquitin-
CC       conjugating enzyme]-L-cysteine + N(6)-ubiquitinyl-[acceptor
CC       protein]-L-lysine.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with the ADA3/NGG1 subunit of the SAGA complex.
CC       Interacts with KRR1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11027267,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9753545}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nucleolus
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10873801, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562095}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 350 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the UPL family. TOM1/PTR1 subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Functions as a component of the nuclear pore complex
CC       (NPC). NPC components, collectively referred to as nucleoporins
CC       (NUPs), can play the role of both NPC structural components and of
CC       docking or interaction partners for transiently associated nuclear
CC       transport factors. NUP84 is involved in nuclear poly(A)+ RNA
CC       export, in NPC assembly and distribution, as well as in nuclear
CC       envelope organization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11823431,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8565072}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The nuclear pore complex (NPC) constitutes the exclusive
CC       means of nucleocytoplasmic transport. NPCs allow the passive
CC       diffusion of ions and small molecules and the active, nuclear
CC       transport receptor-mediated bidirectional transport of
CC       macromolecules such as proteins, RNAs, ribonucleoparticles (RNPs),
CC       and ribosomal subunits across the nuclear envelope. The 55-60 MDa
CC       NPC is composed of at least 31 different subunits: ASM4, CDC31,
CC       GLE1, GLE2, NDC1, NIC96, NSP1, NUP1, NUP2, NUP100, NUP116, NUP120,
CC       NUP133, NUP145, NUP157, NUP159, NUP170, NUP188, NUP192, NUP42,
CC       NUP49, NUP53, NUP57, NUP60, NUP82, NUP84, NUP85, POM152, POM34,
CC       SEC13 and SEH1. Due to its 8-fold rotational symmetry, all
CC       subunits are present with 8 copies or multiples thereof. NUP84 is
CC       part of the heptameric 0.5 MDa autoassembling NUP84 NPC subcomplex
CC       (NUP84, NUP85, NUP120, NUP133, NUP145C, SEC13 and SEH1).
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-12337, EBI-12337;
CC       Q02629:NUP100; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-12337, EBI-11698;
CC       P35729:NUP120; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-12337, EBI-11713;
CC       P49687:NUP145; NbExp=17; IntAct=EBI-12337, EBI-11730;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus, nuclear pore complex. Nucleus
CC       membrane; Peripheral membrane protein; Cytoplasmic side. Nucleus
CC       membrane; Peripheral membrane protein; Nucleoplasmic side.
CC       Note=Symmetric distribution.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 8580 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the Nup84/Nup107 nucleoporin family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for MUC2 post-transcriptional synthesis and
CC       secretion. May play a role in the production of mucus by
CC       intestinal cells (By similarity). Proto-oncogene that may play a
CC       role in cell migration, cell differentiation and cell growth.
CC       Promotes cell adhesion (PubMed:23274113). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18199544, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23274113}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Monomer and homodimer (PubMed:23274113). Interacts with
CC       LYPD3 and DAG1 (alphaDAG1). Interacts with MUC2; disulfide-linked.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12592373, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19359471,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23274113}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q8NEC5:CATSPER1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-712648, EBI-744545;
CC       P12104:FABP2; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-712648, EBI-3905109;
CC       Q15323:KRT31; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-712648, EBI-948001;
CC       Q02817:MUC2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-712648, EBI-2105803;
CC       Q9H1M0:NUP62CL; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-712648, EBI-751933;
CC       Q96HA1:POM121; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-712648, EBI-739990;
CC       Q9UMX0:UBQLN1; NbExp=7; IntAct=EBI-712648, EBI-741480;
CC       Q9UMX0-2:UBQLN1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-712648, EBI-10173939;
CC       Q9UHD9:UBQLN2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-712648, EBI-947187;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Secreted {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15834940}.
CC       Endoplasmic reticulum {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed strongly in trachea, lung, stomach,
CC       colon, prostate and small intestine. Expressed weakly in pituitary
CC       gland, salivary gland, mammary gland, bladder, appendix, ovary,
CC       fetal lung, uterus, pancreas, kidney, fetal kidney, testis,
CC       placenta, thyroid gland and in estrogen receptor (ER)-positive
CC       breast cancer cell lines. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9790916}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the AGR family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [4]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA], AND VARIANT GLN-129.
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: As a component of the LINC (LInker of Nucleoskeleton and
CC       Cytoskeleton) complex, involved in the connection between the
CC       nuclear lamina and the cytoskeleton. The nucleocytoplasmic
CC       interactions established by the LINC complex play an important
CC       role in the transmission of mechanical forces across the nuclear
CC       envelope and in nuclear movement and positioning. Required for
CC       telomere attachment to nuclear envelope in the prophase of meiosis
CC       and for rapid telomere prophase movements implicating a
CC       SUN1/2:KASH5 LINC complex in which SUN1 and SUN2 seem to act at
CC       least partial redundantly. Required for homologue pairing during
CC       meiotic prophase in spermatocytes and probably oocytes. Essential
CC       for male and female gametogenesis. Recruits cytoplasmic dynein to
CC       telomere attachment sites at the nuclear envelope in
CC       spermatocytes. In oocytes is involved in meiotic resumption and
CC       spindle formation. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q80VJ8}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Core component the LINC complex which is composed of
CC       inner nuclear membrane SUN domain-containing proteins coupled to
CC       outer nuclear membrane KASH domain-containing nesprins. SUN and
CC       KASH domain-containing proteins seem to bind each other
CC       promiscuously; however, differentially expression of LINC complex
CC       constituents is giving rise to specific assemblies. At least
CC       SUN1/2-containing core LINC complexes are proposed to be hexameric
CC       composed of three protomers of each KASH and SUN domain-containing
CC       protein. Interacts (via the last 22 AA) with SUN1; this
CC       interaction mediates its telomere localization by forming a
CC       SUN1:KASH5 LINC complex. Component of a probable SUN2:KASH5 LINC
CC       complex. Self-associates. Interacts with DYNC1H1, DCTN1, DYNC1I1/2
CC       and PAFAH1B1; suggesting the association with the dynein-dynactin
CC       motor complex. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q80VJ8}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Plays a role in vesicular protein sorting. Required for
CC       the endosome-to-Golgi retrieval of the vacuolar protein sorting
CC       receptor VPS10. Component of the membrane-associated retromer
CC       complex which is essential in endosome-to-Golgi retrograde
CC       transport. The VPS29-VPS26-VPS35 subcomplex may be involved in
CC       cargo selection.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the retromer complex which consists of
CC       VPS29, VPS26, VPS35, VPS5 and VPS17. Component of a retromer
CC       subcomplex consisting of VPS29, VPS26 and VPS35.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9700157}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P34110:VPS35; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-13092, EBI-20415;
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 259 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the VPS29 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: DNA-binding protein that specifically binds the
CC       regulatory region of middle sporulation genes (MSE). Required for
CC       the repression of middle sporulation genes during vegetative
CC       growth. Represses expression via the recruitment of histone
CC       deacetylase HST1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10562556}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with RFM1. This interaction is required to
CC       recruit HST1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12612074}.

CC       P38074:HMT1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-18547, EBI-8394;

CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 149 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

RP   FUNCTION, TOPOLOGY, INTERACTION WITH GPI2, AND IDENTIFICATION IN THE
RP   GPI-GLCNAC TRANSFERASE COMPLEX.
RX   PubMed=16278447; DOI=10.1128/EC.4.11.1801-1807.2005;
RA   Newman H.A., Romeo M.J., Lewis S.E., Yan B.C., Orlean P., Levin D.E.;
RT   "Gpi19, the Saccharomyces cerevisiae homologue of mammalian PIG-P, is
RT   a subunit of the initial enzyme for glycosylphosphatidylinositol
RT   anchor biosynthesis.";
RL   Eukaryot. Cell 4:1801-1807(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the complex catalyzing the transfer of N-
CC       acetylglucosamine from UDP-N-acetylglucosamine to
CC       phosphatidylinositol, the first step of GPI biosynthesis. Involved
CC       in cell wall biosynthesis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16278447}.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: UDP-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine + 1-phosphatidyl-
CC       1D-myo-inositol = UDP + 6-(N-acetyl-alpha-D-glucosaminyl)-1-
CC       phosphatidyl-1D-myo-inositol.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Glycolipid biosynthesis; glycosylphosphatidylinositol-
CC       anchor biosynthesis.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of the phosphatidylinositol N-
CC       acetylglucosaminyltransferase (GPI-GlcNAc transferase) complex
CC       composed of at least GPI1, GPI2, GPI3, GPI15, GPI19 and ERI1
CC       (Probable). Interacts with GPI2 (PubMed:16278447).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16278447, ECO:0000305|PubMed:16278447}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 752 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the GPI19 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in inositol deacylation of GPI-anchored
CC       proteins which plays important roles in the quality control and
CC       ER-associated degradation of GPI-anchored proteins. Required for
CC       the transport of misfolded protein to the Golgi, although
CC       dipensable for the transport of many normal proteins.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11673477, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14734546,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16319176, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8862519}.

CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=7500943; DOI=10.1007/BF00290368;
RA   Roemer T., Bussey H.;

RL   Mol. Gen. Genet. 249:209-216(1995).

RX   PubMed=11853673; DOI=10.1016/S0092-8674(02)00634-7;

RT   "Kre1p, the plasma membrane receptor for the yeast K1 viral toxin.";
RL   Cell 108:395-405(2002).
RN   [8]
RP   LEVEL OF PROTEIN EXPRESSION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=14562106; DOI=10.1038/nature02046;
RA   Ghaemmaghami S., Huh W.-K., Bower K., Howson R.W., Belle A.,
RA   Dephoure N., O'Shea E.K., Weissman J.S.;
RT   "Global analysis of protein expression in yeast.";
RL   Nature 425:737-741(2003).
RN   [9]
RP   FUNCTION, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=15470101; DOI=10.1099/mic.0.27175-0;
RA   Breinig F., Schleinkofer K., Schmitt M.J.;
RT   "Yeast Kre1p is GPI-anchored and involved in both cell wall assembly
RT   and architecture.";
RL   Microbiology 150:3209-3218(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in a late stage of cell wall 1,6-beta-glucan
CC       synthesis and assembly. Has a structural, rather than enzymic,
CC       function within cell wall 1,6-beta-glucan assembly and
CC       architecture, possibly by being involved in covalently cross-
CC       linking 1,6-beta-glucans to other cell wall components such as
CC       1,3-beta-glucan, chitin and certain mannoproteins. Acts as the
CC       plasma membrane receptor for the yeast K1 viral toxin.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11853673, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15470101}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Lipid-anchor, GPI-anchor.
CC       Secreted, cell wall. Note=Identified as GPI-anchored plasma
CC       membrane protein (GPI-PMP) as well as component of the cell wall.
CC       Concentrated at the surface of mother cells.
CC   -!- PTM: Extensively modified; probably through addition of O-linked
CC       mannose residues.
CC   -!- PTM: The GPI-anchor is attached to the protein in the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum and serves to target the protein to the cell surface.
CC       There, the glucosamine-inositol phospholipid moiety is cleaved off
CC       and the GPI-modified mannoprotein is covalently attached via its
CC       lipidless GPI glycan remnant to the 1,6-beta-glucan of the outer
CC       cell wall layer (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 623 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the KRE1 family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT THR-277, AND IDENTIFICATION
RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RX   PubMed=18407956; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M700468-MCP200;
RA   Albuquerque C.P., Smolka M.B., Payne S.H., Bafna V., Eng J., Zhou H.;
RT   "A multidimensional chromatography technology for in-depth
RT   phosphoproteome analysis.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 7:1389-1396(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The coatomer is a cytosolic protein complex that binds
CC       to dilysine motifs and reversibly associates with Golgi non-
CC       clathrin-coated vesicles, which further mediate biosynthetic
CC       protein transport from the ER, via the Golgi up to the trans Golgi
CC       network. Coatomer complex is required for budding from Golgi
CC       membranes, and is essential for the retrograde Golgi-to-ER
CC       transport of dilysine-tagged proteins (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Oligomeric complex that consists of at least the alpha,
CC       beta, beta', gamma, delta, epsilon and zeta subunits. Interacts
CC       with DSL1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14504276}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm {ECO:0000250}. Golgi apparatus
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein {ECO:0000250};
CC       Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, COPI-coated
CC       vesicle membrane {ECO:0000250}; Peripheral membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Cytoplasmic side {ECO:0000250}. Note=The coatomer
CC       is cytoplasmic or polymerized on the cytoplasmic side of the
CC       Golgi, as well as on the vesicles/buds originating from it.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 18000 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the adaptor complexes medium subunit
CC       family. Delta-COP subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17261844}.

CC       heterooligomer consisting of a GRH1 dimer and a BUG1 dimer.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16269340, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17261844}.

CC       with GRH1.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The coatomer is a cytosolic protein complex that binds
CC       to dilysine motifs and reversibly associates with Golgi non-
CC       clathrin-coated vesicles, which further mediate biosynthetic
CC       protein transport from the ER, via the Golgi up to the trans Golgi
CC       network. Coatomer complex is required for budding from Golgi
CC       membranes, and is essential for the retrograde Golgi-to-ER
CC       transport of dilysine-tagged proteins.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Oligomeric complex that consists of at least the alpha,
CC       beta, beta', gamma, delta, epsilon and zeta subunits. Interacts
CC       with the ESCRT-0 subunit VPS27. Interacts with KEI1 (via C-
CC       terminal region). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17101773,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19726565}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P41811:SEC27; NbExp=18; IntAct=EBI-4860, EBI-4898;
CC       P40509:SEC28; NbExp=11; IntAct=EBI-4860, EBI-4884;
CC       P33767:WBP1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-4860, EBI-12658;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm. Golgi apparatus membrane;
CC       Peripheral membrane protein; Cytoplasmic side. Cytoplasmic
CC       vesicle, COPI-coated vesicle membrane; Peripheral membrane
CC       protein; Cytoplasmic side. Note=The coatomer is cytoplasmic or
CC       polymerized on the cytoplasmic side of the Golgi, as well as on
CC       the vesicles/buds originating from it.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 15200 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the synthesis of the sugar donor Dol-P-Man
CC       which is required in the synthesis of N-linked and O-linked
CC       oligosaccharides and for that of GPI anchors. It is required for
CC       spore germination. Has an essential role in cellular metabolism.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: CTP + dolichol = CDP + dolichyl phosphate.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein glycosylation.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the polyprenol kinase family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Constituent of COPII-coated endoplasmic reticulum-
CC       derived transport vesicles. Required for efficient transport of a
CC       subset of secretory proteins to the Golgi. The C-terminal di-
CC       lysine motif is required for exit from the endoplasmic reticulum.
CC       Required directly for packaging glycosylated pro-alpha-factor into
CC       COPII vesicles. Facilitates retrograde transport from the Golgi to
CC       the endoplasmic reticulum. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11711675,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15516922}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P38353:SSH1; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-23662, EBI-18175;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11157978}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11157978}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The di-lysine motif confers endoplasmic reticulum
CC       localization for type I membrane proteins. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the SURF4 family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Constituent of COPII-coated endoplasmic reticulum-
CC       derived transport vesicles. Required for efficient transport of a
CC       subset of secretory proteins to the Golgi. Possesses a C-terminal
CC       dilysine motif that interacts with COPI coat subunits. Facilitates
CC       retrograde transport from the Golgi to the endoplasmic reticulum.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11560939, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8900179}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Associates with EMP24, ERP1 and ERP2.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P32803:EMP24; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-6642, EBI-6431;
CC       Q05359:ERP1; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-6642, EBI-6581;
CC       P38819:ERP5; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-6642, EBI-6603;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane; Single-pass
CC       type I membrane protein. Golgi apparatus membrane; Single-pass
CC       type I membrane protein. Note=Recycles between endoplasmic
CC       reticulum and Golgi.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Present with 51700 molecules/cell in log phase SD
CC       medium. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14562106}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the EMP24/GP25L family. {ECO:0000305}.
